row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Interior of the Market House
row.abstract: Knoxville's original Market House was built in 1816. During the Civil War, the Union used the Market House to store ammunition and business was conducted outside. A new Market House was built in 1897 and merchants offered a wide variety of items, including baked goods, fresh meats, and homegrown fruits and vegetables from permanent stalls and wagons parked outside. After being partially destroyed by fire, this structure was demolished to make way for the Market Street Mall in 1960. This image shows the market's meat section in the early 20th century.

row.title: Cotton Looms at Brookside Mills
row.abstract: Brookside Cotton Mills was founded in 1885. By 1902, it was Knoxville's largest employer with 1,200 employees. The mill ceased operations in 1956, and the last of its buildings was destroyed in 1997. The Development Corporation of Knox County purchased the property in 2006 with the intention of redeveloping it.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Louisville & Nashville Railroad Depot
row.abstract: Until the Louisville & Nashville Railroad gained entrance to Knoxville in 1905, the Southern Railway held a monopoly on rail traffic through the city. This depot was completed in 1906 and featured such amenities as a Ladies' Waiting Room with a private entrance, a fireplace, rocking chairs, and desks complete with L&N stationary. The building was renovated for the 1982 World's Fair and today houses two restaurants opened shortly after the renovation was complete.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Gay Street Bridge
row.abstract: The Union Army built Knoxville's first bridge across the Tennessee River during the Civil War. This structure was washed away in 1867 and subsequently replaced by a toll bridge. A tornado destroyed this span in 1875, and a fourth bridge was constructed in 1880. This structure lasted until 1898, when it was replaced by a modern and much-admired steel bridge. This particular image was "published for the benefit of the 'Children's Mission Home'" in Knoxville.

row.subject_topical: Motion picture producers and directors--United States | http://id.loc.gov/authorities/subjects/sh87006130
row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Clarence Brown in Plane
row.abstract: Clarence Brown was born on May 10, 1890, in Clinton, Massachusetts. He moved with his family to Knoxville, Tennessee as a child and graduated from Knoxville High School in 1905. Brown received a double degree in mechanical and electrical engineering from the University of Tennessee in 1910 and then began a career selling automobiles in Alabama. Fascinated with movies, he moved to New Jersey where he studied with French director Maurice Tourneur at Peerless Studios. There, the pair directed The Last of the Mohicans (1920). Brown directed or produced more than fifty widely-acclaimed full length motion pictures and worked with many of the most famous performers in the film industry, including Joan Crawford and Clark Gable in Chained (1934), Spencer Tracy in Edison the Man (1940), Elizabeth Taylor in National Velvet (1945), and Gregory Peck in The Yearling (1947). At the time of his retirement in 1952, Brown had received six Academy Award nominations for Best Director and won eight Oscars for his films. When he died in 1987, Brown left $12 million to the University of Tennessee. When added to the $1 million donated during his lifetime, the sum made him the largest donor in the university's history.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Portrait of Miss Will Allen Dromgoole
row.abstract: William Allen Dromgoole (usually called "Will Allen" and known widely as "Miss Will") was born to John Easter and Rebecca Blanche Dromgoole in Murfreesboro, Tennessee in 1860. She graduated from the Clarksville Female Academy in 1876 and went on to study at the New England School of Expression in Boston. After her mother's death in 1884, Dromgoole returned to Tennessee to care for her ageing father and began a career as a writer. She published her first novel, _The Sunny Side of the Cumberlands_, under the name "Will Allen" in 1886. She also studied law with her father and won terms as a clerk in the Tennessee State Senate in 1885 and 1887. She was, however, defeated in 1889 and 1891. After her second defeat, she traveled to Texas, where she taught and wrote for several newspapers. She soon returned to Nashville, where she spent her time with her father until his death in 1897. In 1900, she began writing for the _Nashville Banner_. She was hired as a permanent staff member in 1902 and began writing her popular column, titled "Song and Story," in 1903. She continued this column for 31 years. Dromgoole also volunteered for the U.S. Navy during World War I and was recruited as a yeomanry warrant officer (possibly the first woman to serve in this capacity) in May of 1917. She died on September 1, 1934 and was buried in Evergreen Cemetery in Murfreesboro, Tennessee.

row.title: Young Men's Christian Association (YMCA)
row.abstract: Knoxville's first YMCA was organized in 1854 at the Second Presbyterian Church. The organization moved to this structure, standing on the corner of Commerce and State, in 1900. They continued to meet here until 1929, when they moved to a newer edifice on the corner of Locust and Clinch.

row.title: Participants in UT's 1940 Rose Bowl Appearance
row.abstract: View of various acquaintances of the 1940 UT football team at the time of their trip to the Rose Bowl. In the front are (left to right) Jack Joyner (UT publicity director), Walter Stewart (representing the Memphis Commercial Appeal), Fred Russell (representing the Nashville Banner), Virgie Wacks (representing twelve Tennessee newspapers), George Bugsee (representing the Memphis Press Scimitar), and Raymond Johnson (representing the Nashville Tennesseean). In the back are Clarence Brown (UT alumnus and Chairman of California Arrangements for the UT football team), Ann Morris, Major Robert Neyland (UT football coach), Florence Rice, and Lana Turner. The football team made this visit to the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer studio as guests of Clarence Brown and Louis B. Mayer.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Gillette Ranch Sitting Room
row.abstract: In 1926, Razor baron King Camp Gillette commissioned Wallace Neff to build him a "paradise on earth" in Southern California. The result was a stunning 25 room mansion built in the Spanish Colonial Revival Style whose beauty supposedly brought Gillette to tears. Gillette died in 1932, and his widow sold the property to prominent film director Clarence Brown in 1935. Brown regularly hosted large parties for well-known Hollywood personalities here, and made several changes to the property, including the addition of a projection room and a small airport. He sold the property to the Claretian Order of the Catholic Church in 1952, which used it as a seminary and noviate. The Claretians subsequently sold to Elizabeth Clair Prophet's Church Universal and Triumphant in 1977, which in turn sold to the Soka University of American in 1986. In 2007, Soka sold the property to the National Park Service, which intends to restore and preserve it.

row.title: View toward the United States Pavilion from near the Sunsphere
row.abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

row.title: English Lutheran Church
row.abstract: Knoxville's English Lutheran Church was founded in 1888 and formally incorporated in 1890. It was designed to serve those Lutherans who preferred to worship using English rather than German. The church's congregation grew quickly, and this building was constructed on the corner of Broadway and Emory Streets in 1913. Mrs. Martha Henson donated most of the money for the structure in memory of her late husband, James A. Henson. The building is now known as St. John's Lutheran Church and has been listed on the National Register of Historic Places since April of 1985.

row.title: View in Chilhowee Park
row.abstract: Originally known as Lake Ottossee, Chilhowee Park began to develop as a recreational area in 1890 when William G. McAdoo opened a streetcar line making the lake easily accessible from Knoxville. The area was renamed Chilhowee Park in 1900 and was the site of several expositions between 1910 and 1913. Although it has lost some of its former grandeur, the Park is still a popular recreation area today.

row.abstract: The Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks Home was originally located at 421 W. Main Avenue. The Elks moved to the Home pictured here in 1909, when Colonel J.Y. Johnston took over the Main Avenue property to use as his private residence. This postcard was mailed in 1909.

row.title: Knox County Court House
row.abstract: The first Knox County Court House was designed by architect Drury P. Armstrong and constructed in 1842. It was replaced by a more modern building, built in the Queen Anne style, in 1885. Now called the old Knoxville Courthouse, this structure stands on approximately the site of the Federal barracks of James White's Fort. New wings were added to either side of the courthouse in 1919. The obelisk visible on the courthouse lawn marks the grave of John Sevier, Tennessee's first governor. His wives, Sarah Hawkins and Catherine "Bonny Kate" Sherrill, are buried nearby.

row.title: Greta Garbo in "Inspiration"
row.abstract: In "Inspiration," Andre Martel (Robert Montgomery), a diplomat studying for the consular service, falls in love with Yvonne Valbret (Greta Garbo), an artist's model. The two become lovers, but Martel leaves when he learns of Valbret's sordid past. He later finds her poverty-stricken and buys her a country home out of pity. He also tells Valbret that he is going to marry another woman, and she pleads with him to marry her instead. Remembering his friend Liane Latour (Karen Morley), who killed herself when her lover Raymond Delval (Lewis Stone) left her, Martel goes to Valbret to rekindle their relationship. When he arrives, he finds another of Valbret's lovers begging her to return to him. Martel agrees to overlook this indiscretion, but Valbret, determined not to destroy him, writes him a farewell note and leaves while he is asleep.

row.title: Chairlifts Near the Base of the State of Tennessee Amphitheater
row.abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

row.title: Joan Crawford in "Possessed"
row.abstract: "Possessed" is the story of Marian Martin (Joan Crawford), a factory girl who moves to Manhattan looking for excitement and hoping to trade her life on the assembly line for one more posh. When she meets lawyer Mark Whitney (Clark Gable), she thinks her dreams have come true%3A he is rich and handsome and can buy her the life she dreams of. Unfortunately, he is already married and his political ambitions would be destroyed by a divorce scandal. Thus, Martin becomes his mistress and poses as his ex-wife. When her small town ex-boyfriend Al Manning (Wallace Ford) asks her to marry him, she turns him down and he exposes Whitney's sordid private life. Martin is forced to defend her relationship with Whitney at an election rally, and her story moves the crowd to tears. Relieved, Whitney proposes to Martin, thus fulfilling her ambitions.

row.title: Clarence, Larkin, and Catherine (Gaw) Brown
row.abstract: Larkin Harry Brown was born on April 8, 1866 to John and Mary (White) Brown in Pennsylvania. He married Katherine Ann Gaw (1865-1964) on July 29, 1889 and the couple settled in Massachusetts. Their one child, Clarence Leon Brown, was born on May 10, 1890. In about 1902, the family moved to Knoxville, Tennessee where Larkin Brown worked for Brookside Mills. After Clarence Brown became a prominent film director, Larkin and Katherine followed him to Southern California, where Larkin Brown died on March 11, 1942.

row.title: Tennessee State Capitol Building
row.abstract: In the early 20th century, popular theory held that this building, located on Cumberland Avenue, was the first state capitol of Tennessee. There is, however, no evidence to support this claim - indeed, several astute commentators have pointed out that this structure was not built until after the capital had moved to Middle Tennessee. In any case, the building was razed in January of 1927.

row.title: Clarence Brown with "National Velvet" Cast
row.abstract: "National Velvet" stars Elizabeth Taylor as Velvet Brown, an English girl with a passion for horses who wins the spirited but untrained steed Pie in a town auction. Velvet is determined to win the prestigious Grand National, and jaded jockey Mi Taylor (Mickey Rooney) is hired to train her. Although Velvet's father (Donald Crisp) disapproves, her mother (Anne Revere), recalling her own girlhood ambitions, repeatedly overrules his decisions in favor of their headstrong daughter. Against all odds, Velvet and Pie go on to win the Steeplechase at the Grand National.

row.title: Island Home Farm
row.abstract: Perez Dickinson was born in Amherst, Massachusetts in 1813. He moved to Knoxville in about 1830, where he quickly became an extremely popular and successful merchant. He purchased Williams Island (located in the Tennessee River) in 1869. Here, he constructed a manor house and established Island Home Farm. He raised crops of fruits and vegetables until his death in 1901.

row.title: William Gannaway "Parson" Brownlow Residence
row.abstract: Controversial Methodist preacher and newspaperman William Gannaway "Parson" Brownlow was born in 1805 in Wythe County, Virginia. His zest for confrontation and staunch Union loyalties convinced the Confederacy to expel him from Tennessee during the Civil War, but he returned to Tennessee in March of 1865 when he was elected governor. During his term, Brownlow convinced the legislature to ratify the 14th Amendment (thus sparing Tennessee from Reconstruction) and made great progress toward restoring the State's economic health. He served one term in the US Senate before dying in 1877.

row.title: Rudolph Valentino in "The Eagle"
row.abstract: Based on a Pushkin novel, "The Eagle" stars Rudolph Valentino as a Russian cossack named Vladimir Dubrouvsky. He is one of Catherine the Great's particular favorites, but he will not be kept as a lover and spurns her advances. When Kyrilla Troekouroff steals his lands, he creates a secret identity, "The Black Eagle," and becomes a masked avenger. Although bent on revenge, he falls in love with Troekouroff's daughter, Mascha (Vilma Banky). Mascha, in turn, worships the Eagle but disdains his unmasked identity, her foppish French tutor Monsieur Le Blanc. Dubrouvsky's love for Masha eventually counteracts his desire for revenge against her father, and the couple flee Troekouroff's estate. Although captured by the Czarina's men, Catherine rescinds her orders to execute the Eagle and the pair escape to Paris.

row.title: Clarence Brown on the Set of "Deep Waters"
row.abstract: The film "Deep Waters," directed by Clarence Brown's mentor Maurice Tourneur, was adapted from the book "Caleb West: Master Diver" by Francis H. Smith and released in 1920. In the movie, Henry Sanford (Henry Woodward) is building a lighthouse at Keyport when he falls in love with Kate Leroy (Florence Deshon). Unfortunately, she is already married to wealthy Morgan Leroy (Jack McDonald). Simultaneously, Betty (Barbara Bedford), wife of master diver Caleb West (Broerkin Christians), attracts the attention of Bill Lacey (John Gilbert), who works with her husband. When Lacey is injured, Betty takes care of him and eventually agrees to run away with him. She soon repents of her rash action, but her husband will not take her back. Later, Lacey's ship is wrecked near the new lighthouse and West makes a dive to recover his body. Upon returning to the surface, he discovers that Betty has been operating his air pump, and the two reconcile.

row.title: Australian and Chinese Pavilions
row.abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

row.title: View of Strong Hall (White Avenue Side)
row.abstract: Sophronia Strong Hall (known colloquially as "Sophie's") was built in 1925 when the University found itself in need of a larger women's dormitory. Benjamin Rush Strong (1848-1915) had left the University $30,000 in his will for the purpose on the condition that the resulting building be named after his mother, Sophronia (Marrs) Strong, and that a wildflower garden be planted every spring in her memory. Several wings were added in the 1950s, each named after one of the first co-eds to attend the University. Sophronia Strong's ghost was said to watch over the Hall's residents, appearing as a lady dressed in white on her birthday (February 17) and perpetrating various harmless pranks. The last residents of the hall moved out after the 2008 Spring Semester and the building was put to other uses.

row.title: Mary Cora de Garmo Bryan
row.abstract: Portrait of Mary Cora de Garmo Bryan. Born on August 28, 1891, Mary was the first child of Frank and Mary Eloise (Donnell) de Garmo. She earned her A.B. (1912) and M.A. (1913) degrees at Washington College and eventually obtained a Ph.D from Cornell University (1931). She married Charles W. Bryan Jr., a prominent civil engineer, on June 9, 1920. During her career as a nutritionist, she taught at several educational institutions, edited the "Journal of Home Economics," wrote four books, helped to develop the national school lunch program, and served in a variety of professional organizations. She died in Illinois on May 12, 1986.

row.title: Grand Army of the Republic Monument
row.abstract: The first Grand Army of the Republic monument was erected in the northeast corner of Knoxville's National Cemetery in 1901. This memorial featured a column of Tennessee marble topped by a statue of a Union soldier and a bronze eagle with his wings spread. This monument was struck by lightning and destroyed on August 22, 1904. Its replacement, shown here, was completed on October 15, 1906. It features a miniature medieval fortress and a central column topped with a statue of a Union soldier at parade rest. A contemporary local legend identifies him as General John T. Wilder, who was the only ranking general on the memorial committee.

row.title: Buck Karns Bridge
row.abstract: The Buck Karns bridge was named for Knoxville resident James (Buck) Karns, who was one of six Tennesseeans to earn the Congressional Medal of Honor during World War I. The bridge is part of US-129 and crosses the Tennessee River near the University of Tennessee's Agricultural Campus. It is also known as the Alcoa Highway Bridge.

row.title: Interior of the Market House
row.abstract: Knoxville's original Market House was built in 1816. During the Civil War, the Union used the Market House to store ammunition and business was conducted outside. A new Market House was built in 1897 and merchants offered a wide variety of items, including baked goods, fresh meats, and homegrown fruits and vegetables from permanent stalls and wagons parked outside. After being partially destroyed by fire, this structure was demolished to make way for the Market Street Mall in 1960. This image shows the stalls of two of Knoxville's most prominent bakers, Kern's and Swan's, as well as W.E. Bradley's vegetable stall.

row.title: John T. Whitaker and Unidentified Man
row.abstract: John Thompson Whitaker was born on January 25, 1906. He earned his A.B. from the University of the South in 1927 and went on to write for the Chattanooga News and the New York Herald Tribune. He eventually became a foreign correspondent and covered the Ethiopian and Spanish Civil Wars before being stationed in Europe during World War II. He wrote three books%3A And Fear Came (1936), Americas to the South (1939), and We Cannot Escape History (1943). He died on September 11, 1946.

row.abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. row.title: Oakwood Mansion
row.abstract: Charles J. McClung built Oakwood Mansion for his son, Matthew McClung, in 1870. The house changed hands in 1873, when it became home to Matthew's sister Lucy and her husband, Jacob Lytton Thomas. The home was then located at the outskirts of town, allowing Thomas to farm and raise livestock. Railroad contractor Henry H. Thrasher purchased the house in about 1905 and remodeled it completely, adding porches, columns, and the brick exterior. He sold it in the late 1920s to a group of physicians, who renamed it the Howard-Henderson Hospital. It was briefly known as the Acuff Clinic before becoming the Kingston Pike Motel in the late 1950s. When that enterprise failed, the structure was remodeled and reopened as the Kingston Pike Nursing Home. It continued in this capacity until the early 1990s. It was home to a number of businesses, including a beauty parlor and a restaurant, before Sam Furrow purchased it in 1999. The structure currently serves as office space for a number of enterprises.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Post Office
row.abstract: Completed in 1874, Knoxville's Post Office and Custom House may have been the city's first building to be designed by a professional architect, in this case Alfred B. Mullett. The structure was enlarged in 1910 and operated until a new Post Office was constructed in 1934. The TVA occupied the building until 1976, when it was restored and repurposed as the East Tennessee Historical Center.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Fort James White
row.abstract: General James White built this house, the first in Knoxville, in 1786. It was originally located at one corner of a rectangular lot with smaller houses in the other three corners, a common frontier design intended to protect against Indians. After the White family established a farm away from this location, the structure was repurposed as the kitchen wing of the Kennedy residence on State Street. In 1906, Isaiah Ford purchased the building and moved it to Woodlawn Pike, where he used it as a private residence. It changed hands again in 1970, when the City Association of Women's Clubs purchased the home and moved it back to central Knoxville. It currently stands near the Knoxville Coliseum and is one of the most visited historical sites in the city.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Shadow of the Mysterious Murderer in "The Goose Woman"
row.abstract: Shadow of the Mysterious Murderer (played by Clarence Brown) in "The Goose Woman." The movie (inspired by the famous Halls-Mills murder case) stars Louise Dresser as Marie Du Nord, an opera singer who loses her voice and her reputation after her illegitimate son is born. Shamed, she returns to her original name (Mary Holmes) and moves back to her hometown. When a murder is committed near her home, she invents a story to return herself to the public eye. Her plan, however, backfires when her son, Gerald (Jack Pickford), is arrested for the murder.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: First Plan of Knoxville
row.abstract: Plan showing the original layout of the city of Knoxville, drawn in about 1791. A number of the city's earliest families are represented on this map, including Humes, Henley, Cowan, McClung, Camp, Beardin, Blount, Strong, Crozier, and Craighead. The section designated "graveyard" at the bottom left survives as the graveyard as the First Presbyterian Church. The original document is available in the Special Collections Library.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Gillette Ranch Sitting Room (with Balcony)
row.abstract: In 1926, Razor baron King Camp Gillette commissioned Wallace Neff to build him a "paradise on earth" in Southern California. The result was a stunning 25 room mansion built in the Spanish Colonial Revival Style whose beauty supposedly brought Gillette to tears. Gillette died in 1932, and his widow sold the property to prominent film director Clarence Brown in 1935. Brown regularly hosted large parties for well-known Hollywood personalities here, and made several changes to the property, including the addition of a projection room and a small airport. He sold the property to the Claretian Order of the Catholic Church in 1952, which used it as a seminary and noviate. The Claretians subsequently sold to Elizabeth Clair Prophet's Church Universal and Triumphant in 1977, which in turn sold to the Soka University of American in 1986. In 2007, Soka sold the property to the National Park Service, which intends to restore and preserve it.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Clarence Brown Directing "Ah! Wilderness"
row.abstract: "Ah! Wilderness" stars Eric Linden as Richard Miller, a young idealist living in Connecticut in 1906. He has just been selected as the valedictorian of his high school class, and intends to inject modern anti-capitalist ideas into his speech. His father (Lionel Barrymore) discovers his plans, however, and prevents him from carrying them out. The town later celebrates the Fourth of July, where Richard spends time with his girlfriend, Muriel McComber (Cecilia Parker). The couple is forced to separate, however, when Muriel's father objects to Richard's letters to Muriel quoting such poets as Omar Khayy%C3%A1m and Swinburne. Heartbroken, Richard goes to a bar, gets drunk, and meets a young prostitute named Belle (Helen Flint). His alcoholic uncle Sid (Wallace Beery) nurses him back to sobriety, but before he can face his parents, he sneaks out to meet Muriel. On his return home, he and his father (who has previously discovered that Muriel's father has changed his mind about Richard) have a talk about the dangers of alcohol and promiscuous women, and all ends well.

row.title: Rudolph Valentino in "The Eagle"
row.abstract: Based on a Pushkin novel, "The Eagle" stars Rudolph Valentino as a Russian cossack named Vladimir Dubrouvsky. He is one of Catherine the Great's particular favorites, but he will not be kept as a lover and spurns her advances. When Kyrilla Troekouroff steals his lands, he creates a secret identity, "The Black Eagle," and becomes a masked avenger. Although bent on revenge, he falls in love with Troekouroff's daughter, Mascha (Vilma Banky). Mascha, in turn, worships the Eagle but disdains his unmasked identity, her foppish French tutor Monsieur Le Blanc. Dubrouvsky's love for Masha eventually counteracts his desire for revenge against her father, and the couple flee Troekouroff's estate. Although captured by the Czarina's men, Catherine rescinds her orders to execute the Eagle and the pair escape to Paris.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Gay Street Bridge
row.abstract: The Union Army built Knoxville's first bridge across the Tennessee River during the Civil War. This structure was washed away in 1867 and subsequently replaced by a toll bridge. A tornado destroyed this span in 1875, and a fourth bridge was constructed in 1880. This structure lasted until 1898, when it was replaced by a modern and much-admired steel bridge.

row.title: Greta Garbo, Lew Cody, John Gilbert, and Clarence Brown on the Set of "Flesh and the Devil"
row.abstract: "Flesh and the Devil" tells the story of two Austrian military men, Leo von Harden (John Gilbert) and Ulrich von Eltz (Lars Hanson), who have been friends since childhood. At the beginning of the movie, von Harden meets (and begins an affair with) Felicitas (Greta Garbo). When her husband Count Von Rhaden (Marc MacDermott) discovers them, he challenges von Harden to a duel. von Harden kills the Count, but his superiors send him to Africa as punishment. When he returns, it is to find Felicitas married to von Eltz, who he had asked to take care of her during his absence. von Harden eventually loses control of himself, and the movie ends with a climactic duel between the two former friends.

row.title: Ellis and Ernest Drugstore
row.abstract: College friends Wilbur Ellis and Harold Ernest opened Ellis and Ernest Drugstore near the University of Tennessee campus in 1926. For many years, E&E served as a popular gathering place for UT students as well as Knoxville residents and tourists. The drugstore was razed in the late 1960s in order to accommodate the Carolyn P. Brown University Center, but the establishment was commemorated with the Ellis and Ernest Friendship Walk.

row.title: Entrance Hall in the Blount Mansion
row.abstract: William Blount (who signed the US Constitution and served as the Governor of the Territory of the United States South of the Ohio River) and his wife Mary commissioned this home in 1792. In addition to its size, the home boasted a number of features not commonly seen on the frontier, including hardwood floors and glass windows. A group of women led by Mary Boyce Temple led a campaign to preserve Blount Mansion in the early 1920s, and the house became a museum in 1925.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Entrance to the Technology and Lifestyle Building
row.abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

row.title: Leslie Howard and Norma Shearer in "A Free Soul"
row.abstract: In "A Free Soul," alcoholic lawyer Stephen Ashe (Lionel Barrymore) takes on the case of dashing gangster Ace Wilfong (Clark Gable). Ashe's daughter Jan (Norma Shearer) soon falls in love with Wilfong, and the pair run away to New York. Concerned for his daughter's safety, Ashe seeks her out and strikes a bargain%3A he'll stop drinking if she'll leave Wilfong. Both renig, and Jan returns to Wilfong. He has become brutal, however, and tries to molest her. She is saved by her ex-fiance, Dwight Winthrop (Leslie Howard), who murders Wilfong and is arrested. Jan begs her father to defend Winthrop, and Ashe confesses to the murder himself so that Jan and Winthrop can stay together. This confession leads to his own death at the hands of Wilfong's vengeful gang. "A Free Soul" was remade as "The Girl Who Has Everything" with Elizabeth Taylor in 1953.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: St. James Hotel
row.abstract: Originally known as the Van Deventer building, the St. James Hotel was built shortly after the "Million Dollar Fire" of 1897. During the 1920s, the hotel developed a reputation as a musical center: WNOX (earlier WNAV) was located at the St. James by 1923, and the Brunswick/Vocalion label set up temporary quarters in the building in 1929. A number of artists, many of whom went on to achieve national and international recognition, made recordings here during the "St. James Sessions" of 1929-1930. The hotel was demolished in 1973.

row.title: East Tennessee Baptist Hospital
row.abstract: In 1943, a group of East Tennessee Baptists conceived of building a Baptist Hospital in Knoxville to alleviate a pronounced shortage of available hospital beds in that city. The East Tennessee Baptist Hospital was completed in 1948 at a cost of $3,128,000. It provided space for 254 inpatients and was considered one of the most modern hospitals in the South. A number of additions have been made over the years, including the Blount Professional Building, the Baptist Professional Building, a Chapel, the Baptist Medical Tower, a Heart Center, an Eye Institute, a Regional Cancer Center, and several branches. The hospital continues to prosper and serve East Tennessee today.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Portrait of Don Whitehead
row.abstract: Donald Ford Whitehead was born to Harry Ford and Elizabeth (Bond) Whitehead on April 8, 1908 in Inman, Virginia. He was raised in Kentucky and earned his degree in journalism from the University of Kentucky in 1928. After graduating, he worked for several newspapers in Kentucky and Tennessee before joining the Associated Press in 1935. He worked as a feature writer in New York for several years and eventually became a foreign correspondent. In this role, he reported on World War II (including the North Africa campaign), postwar atomic testing, and the Korean War. He went on to win two Pulitzer Prizes (1951 and 1953) and write several books, including the bestseller The FBI Story (1956). He also worked for both the New York Herald Tribune and the Knoxville News-Sentinel before retiring in 1978. He married Marie Patterson (1906-1979) on 20 December 1928 and the couple had one daughter, Ruth. Whitehead died in Knoxville, Tennessee on January 12, 1981 of lung cancer at age 72.

row.title: Mickey Rooney in "National Velvet"
row.abstract: "National Velvet" stars Elizabeth Taylor as Velvet Brown, an English girl with a passion for horses who wins the spirited but untrained steed Pie in a town auction. Velvet is determined to win the prestigious Grand National, and jaded jockey Mi Taylor (Mickey Rooney) is hired to train her. Although Velvet's father (Donald Crisp) disapproves, her mother (Anne Revere), recalling her own girlhood ambitions, repeatedly overrules his decisions in favor of their headstrong daughter. Against all odds, Velvet and Pie go on to win the Steeplechase at the Grand National.

row.title: Farragut Hotel
row.abstract: Named after Admiral David Glasgow Farragut, the Hotel Farragut opened on the corner of Gay and Clinch (the site of the old Imperial Hotel) on February 1, 1919. It flourished until 1929 when the Andrew Johnson Hotel opened nearby, after which time the two hotels provided each other with stiff competition. The Farragut closed in 1977 and was converted into office space in 1978.

row.title: Hotel Andrew Johnson
row.abstract: The Andrew Johnson Hotel opened on Gay Street in 1929 and prospered throughout the Great Depression. Its numerous guests included Jean Paul Sarte, Duke Ellington, Amelia Erhart, Liberace, Tony Perkins, and Sergei Rachmaninoff. Knox County purchased the building in 1990, and is considering selling the property for a mix of residential and commercial uses as of June 2007.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Company K Moving to Front Lines
row.abstract: The original caption of this image reads "Part of Company K moving to the Front Lines. March 31- 1941. Camp Barkley, Texas. Corp. Roer. P.F.C. Peck. Co K 158th Inf. 45th Div." The 158th Infantry Regiment began as the First Arizona Volunteer Infantry on September 2, 1865. It was drafted into Federal service during World War I as part of the 40th Division and reassigned to the 45th Division during postwar reorganizations. When a National Emergency was declared on September 16, 1940, the 158th joined the 45th for training at Fort Sill, Oklahoma and Fort Barkley, Texas. They were detached from the 45th in December of 1941 and sent to the Canal Zone for training in jungle warfare before being assigned to the Pacific Theater in early 1943. The unit was scheduled to spearhead the final invasion of Japan, which was subsequently rendered unnecessary by the atomic bomb. The 158th was deactivated and sent home in January of 1946.

row.title: Clarence Brown in Childhood
row.abstract: Clarence Brown was born on May 10, 1890, in Clinton, Massachusetts. He moved with his family to Knoxville, Tennessee as a child and graduated from Knoxville High School in 1905. Brown received a double degree in mechanical and electrical engineering from the University of Tennessee in 1910 and then began a career selling automobiles in Alabama. Fascinated with movies, he moved to New Jersey where he studied with French director Maurice Tourneur at Peerless Studios. There, the pair directed "The Last of the Mohicans" (1920). Brown directed or produced more than fifty widely-acclaimed full length motion pictures and worked with many of the most famous performers in the film industry, including Joan Crawford and Clark Gable in "Chained" (1934), Spencer Tracy in "Edison the Man" (1940), Elizabeth Taylor in "National Velvet" (1945), and Gregory Peck in "The Yearling" (1947). At the time of his retirement in 1952, Brown had received six Academy Award nominations for Best Director and won eight Oscars for his films. When he died in 1987, Brown left $12 million to the University of Tennessee. When added to the $1 million donated during his lifetime, the sum made him the largest donor in the university's history.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Knox County Court House
row.abstract: The first Knox County Court House was designed by architect Drury P. Armstrong and constructed in 1842. It was replaced by a more modern building, built in the Queen Anne style, in 1885. Now called the old Knoxville Courthouse, this structure stands on approximately the site of the Federal barracks of James White's Fort. New wings were added to either side of the courthouse in 1919. The obelisk visible on the courthouse lawn marks the grave of John Sevier, Tennessee's first governor. His wives, Sarah Hawkins and Catherine "Bonny Kate" Sherrill, are buried nearby.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Australian Pavilion and UT Buildings
row.abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

row.abstract: John Edwin and Adelia (Armstrong) Lutz built this home, called "Westwood," on Knoxville's Kingston Pike in approximately 1890. J.E. Lutz was a successful merchant and insurance broker in Knoxville during the early 20th century. The home was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1984.

row.title: Raising of Gay Street
row.abstract: In 1919, the north end of Gay Street was raised by 15 feet and the Gay Street viaduct constructed. A number of shops moved to locations under the new viaduct, where they prospered for many years. Unfortunately, the structure gradually fell into disrepair and was closed for demolition in November of 2005. It was replaced by a concrete viaduct in late 2006, which remains in use today.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: First Baptist Church
row.abstract: Brothers James and John Moses organized the congregation that would become Knoxville's First Baptist Church in 1843. The church's first permanent house of worship stood on Gay Street and was completed in 1850. The congregation split in 1869, and the dissidents formed Knoxville's Second Baptist Church. The First Baptist Church moved to their second home (made possible in large part by merchant and philanthropist W.W. Woodruff) in 1888. Their current house of worship, located at the corner of Walnut and Main Streets, was completed in 1924 and is still in use today. It was placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1997.

row.title: Mrs. Frank de Garmo
row.abstract: Mary Eloise de Garmo (right) with an unidentified woman. de Garmo was born Mary Eloise Donnell on November 3, 1865 in Covington, Kentucky. She attended college in Illinois and taught school in Missouri before marrying Frank de Garmo in 1890. During the early part of the 20th century, de Garmo was active in a number of women's organizations. She worked tirelessly to improve children's health care, serving as the national chairperson of the Department of Good Roads for Child Welfare and founding the Better Babies movement. The first Better Babies Contest was held at the Louisiana State Fair in 1908 and national events, held for children aged six months to three years, followed soon after. During the 1930s, de Garmo served as the President of the Louisiana Mothers' Congress and as the President of the National Mothers' Union. The de Garmos had two children%3A Margaret de Garmo Payne and Mary Cora Bryan. Mary E. de Garmo passed away on September 24, 1953, in Chicago, Illinois.

row.title: Entrance to Chilhowee Park
row.abstract: Originally known as Lake Ottossee, Chilhowee Park began to develop as a recreational area in 1890 when William G. McAdoo opened a streetcar line making the lake easily accessible from Knoxville. The area was renamed Chilhowee Park in 1900 and was the site of several expositions between 1910 and 1913. Although it has lost some of its former grandeur, the Park is still a popular recreation area today.

row.title: John T. Whitaker in Military Uniform
row.abstract: John Thompson Whitaker was born on January 25, 1906. He earned his A.B. from the University of the South in 1927 and went on to write for the Chattanooga News and the New York Herald Tribune. He eventually became a foreign correspondent and covered the Ethiopian and Spanish Civil Wars before being stationed in Europe during World War II. He wrote three books%3A And Fear Came (1936), Americas to the South (1939), and We Cannot Escape History (1943). He died on September 11, 1946.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Talahi Park
row.abstract: In Robert L. Nash's original vision, Talahi was to be not just a park but an entire upper-class subdivision in west Knoxville. He acquired land adjoining Knoxville's new Sequoyah Hills neighborhood in 1926 and began marketing it to potential residents in 1929. Only one lot was sold before the Great Depression, which put an end to Nash's dream. After his 1933 suicide, Sequoyah Hills effectively annexed Talahi, which developed with the rest of the area into one of Knoxville's toniest neighborhoods.

row.title: Cherokee Textile Mills
row.abstract: Cherokee Textile Mills was founded in Knoxville, Tennessee in 1917. It produced fine cotton goods on a contract basis. The Mill moved from Knoxville to Sevierville, Tennessee, in 1954 as a result of Sevierville's 1951 decision to issue revenue bonds to attract nonlocal business.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: United States Pavilion
row.abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: View on the Set of "A Woman of Affairs"
row.abstract: "A Woman of Affairs" stars Greta Garbo as Diana Merrick, a worldly socialite who has loved Neville 'Nevs' Holderness (John Gilbert) since both were children. Nevs' father disapproves, and sends Nevs to Egypt to work after convincing him not to marry Diana. Two years later, Diana marries another childhood friend, David Furness (Johnny Mack Brown), who later commits suicide in Paris. As a result of the tragedy, Diana is cast out of upper-class English society and embarks on a string of meaningless affairs with men around the world. She eventually returns to England days before Nevs' wedding to Constance (Dorothy Sebastian).

row.title: Whittle Springs Hotel
row.abstract: The original Whittle Springs Hotel was built in about 1902 about three miles to the north of Knoxville. It advertised such conveniences as electric lights, baths, unexcelled cuisine, and both telephone and telegraph connections. This structure burned in 1919, and the second Whittle Springs Hotel (shown) was constructed on the same site. This building was razed in 1964.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: First Methodist Episcopal Church
row.abstract: The first Methodist Episcopal Church was organized shortly after the Civil War by the Reverend J.B. Ford. Their first permanent church, dedicated in 1869, stood on the corner of Clinch and Market Streets. The congregation grew quickly and moved to this church, located on the corner of Clinch Avenue and Locust Street, in 1894. The building was designed in the Romanesque style by architect H.H. Richardson. The Church moved again, this time to the Hugh Sanford property, in 1966 and became the First United Methodist Church when the Methodist Church and the United Evangelical Brethren merged in 1968.

row.title: Interior of the Tennessee Theater
row.abstract: The Tennessee Theater opened to the public on October 1, 1928. It featured such luxuries as brocade draperies, crystal chandeliers, carpeted draperies, and an ornate dome. This photograph was taken during a radio exhibit featured during the Theater's first month of operation.

row.title: Hotel Imperial
row.abstract: The Imperial Hotel was built on the corner of Gay and Clinch Streets in about 1894. It replaced several older businesses, including the Hotel Hattie. The Imperial burned down in 1916 and was replaced by the "completely fireproof" Farragut Hotel in 1919.

row.abstract: The woman shown in this picture is most likely John Whitaker's first wife, Mary Maverick Lloyd (1905-1976). Lloyd spent most of her life in the Chicago area, where she campaigned tirelessly for world government and citizenship. The identity of the child in the image is not known.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Knoxville City Hall
row.abstract: Knoxville's old City Hall was constructed in 1844 and originally housed the Tennessee School for the Deaf. It served as a makeshift hospital for both Union and Confederate troops during the Civil War but returned to its original purpose when the war ended. It became Knoxville's City Hall in 1924, and continued in this function until 1980. The structure is now listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Public Hall
row.abstract: Knoxville's original Public Hall, better known as the Market House, was built in 1816. During the Civil War, the Union used the Market House to store ammunition and business was conducted outside. A new Market House (shown) was built in 1897 and merchants offered a wide variety of items, including baked goods, fresh meats, and homegrown fruits and vegetables from permanent stalls and wagons parked outside. After being partially destroyed by fire, this structure was demolished to make way for the Market Street Mall in 1960.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Houses in Knoxville's Mill Street Section
row.abstract: View of houses in Knoxville's Mill Street section, located a mere two blocks away from Gay Street. According to Welles, this section is home to "poor whites of unassorted varieties of occupations." Although conditions had improved in previous years, the district was still characterized by poverty, filth, and squalor in 1919.

row.title: Bijou Theater
row.abstract: The Lamar House Hotel was built in 1817. The Bijou Theatre opened as part of that hotel on March 8, 1909. Over the years, it hosted many famous vaudeville and theater acts. By 2005, however, the Theater was deteriorating and its owners defaulted on their mortgage. Knoxvillians, including Mayor Bill Haslam, banded together to save the Theater and fundraising and renovation efforts are ongoing.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Norma Shearer and Clark Gable in "A Free Soul"
row.abstract: In "A Free Soul," alcoholic lawyer Stephen Ashe (Lionel Barrymore) takes on the case of dashing gangster Ace Wilfong (Clark Gable). Ashe's daughter Jan (Norma Shearer) soon falls in love with Wilfong, and the pair run away to New York. Concerned for his daughter's safety, Ashe seeks her out and strikes a bargain%3A he'll stop drinking if she'll leave Wilfong. Both renig, however, and Jan returns to Wilfong. He has become brutal, however, and tries to molest her. She is saved by her ex-fiance, Dwight Winthrop (Leslie Howard), who murders Wilfong and is arrested. Jan begs her father to defend Winthrop, and Ashe confesses to the murder himself so that Jan and Winthrop can stay together. This confession leads to his own death at the hands of Wilfong's vengeful gang. "A Free Soul" was remade as "The Girl Who Has Everything" with Elizabeth Taylor in 1953.

row.title: Barge on Pickwick Lake
row.abstract: Pickwick Lake, which boasts about 490 miles of shoreline and 43,100 acres of water surface, began to fill in 1938 after the construction of Pickwick Landing Dam. Although the dam is located in Tennessee, much of the lake extends into northern Alabama where it covers a large portion of Muscle Shoals and so makes the Tennessee River much easier to navigate.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Jean Harlow, Clark Gable, and Myrna Loy in "Wife vs. Secretary"
row.abstract: "Wife vs. Secretary" tells the story of Van Stanhope (Clark Gable), an industrious magazine publisher who is happily married to Linda (Myrna Loy). Although his secretary, Helen "Whitey" Wilson (Jean Harlow), is in love with him, she respects his marriage and takes pains to ensure that their relationship remains strictly professional. Linda is suspicious, however, especially since her mother (May Robson) frequently suggests that Van is being unfaithful. These suspicions are apparently confirmed when Van takes Whitey on an important business trip to Cuba. Linda is infuriated, but Whitey manages to convince her that her husband has never betrayed her, thus saving their marriage.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Swan's Bread Company
row.abstract: Brothers Charles and George Swan founded Swan Brothers Bakery in 1883. They were originally located on Central Street and operated a stall in Knoxville's Market House. The company acquired what became their main facility on the 1800 block of Magnolia Avenue (shown) in 1928, where they continued to operate until being acquired by the American Bread Company in 1989. The bakery finally closed in 1991 and the buildings were auctioned in 1992.
row.name: unknown | Role: Creator | Role URI: http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Paddy-Carr, a Creek Interpreter
row.abstract: As his name implies, Paddy Carr was the son of an Irish father and a Creek mother. He was born near Fort Mitchell, Alabama, and reared in the family of Indian Agent Colonel Crowell. It was in this household that he learned to speak the Creek language. Carr served as an interpreter in the 1826 Creek delegation sent to Washington to argue against the Treaty of Indian Springs, where he gained a reputation as a brilliant translator. He established himself as a trader after his return from Washington and soon amassed considerable property. He later served as a guide and interpreter for the US Army in Alabama and Florida during the Creek War. This print was taken from a portrait painted by Charles Bird King in 1826. The original has since been destroyed by fire.
row.name: King, Charles Bird, 1785-1862 | URI: http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n88156294 | Role: Creator | Role URI: http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Chilhowee Park (near Machinery and Liberal Arts Building)
row.abstract: The Machinery and Liberal Arts Building was constructed in Chilhowee Park as part of the 1913 National Conservation Exposition. Although this event dealt only with local issues, it was an ambitious attempt to educate citizens and businessmen about the importance of conserving natural resources. The Exposition was sponsored by President Theodore Roosevelt and continued previous efforts in the field.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Still from "Don't Marry for Money"
row.abstract: Still from "Don't Marry for Money" (1924). In the movie, Marion (Rubye De Remer) marries millionaire Peter Smith (House Peters Sr.) soon after becoming a modestite on New York's fashionable 5th Avenue. He, however, is not romantic enough to satisfy her, and she soon takes up with playboy Crane Martin (Cyril Chadwick) who has made a business of seducing and robbing disaffected housewives. Smith, however, orchestrates a situation forcing Martin to expose himself, and Marion returns to her husband.

row.title: Appalachian Exposition Administration Building
row.abstract: The 1910 Appalachian Exposition was held from September 12 to October 12 in Knoxville's Chilhowee Park. The first of its kind in Appalachia, the Fair was intended to demonstrate Southern progress in industry and commerce and to advocate the preservation of the area's natural resources. The fair did not, however, achieve its broader goal%3A to turn Knoxville into a model New South city.

row.title: John T. Whitaker and Unidentified Man
row.abstract: John Thompson Whitaker was born on January 25, 1906. He earned his A.B. from the University of the South in 1927 and went on to write for the Chattanooga News and the New York Herald Tribune. He eventually became a foreign correspondent and covered the Ethiopian and Spanish Civil Wars before being stationed in Europe during World War II. He wrote three books%3A And Fear Came (1936), Americas to the South (1939), and We Cannot Escape History (1943). He died on September 11, 1946.

row.title: Albert Guinn Hope House (Hopecote)
row.abstract: John Fanz Staub designed this home at 1820 Melrose Avenue for his aunt, Emma Fanz Price Hope, in 1921. Completed in 1924, the home reflects Mrs. Hope's fondness for the cottage architecture of England's Cotswold District. The University of Tennessee purchased the home in 1980, and Staub oversaw its renovation just before his death in 1981. The building now houses the University's distinguished visitors.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Clarence and Catherine (Gaw) Brown
row.abstract: Clarence Brown was born on May 10, 1890, in Clinton, Massachusetts. He moved with his family to Knoxville, Tennessee as a child and graduated from Knoxville High School in 1905. Brown received a double degree in mechanical and electrical engineering from the University of Tennessee in 1910 and then began a career selling automobiles in Alabama. Fascinated with movies, he moved to New Jersey where he studied with French director Maurice Tourneur at Peerless Studios. There, the pair directed The Last of the Mohicans (1920). Brown directed or produced more than fifty widely-acclaimed full length motion pictures and worked with many of the most famous performers in the film industry, including Joan Crawford and Clark Gable in Chained (1934), Spencer Tracy in Edison the Man (1940), Elizabeth Taylor in National Velvet (1945), and Gregory Peck in The Yearling (1947). At the time of his retirement in 1952, Brown had received six Academy Award nominations for Best Director and won eight Oscars for his films. When he died in 1987, Brown left $12 million to the University of Tennessee. When added to the $1 million donated during his lifetime, the sum made him the largest donor in the university's history.

row.title: Tate Springs Hotel
row.abstract: Captain Thomas Tomlinson built the Tate Springs Hotel in the late 1800s near one of the mineral springs flowing from Clinch Mountain in Grainger County. The resort, which featured cottages, stables, a golf course, and a park, was extremely prosperous until the Great Depression. The original structure was torn down in 1936 and the property was sold to Kingswood School in 1941. Today, the only remnant of the hotel is a gazebo standing near the mineral spring.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Clarence Brown and Two Unidentified Men with Plane
row.abstract: In 1926, razor baron King Camp Gillette commissioned Wallace Neff to build him a "paradise on earth" in Southern California. The result was a stunning 25 room mansion built in the Spanish Colonial Revival Style whose beauty supposedly brought Gillette to tears. Gillette died in 1932, and his widow sold the property to prominent film director Clarence Brown in 1935. Brown regularly hosted large parties for well-known Hollywood personalities here, and made several changes to the property including the addition of a projection room and a small airport. He sold the property to the Claretian Order of the Catholic Church in 1952, which used it as a seminary and noviate. The Claretians subsequently sold to Elizabeth Clair Prophet's Church Universal and Triumphant in 1977, which in turn sold to the Soka University of American in 1986. In 2007, Soka sold the property to the National Park Service, which intends to restore and preserve it.

row.title: Appalachian Exposition Administration Building
row.abstract: The 1910 Appalachian Exposition was held from September 12 to October 12 in Knoxville's Chilhowee Park. The first of its kind in Appalachia, the Fair was intended to demonstrate Southern progress in industry and commerce and to advocate the preservation of the area's natural resources. The fair did not, however, achieve its broader goal: to turn Knoxville into a model New South city.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Wallace McClure Residence
row.abstract: Wallace K. McClure purchased this home on Temple Avenue (now Volunteer Boulevard) from Henry H. Ingersoll in 1902. He and his family lived in the house until his death in 1921. In 1941, Wallace McClure Jr. donated the house to the University of Tennessee as part of the W.K. McClure Foundation for the Study of World Affairs that he had founded as a memorial for his father. The house was demolished in the 1960s.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Clarence Brown Directing "Possessed"
row.abstract: "Possessed" is the story of Marian Martin (Joan Crawford), a factory girl who moves to Manhattan looking for excitement and hoping to trade her life on the assembly line for one more posh. When she meets lawyer Mark Whitney (Clark Gable), she thinks her dreams have come true%3A he is rich and handsome and can buy her the life she dreams of. Unfortunately, he is already married and his political ambitions would be destroyed by a divorce scandal. Thus, Martin becomes his mistress and poses as his ex-wife. When her small town ex-boyfriend Al Manning (Wallace Ford) asks her to marry him, she turns him down and he exposes Whitney's sordid private life. Martin is forced to defend her relationship with Whitney at an election rally, and her story moves the crowd to tears. Relieved, Whitney proposes to Martin, thus fulfilling her ambitions.

row.title: Corner of Melrose Street and Cumberland Avenue
row.abstract: View of the intersection of Melrose Avenue and Cumberland Avenue, showing the entrance to a residential neighborhood and a set of electric streetcar tracks. Melrose Park was originally an upscale Knoxville residential neighborhood. The University of Tennessee acquired the area in the 1960s and began destroying its Victorian-era homes to allow for University expansion in the late 1970s. Although several homes were adapted to house University programs, few traces of the area's original character remain today.

row.title: William Blount Mansion
row.abstract: William Blount (who signed the US Constitution and served as the Governor of the Territory of the United States South of the Ohio River) and his wife Mary commissioned this home in 1792. In addition to its size, the home boasted a number of features not commonly seen on the frontier, including hardwood floors and glass windows. A group of women led by Mary Boyce Temple led a campaign to preserve Blount Mansion in the early 1920s, and the house became a museum in 1925.

row.title: Island Park in Bluff City, Tennessee
row.abstract: Bluff City, located on the Holston River between Bristol and Johnson City, was originally known as Choate's (also spelled Shoate's) Ford for Edward Choate, one of its first white settlers. It was often used as a river crossing, as it lay on several popular overland routes. The town's name was changed to Middletown in 1793 and again to Union Depot (later shortened to Depot) in 1859 when the East Tennessee and Virginia Railroad came through. The town was known as Zollicoffer (for the Confederate general of that name) during the Civil War, but reverted to Union at the War's end. It was finally named Bluff City in 1887.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Reinternment of Catherine Sevier
row.abstract: In the early 1920s, the Honorable S.G. Heiskell hit upon the idea of reinterring Catherine Sevier (wife of former governor John Sevier) in Knoxville. This photograph, probably taken at the site of Sevier's original burial in Russellville, Alabama, shows the Knoxville delegation dispatched to retrieve her remains. Upon their return, Sevier lay in state at the Women's Building and was reinterred with great fanfare on July 27, 1922. Former governor John Sevier's remains had been reinterred in Knoxville in 1889.

row.title: Perez Dickinson's Home
row.abstract: Perez Dickinson was born in Amherst, Massachusetts in 1813. He moved to Knoxville in about 1830, where he quickly became an extremely popular and successful merchant. He had this elegant home at the corner of Main and Locust Streets built in 1831. After his death in 1901, C.B. Atkin bought the house and made several additions, including a front portico in the classic colonial style. The structure was demolished in about 1950.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Joan Crawford in "Sadie McKee"
row.abstract: Sadie McKee (Joan Crawford) is a cook's daughter and works a maid for the wealthy Alderson family. Although she flirts with her employer, Mike Alderson (Franchot Tone), she loves her humble boyfriend Tommy Wallace (Gene Raymond). The couple runs away to New York to get married, but before the ceremony Wallace meets a showgirl and deserts McKee. She decides to stay in the city, and gets a job in a nightclub owned by alcoholic millionaire Jack Brennan (Edward Arnold). Brennan is smitten with McKee, who eventually gives up on finding true love and marries Brennan for his money. She is unhappy, however, and leaves him when she finds out that Wallace is in trouble. With Alderson's help, she eventually discovers that he is extremely ill in a hospital. She goes to visit him, and he pair confess their love for each other shortly before Wallace dies.

row.title: Young Men's Christian Association (YMCA)
row.abstract: Knoxville's first YMCA was organized in 1854 at the Second Presbyterian Church. The organization moved to this structure, standing on the corner of Commerce and State, in 1900. They continued to meet here until 1929, when they moved to a newer edifice on the corner of Locust and Clinch.

row.title: Mary Cora de Garmo
row.abstract: Portrait of Mary Cora de Garmo made in St. Louis, Missouri, in 1913. Born on August 28, 1891, Mary was the first child of Frank and Mary Eloise (Donnell) de Garmo. She earned her A.B. (1912) and M.A. (1913) degrees at Washington College and eventually obtained a Ph.D from Cornell University (1931). She married Charles W. Bryan Jr., a prominent civil engineer, on June 9, 1920. During her career as a nutritionist, she taught at several educational institutions, edited the "Journal of Home Economics," wrote four books, helped to develop the national school lunch program, and served in a variety of professional organizations. She died in Illinois on May 12, 1986.

row.title: View on World's Fair Grounds (Looking toward the Sunsphere)
row.abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Henley Street Bridge
row.abstract: The Henley Street Bridge was built at a cost of $1 million between 1930 and 1932. After the Fort Loudon Dam was completed and its reservoir filled in 1943, the water level in the Tennessee River rose by several feet and so changed the appearance of the bridge. This image shows several of the shoals characteristic of the lower water level.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: John Sevier's "Marble Springs Plantation"
row.abstract: John Sevier was born in 1745 in Virginia. He fought in the Revolutionary War (most notably at the Battle of Kings Mountain) and was later involved in the short-lived State of Franklin and the campaign for Tennessee statehood. When Sevier became Tennessee's first governor in 1796, he settled in South Knox County. Here, he constructed "Marble Springs Plantation," which consisted of a main building (shown) and several smaller outbuildings. Sevier died in Alabama in 1815 and was removed to the Knox County Courthouse lawn in 1889. His wives, Sarah Hawkins and Catherine "Bonny Kate" Sherrill, are buried nearby.

row.title: Church Street Methodist Episcopal Church, South
row.abstract: When the Church Street Methodist Episcopal Church South building (constructed in 1875) was destroyed by fire in 1928, the structure shown replaced it. Although the new building stood at the corner of Henley and Main Streets, the congregation chose to retain "Church Street" in its name. The church's name was changed to Church Street United Methodist Church when the nationwide United Methodist Church was formed in 1968, and this structure continues to operate as a Methodist Church today.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Gillette Ranch Hallway
row.abstract: In 1926, Razor baron King Camp Gillette commissioned Wallace Neff to build him a "paradise on earth" in Southern California. The result was a stunning 25 room mansion built in the Spanish Colonial Revival Style whose beauty supposedly brought Gillette to tears. Gillette died in 1932, and his widow sold the property to prominent film director Clarence Brown in 1935. Brown regularly hosted large parties for well-known Hollywood personalities here, and made several changes to the property, including the addition of a projection room and a small airport. He sold the property to the Claretian Order of the Catholic Church in 1952, which used it as a seminary and noviate. The Claretians subsequently sold to Elizabeth Clair Prophet's Church Universal and Triumphant in 1977, which in turn sold to the Soka University of American in 1986. In 2007, Soka sold the property to the National Park Service, which intends to restore and preserve it.

row.title: David Bryan and Juano Hernandez in "Intruder in the Dust"
row.abstract: David Bryan and Juano Hernandez in "Intruder in the Dust." The movie is set in rural Mississippi during the 1940s and features Juano Hernandez as Lucas Beauchamp, a black man with a reputation for standing up to whites. When Beauchamp is found standing over a white man's dead body, he is immediately jailed. He insists that he is innocent and asks the town's most prominent lawyer, Gavin Stevens (David Brian), to defend him, but Stevens refuses. The situation changes, however, when a local boy named Chick Mallison (Claude Jarman Jr.) who Beauchamp has helped in the past hears talk of an impending lynching and begs Stevens to change his mind.

row.title: John T. Whitaker and Hubert R. Knickerbocker
row.abstract: John Thompson Whitaker was born on January 25, 1906. He earned his A.B. from the University of the South in 1927 and went on to write for the Chattanooga News and the New York Herald Tribune. He eventually became a foreign correspondent and covered the Ethiopian and Spanish Civil Wars before being stationed in Europe during World War II. He wrote three books%3A And Fear Came (1936), Americas to the South (1939), and We Cannot Escape History (1943). He died on September 11, 1946. The man seen with him in this picture is likely fellow reporter Hubert Renfro Knickerbocker.

row.title: Church Street Methodist Episcopal Church, South
row.abstract: This building is the second of the two Southern Methodist Episcopal Churches that stood on Church Street between 1836 and 1928. It was built in 1875 and burned down in 1928. After the fire, the congregation elected to build a new structure on the corner of Henley and Main Streets, which continues to operate today.

row.title: Clarence and Alice (Joyce) Brown
row.abstract: Alice Joyce was born on October 1, 1890 in Kansas City, Missouri. She worked as a telephone operator and as a fashion model before entering film in 1910. She went on earn the nickname "The Madonna of the Screen" and to make a number of silent films, including "Whom the Gods Destroy" (1916), "Within the Law" (1917), "Stella Dallas" (1925), and "So's Your Old Man" (1926). Joyce retired in 1930 with the advent of "talkies." She was married three times: first to Tom Moore (from 1914 to 1920), second to James Regan (from 1920 to 1932), and finally to Clarence Brown (from 1933 to 1945). Alice Joyce Brown died of heart disease on October 9, 1955 and was buried in the San Fernando Mission Cemetery.

row.title: Knox County Court House
row.abstract: The first Knox County Court House was designed by architect Drury P. Armstrong and constructed in 1842. It was replaced by a more modern building, built in the Queen Anne style, in 1885. Now called the old Knoxville Courthouse, this structure stands on approximately the site of the Federal barracks of James White's Fort. New wings were added to either side of the courthouse in 1919. Two of the monuments on the courthouse's grounds are visible in this image%3A the obelisk commemorates Tennessee's first governor John Sevier, while the marble archway honors Confederate surgeon John Mason Boyd.

row.title: Clarence Brown on the Set of "The Signal Tower"
row.abstract: "The Signal Tower" was one of the earliest movies that Clarence Brown directed. It tells the story of a railroad signal man named David Tolliver (Rockcliffe Fellowes), his wife Sally (Virginia Vallie), and their child Sonny (Frankie Darrow). The family lives near the signal tower where Tolliver works. When the relief signal man retires, his replacement Joe Standish (Wallace Beery) boards with the Tollivers. Standish is evicted after attempting to seduce Sally and arrives at work drunk and late the following night. As a result, Tolliver works an extra shift and Standish attempts to force himself on Sally while he is distracted. Sonny runs to his father for help, but Tolliver is busy preventing a freight train that has broken in half from colliding with the oncoming Limited. Sally takes matters into her own hands, and aims what she believes to be an unloaded gun at Standish. It discharges, however, hitting Standish and so dissuading him. Thus, both the train and Sally's honor are preserved.

row.title: Portrait of Camp Chapman Forestry Personnel
row.abstract: Camp David C. Chapman (CCC Company 1460) was established in Sevierville on June 2, 1933. Its members worked on projects (including building bridges and fire towers) in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park. This image most likely shows the camp's Forestry personnel, including L.W. Frierson, T.J.M. Scott, W.W. Blalock, Joe Davis, Clyde Davenport, W.P. Trotter, E.L. Rawlings, and Jesse Buchanan.

row.title: Burwell Building
row.abstract: The Knoxville Banking and Trust Building was completed in 1907 on the site of the original Blount College. It was Knoxville's tallest building until 1912, when it was surpassed by the Holston. C.B. Atkin later purchased the structure, which he enlarged and renamed the Burwell Building in honor of his wife, Mary Burwell. The structure became famous in 1928, when the Tennessee Theater was added as part of an addition standing at 604-606 Gay Street. It was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1982.
