row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Clarence Brown in Childhood
row.abstract: Clarence Brown was born on May 10, 1890, in Clinton, Massachusetts. He moved with his family to Knoxville, Tennessee as a child and graduated from Knoxville High School in 1905. Brown received a double degree in mechanical and electrical engineering from the University of Tennessee in 1910 and then began a career selling automobiles in Alabama. Fascinated with movies, he moved to New Jersey where he studied with French director Maurice Tourneur at Peerless Studios. There, the pair directed "The Last of the Mohicans" (1920). Brown directed or produced more than fifty widely-acclaimed full length motion pictures and worked with many of the most famous performers in the film industry, including Joan Crawford and Clark Gable in "Chained" (1934), Spencer Tracy in "Edison the Man" (1940), Elizabeth Taylor in "National Velvet" (1945), and Gregory Peck in "The Yearling" (1947). At the time of his retirement in 1952, Brown had received six Academy Award nominations for Best Director and won eight Oscars for his films. When he died in 1987, Brown left $12 million to the University of Tennessee. When added to the $1 million donated during his lifetime, the sum made him the largest donor in the university's history.

row.title: Colonel James Van Deventer's Home
row.abstract: Colonel James Van Deventer and his family lived in this home on Temple Avenue (now called Volunteer Boulevard) from approximately 1900 until 1908. The University of Tennessee later used the structure as its Faculty Club, and the building was finally razed in the 1980s to allow for the construction of Hodges Library.

row.title: East Tennessee Female Institute
row.abstract: The East Tennessee Female Institute was founded in 1828. The academy offered such courses as arithmetic, orthography, reading, music, penmanship, astronomy, chemistry, and latin. The institute was merged with the Knoxville public school system in 1882, and this building was demolished in 1889.

row.title: Knoxville Academy of Medicine
row.abstract: Built in 1812, this structure originally served as prominent Knoxvillian James Parks' private residence. The Knoxville Academy of Medicine purchased the building in 1949 and added a large addition (not shown) in 1968. The building is now listed on the National Register of Historic Places and further restoration is planned.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Clarence Brown Directing "A Woman of Affairs"
row.abstract: "A Woman of Affairs" stars Greta Garbo as Diana Merrick, a worldly socialite who has loved Neville 'Nevs' Holderness (John Gilbert) since both were children. Nevs' father disapproves, and sends Nevs to Egypt to work after convincing him not to marry Diana. Two years later, Diana marries another childhood friend, David Furness (Johnny Mack Brown), who later commits suicide in Paris. As a result of the tragedy, Diana is cast out of upper-class English society and embarks on a string of meaningless affairs with men around the world. She eventually returns to England days before Nevs' wedding to Constance (Dorothy Sebastian).
row.name: unknown | Role: Creator | Role URI: http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Clarence Brown "Directing Intruder in the Dust"
row.abstract: Clarence Brown directing "Intruder in the Dust." The movie is set in rural Mississippi during the 1940s and features Juano Hernandez as Lucas Beauchamp, a black man with a reputation for standing up to whites. When Beauchamp is found standing over a white man's dead body, he is immediately jailed. He insists that he is innocent and asks the town's most prominent lawyer, Gavin Stevens (David Brian), to defend him, but Stevens refuses. The situation changes, however, when a local boy named Chick Mallison (Claude Jarman Jr.) who Beauchamp has helped in the past hears talk of an impending lynching and begs Stevens to change his mind.

row.title: Southern Railway Station
row.abstract: This Southern Railway Station was built in Knoxville in 1904. It prospered until passenger traffic began to decline in the 1960s due to competition from airplanes and automobiles. The last passenger train to pass through the station was the "Birmingham Special," which departed on August 12, 1970. The station was renovated in the early 1990s for use by Knoxville architectural firm Bullock, Smith, and Partners, Inc.

row.collection: University of Tennessee Photograph and Slide Collection
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Font of Strong Hall
row.abstract: Sophronia Strong Hall (known colloquially as "Sophie's") was built in 1925 when the University found itself in need of a larger women's dormitory. Benjamin Rush Strong (1848-1915) had left the University $30,000 in his will for the purpose on the condition that the resulting building be named after his mother, Sophronia (Marrs) Strong, and that a wildflower garden be planted every spring in her memory. Several wings were added in the 1950s, each named after one of the first co-eds to attend the University. Sophronia Strong's ghost was said to watch over the Hall's residents, appearing as a lady dressed in white on her birthday (February 17) and perpetrating various harmless pranks. The last residents of the hall moved out after the 2008 Spring Semester and the building was put to other uses.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Flags Outside the Chinese Pavilion
row.abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

row.title: Port of Knoxville Public Terminal
row.abstract: River traffic has flowed through East Tennessee since the area was settled in the late 18th century. From 1930 to 1933, the TVA made a number of improvements to the river that allowed for a significant increase in the quantity of Knoxville's river trade. The TVA operated Knoxville's Public Terminal (located on Neyland Drive) from 1944 to 1952, when it was leased to private interests. In 1962, the terminal was sold and became a for-hire facility.

row.title: Clarence Brown Directing "Anna Karenina"
row.abstract: "Anna Karenina" stars Greta Garbo as the sheltered wife of Czarist official Karenin (Basil Rathbone). She is not happy in her marriage, however, and soon falls in love with Count Vronsky (Frederic March). When this affair is discovered, Anna Karenina is cast out of upper-class Russian society and is even prohibited from seeing her son, Sergei (Freddie Bartholomew), whose father tells him that his mother is dead. Anna Karenina follows Vronsky to Venice and later to St. Petersburg, where he deserts her to fight in the Turkish-Serbian War. She is finally driven to suicide, and throws herself under a train.

row.title: Clarence Brown at Pump Station
row.abstract: In 1926, razor baron King Camp Gillette commissioned Wallace Neff to build him a "paradise on earth" in Southern California. The result was a stunning 25 room mansion built in the Spanish Colonial Revival Style whose beauty supposedly brought Gillette to tears. Gillette died in 1932, and his widow sold the property to prominent film director Clarence Brown in 1935. Brown regularly hosted large parties for well-known Hollywood personalities here, and made several changes to the property including the addition of a projection room and a small airport. He sold the property to the Claretian Order of the Catholic Church in 1952, which used it as a seminary and noviate. The Claretians subsequently sold to Elizabeth Clair Prophet's Church Universal and Triumphant in 1977, which in turn sold to the Soka University of American in 1986. In 2007, Soka sold the property to the National Park Service, which intends to restore and preserve it.

row.title: Louisville & Nashville Railroad Yards and Terminals
row.abstract: View of the Louisville & Nashville Railroad yards and terminals. The Commonwealth of Kentucky granted the L&N a charter on March 5, 1850 and the Tennessee State Legislature authorized the railroad's extension to Nashville on December 4, 1851. The railroad began expanding after the Civil War and eventually reached such cities as Knoxville (Tennessee), Montgomery (Alabama), Norton (Virginia), and New Orleans (Louisiana). By the time the Seabord Coastline Railroad bought the L&N in 1971, it operated 6,574 miles of track in 13 states.

row.title: St. James Hotel
row.abstract: Originally known as the Van Deventer building, the St. James Hotel was built shortly after the "Million Dollar Fire" of 1897. During the 1920s, the hotel developed a reputation as a musical center%3A WNOX (earlier WNAV) was located at the St. James by 1923, and the Brunswick/Vocalion label set up temporary quarters in the building in 1929. A number of artists, many of whom went on to achieve national and international recognition, made recordings here during the "St. James Sessions" of 1929-1930. The hotel was demolished in 1973.

row.title: Map of Knoxville, Tennessee
row.abstract: This map, which features illustrations of many prominent Knoxville structures, was printed in 1886 in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. It shows much of downtown Knoxville, including East Tennessee University, the Gay Street Bridge, the Knoxville & Augusta Railroad Bridge, and numerous churches, parks, and theaters. A larger version of this image is available at the University of Tennessee Special Collections Library.

row.title: Rudolph Valentino, Clarence Brown, and Arabella Brown on the Set of "The Eagle"
row.abstract: Based on a Pushkin novel, "The Eagle" stars Rudolph Valentino as a Russian cossack named Vladimir Dubrouvsky. He is one of Catherine the Great's particular favorites, but he will not be kept as a lover and spurns her advances. When Kyrilla Troekouroff steals his lands, he creates a secret identity, "The Black Eagle," and becomes a masked avenger. Although bent on revenge, he falls in love with Troekouroff's daughter, Mascha (Vilma Banky). Mascha, in turn, worships the Eagle but disdains his unmasked identity, her foppish French tutor Monsieur Le Blanc. Dubrouvsky's love for Masha eventually counteracts his desire for revenge against her father, and the couple flee Troekouroff's estate. Although captured by the Czarina's men, Catherine rescinds her orders to execute the Eagle and the pair escape to Paris.

row.title: Appalachian Exposition Main Building
row.abstract: The 1910 Appalachian Exposition was held from September 12 to October 12 in Knoxville's Chilhowee Park. The first of its kind in Appalachia, the Fair was intended to demonstrate Southern progress in industry and commerce and to advocate the preservation of the area's natural resources. The fair did not, however, achieve its broader goal: to turn Knoxville into a model New South city.

row.title: Motor Section Training
row.abstract: The original caption for this image reads "Motor squad and gun. Camp Barkley, Texas April-1941. Co. K. 158th Inf. 45th Div." The 158th Infantry Regiment began as the First Arizona Volunteer Infantry on September 2, 1865. It was drafted into Federal service during World War I as part of the 40th Division and reassigned to the 45th Division during postwar reorganizations. When a National Emergency was declared on September 16, 1940, the 158th joined the 45th for training at Fort Sill, Oklahoma and Fort Barkley, Texas. They were detached from the 45th in December of 1941 and sent to the Canal Zone for training in jungle warfare before being assigned to the Pacific Theater in early 1943. The unit was scheduled to spearhead the final invasion of Japan, which was subsequently rendered unnecessary by the atomic bomb. The 158th was deactivated and sent home in January of 1946.

row.abstract: Clarence Brown's second wife, Ona (often spelled "Mona") Maris, was born in Buenos Aires, Argentina in 1903. row.title: Clarence Brown Directing "Inspiration"
row.abstract: In "Inspiration," Andre Martel (Robert Montgomery), a diplomat studying for the consular service, falls in love with Yvonne Valbret (Greta Garbo), an artist's model. The two become lovers, but Martel leaves when he learns of Valbret's sordid past. He later finds her poverty-stricken and buys her a country home out of pity. He also tells Valbret that he is going to marry another woman, and she pleads with him to marry her instead. Remembering his friend Liane Latour (Karen Morley), who killed herself when her lover Raymond Delval (Lewis Stone) left her, Martel goes to Valbret to rekindle their relationship. When he arrives, he finds another of Valbret's lovers begging her to return to him. Martel agrees to overlook this indiscretion, but Valbret, determined not to destroy him, writes him a farewell note and leaves while he is asleep.

row.title: Gay Street (800 Block)
row.abstract: View on Gay Street, long one of Knoxville's major thoroughfares. Visible businesses include the Bijou Theatre, Loew's Store, and the Colonial Hotel. One can also see the tracks for the electric streetcars that ran in Knoxville during the early 20th century and one of the towers that policemen used to control traffic during the 1920s.

row.title: Irene Dunne and Alan Marshal in "The White Cliffs of Dover"
row.abstract: "The White Cliffs of Dover" begins with Susan Dunn (Irene Dunne) and her father, Hiram Porter Dunn (Frank Morgan), vacationing in England during World War I. Here, Susan meets and marries wealthy British aristocrat Sir John Ashwood (Alan Marshal). Sadly, Ashwood is killed on the battlefield, and Susan is left to raise their son, John Ashwood II (Roddy McDowall and Peter Lawford) alone. During World War II, the younger John Ashwood serves with the British army while Susan Ashwood works for the Red Cross. He is wounded in battle, and she is devastated to find her own son among the wounded soldiers that she cares for. She is unable to save his life, but consoles herself with the knowledge that both her husband and her son died for a noble cause.

row.title: Interior of the Regas Restaurant
row.abstract: Greek immigrants George and Frank Regas started the Regas Brothers Cafe (originally known as the Astor Cafe) on Gay Street in 1919. The restaurant stayed open 24 hours a day, except for Christmas Eve and part of Christmas Day. The Regas family continues to operate the eatery, now called Regas Restaurant, today.

row.title: Flag Outside the United States Pavilion
row.abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

row.title: Dining Room in the Blount Mansion
row.abstract: William Blount (who signed the US Constitution and served as the Governor of the Territory of the United States South of the Ohio River) and his wife Mary commissioned this home in 1792. In addition to its size, the home boasted a number of features not commonly seen on the frontier, including hardwood floors and glass windows. A group of women led by Mary Boyce Temple led a campaign to preserve Blount Mansion in the early 1920s, and the house became a museum in 1925.

row.title: Henson Hall
row.abstract: When Mrs. Martha C. Henson died in 1927, she left the University of Tennessee $200,000 to be used for the betterment of the school's female students. The money was used to build a women's dormitory, which opened in 1930 and was named Henson Hall in her honor. The building housed Air Cadet Training Program students from 1943 until June of 1944, but returned to housing women as soon as the program ended. It became an academic building in the late 1970s, and continues to serve in this capacity today.

row.title: Mary Olivia Rawls (Mills) Hoskins
row.abstract: Mary Olivia Rawls was born to William and Susan (Dickason) Rawls on a plantation near Commerce Landing, Mississippi on January 8, 1842. Her parents died shortly after she was born, and she was adopted by Captain John Mills and his wife. The family moved to East Tennessee, where Mary Mills attended Dr. Park's seminary in Rogersville and graduated from the East Tennessee Female Institute. She married William Patton Hoskins (1838-1902) on September 26, 1860, and the couple had seven children: Leila Susan, Nellie Temple, James Dickason, Lynn Wood, Horace Mills, Bessie Olivia, and Mary Margaret. Mary Rawls Mills Hoskins died in 1917 in Knoxville, Tennessee.

row.title: Students in Front of Strong Hall
row.abstract: Sophronia Strong Hall (known colloquially as "Sophie's") was built in 1925 when the University found itself in need of a larger women's dormitory. Benjamin Rush Strong (1848-1915) had left the University $30,000 in his will for the purpose on the condition that the resulting building be named after his mother, Sophronia (Marrs) Strong, and that a wildflower garden be planted every spring in her memory. Several wings were added in the 1950s, each named after one of the first co-eds to attend the University. Sophronia Strong's ghost was said to watch over the Hall's residents, appearing as a lady dressed in white on her birthday (February 17) and perpetrating various harmless pranks. The last residents of the hall moved out after the 2008 Spring Semester and the building was put to other uses.

row.title: Portrait of John T. Whitaker
row.abstract: John Thompson Whitaker was born on January 25, 1906. He earned his A.B. from the University of the South in 1927 and went on to write for the Chattanooga News and the New York Herald Tribune. He eventually became a foreign correspondent and covered the Ethiopian and Spanish Civil Wars before being stationed in Europe during World War II. He wrote three books%3A And Fear Came (1936), Americas to the South (1939), and We Cannot Escape History (1943). He died on September 11, 1946.

row.title: Crowds on the International Court of Flags
row.abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

row.title: View of the Cherokee Country Club and the Horseshoe Bend
row.abstract: The Cherokee Country Club's original clubhouse (shown here) was constructed in 1907. This structure was demolished in 1928 to make way for a more elaborate clubhouse designed by Knoxville architects Baumann and Baumann. The Tennessee River's Horseshoe Bend (today a National Military Park commemorating the Battle of Horseshoe Bend fought there on March 27, 1814) is shown as it appears from the clubhouse.

row.title: John T. Whitaker and Unidentified General
row.abstract: John Thompson Whitaker was born on January 25, 1906. He earned his A.B. from the University of the South in 1927 and went on to write for the Chattanooga News and the New York Herald Tribune. He eventually became a foreign correspondent and covered the Ethiopian and Spanish Civil Wars before being stationed in Europe during World War II. He wrote three books%3A And Fear Came (1936), Americas to the South (1939), and We Cannot Escape History (1943). He died on September 11, 1946.

row.title: Knoxville Street Market
row.abstract: Knoxville street market, likely on Market Street near the Market House. Knoxville's original Market House was built in 1816. During the Civil War, the Union used the Market House to store ammunition and business was conducted outside. A new Market House was built in 1897 and merchants offered a wide variety of items, including baked goods, fresh meats, and homegrown fruits and vegetables from permanent stalls and wagons parked outside. After being partially destroyed by fire, this structure was demolished to make way for the Market Street Mall in 1960.

row.title: One of the Better Streets of the Dale Avenue District
row.abstract: Some of the nicer homes located in the Dale Avenue District. Welles places this area in the Northwest District, which she describes as "essentially a mill section, [as] many of its inhabitants depend ... for their living on the large mills." She finds the homes to be "poorly constructed in most instances" but does not find the living conditions as deplorable as they are in some of the other sections.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Clarence Brown in Childhood
row.abstract: Clarence Brown was born on May 10, 1890, in Clinton, Massachusetts. He moved with his family to Knoxville, Tennessee as a child and graduated from Knoxville High School in 1905. Brown received a double degree in mechanical and electrical engineering from the University of Tennessee in 1910 and then began a career selling automobiles in Alabama. Fascinated with movies, he moved to New Jersey where he studied with French director Maurice Tourneur at Peerless Studios. There, the pair directed "The Last of the Mohicans" (1920). Brown directed or produced more than fifty widely-acclaimed full length motion pictures and worked with many of the most famous performers in the film industry, including Joan Crawford and Clark Gable in "Chained" (1934), Spencer Tracy in "Edison the Man" (1940), Elizabeth Taylor in "National Velvet" (1945), and Gregory Peck in "The Yearling" (1947). At the time of his retirement in 1952, Brown had received six Academy Award nominations for Best Director and won eight Oscars for his films. When he died in 1987, Brown left $12 million to the University of Tennessee. When added to the $1 million donated during his lifetime, the sum made him the largest donor in the university's history.

row.title: Residence of Charles and Nellie Ross
row.abstract: This house, which stood on Rose Avenue in Knoxville, Tennessee, was home to Professor Charles C. Ross beginning in 1891. His sister Nellie lived with him from 1895 until she married James Milton Bailey in 1898. Another (currently unidentified) individual may also have occupied the house during this time. Charles Ross, Nellie Ross, and an illegible name are inscribed on the back of the picture.

row.title: Park City High School
row.abstract: Park City High School was built in 1907. For a brief time, it was the largest high school in Knoxville. It later became Park Lowry Grammar School and was closed in 1982. The building was sold to private contractors in the mid 1980s, but was completely razed after being badly damaged by fire in September of 1987.

row.title: Interior of the Appalachian Exposition's Main Building
row.abstract: The 1910 Appalachian Exposition was held from September 12 to October 12 in Knoxville's Chilhowee Park. The first of its kind in Appalachia, the Fair was intended to demonstrate Southern progress in industry and commerce and to advocate the preservation of the area's natural resources. The fair did not, however, achieve its broader goal%3A to turn Knoxville into a model New South city.

row.title: Church Street Methodist Episcopal Church, South
row.abstract: When the Church Street Methodist Episcopal Church South building (constructed in 1875) was destroyed by fire in 1928, the structure shown replaced it. Although the new building stood at the corner of Henley and Main Streets, the congregation chose to retain "Church Street" in its name. The church's name was changed to Church Street United Methodist Church when the nationwide United Methodist Church was formed in 1968, and this structure continues to operate as a Methodist Church today.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Brabson's Ferry
row.abstract: Brabson Island, site of Brabson's Ferry Plantation, sits in the French Broad River in Sevier County, Tennessee. Since this postcard was mailed in 1913, the notation "Brabson's Ferry near Knoxville, Tenn." most likely refers to the ferry that crosses the French Broad several miles upstream of Brabson Island rather than to the Plantation or to the island proper. Brabson's Ferry Plantation was added to the National Register of Historic Places on June 25, 1975.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Gillette Ranch Sitting Room
row.abstract: In 1926, Razor baron King Camp Gillette commissioned Wallace Neff to build him a "paradise on earth" in Southern California. The result was a stunning 25 room mansion built in the Spanish Colonial Revival Style whose beauty supposedly brought Gillette to tears. Gillette died in 1932, and his widow sold the property to prominent film director Clarence Brown in 1935. Brown regularly hosted large parties for well-known Hollywood personalities here, and made several changes to the property, including the addition of a projection room and a small airport. He sold the property to the Claretian Order of the Catholic Church in 1952, which used it as a seminary and noviate. The Claretians subsequently sold to Elizabeth Clair Prophet's Church Universal and Triumphant in 1977, which in turn sold to the Soka University of American in 1986. In 2007, Soka sold the property to the National Park Service, which intends to restore and preserve it.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Hotel Farragut
row.abstract: Named after Admiral David Glasgow Farragut, the Hotel Farragut opened on the corner of Gay and Clinch (the site of the old Imperial Hotel) on February 1, 1919. It flourished until 1929 when the Andrew Johnson Hotel opened nearby, after which time the two hotels provided each other with stiff competition. The Farragut closed in 1977 and was converted into office space in 1978.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.collection: University of Tennessee Photograph and Slide Collection
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Strong Hall
row.abstract: Sophronia Strong Hall (known colloquially as "Sophie's") was built in 1925 when the University found itself in need of a larger women's dormitory. Benjamin Rush Strong (1848-1915) had left the University $30,000 in his will for the purpose on the condition that the resulting building be named after his mother, Sophronia (Marrs) Strong, and that a wildflower garden be planted every spring in her memory. Several wings were added in the 1950s, each named after one of the first co-eds to attend the University. Sophronia Strong's ghost was said to watch over the Hall's residents, appearing as a lady dressed in white on her birthday (February 17) and perpetrating various harmless pranks. The last residents of the hall moved out after the 2008 Spring Semester and the building was put to other uses.

row.title: Lawson McGhee Library
row.abstract: In 1885, Charles McClung McGhee established the Lawson McGhee Library as a memorial to his daughter, May Lawson McGhee Williams. The original building on the corner of Gay and Vine was replaced by this white marble structure on the corner of Market and Commerce in 1917. It remained in use until 1971, when a new building was constructed.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Auditorium of the First Baptist Church
row.abstract: Brothers James and John Moses organized the congregation that would become Knoxville's First Baptist Church in 1843. The church's first permanent house of worship stood on Gay Street and was completed in 1850. The congregation split in 1869, and the dissidents formed Knoxville's Second Baptist Church. The First Baptist Church moved to their second home (made possible in large part by merchant and philanthropist W.W. Woodruff) in 1888. Their current house of worship, located at the corner of Walnut and Main Streets, was completed in 1924 and is still in use today. It was placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1997.

row.title: Hotel Andrew Johnson
row.abstract: The Andrew Johnson Hotel opened on Gay Street in 1929 and prospered throughout the Great Depression. Its numerous guests included Jean Paul Sarte, Duke Ellington, Amelia Erhart, Liberace, Tony Perkins, and Sergei Rachmaninoff. Knox County purchased the building in 1990, and is considering selling the property for a mix of residential and commercial uses as of June 2007. This particular postcard was mailed on October 13, 1934 from Chattanooga.

row.title: Deaderick Avenue Baptist Church
row.abstract: In early 1892, W.W. Woodruff offered his lot on Deaderick Street and his help raising funds to Knoxville's First Baptist Church in order to organize a new church. The product of these efforts was Centennial Baptist Church (renamed Deaderick Avenue Baptist Church in 1905), which was dedicated on September 13, 1892. The church was destroyed by fire in 1909, but was quickly rebuilt and continued to prosper for many years. Unfortunately, it no longer exists today.

row.title: Students in Strong Hall
row.abstract: Sophronia Strong Hall (known colloquially as "Sophie's") was built in 1925 when the University found itself in need of a larger women's dormitory. Benjamin Rush Strong (1848-1915) had left the University $30,000 in his will for the purpose on the condition that the resulting building be named after his mother, Sophronia (Marrs) Strong, and that a wildflower garden be planted every spring in her memory. Several wings were added in the 1950s, each named after one of the first co-eds to attend the University. Sophronia Strong's ghost was said to watch over the Hall's residents, appearing as a lady dressed in white on her birthday (February 17) and perpetrating various harmless pranks. The last residents of the hall moved out after the 2008 Spring Semester and the building was put to other uses.

row.title: Whittle Springs Hotel
row.abstract: The original Whittle Springs Hotel was built in about 1902 about three miles to the north of Knoxville. It advertised such conveniences as electric lights, baths, unexcelled cuisine, and both telephone and telegraph connections. This structure burned in 1919, and the second Whittle Springs Hotel (shown) was constructed on the same site. This building was razed in 1964.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Pond on Gillette Ranch
row.abstract: In 1926, razor baron King Camp Gillette commissioned Wallace Neff to build him a "paradise on earth" in Southern California. The result was a stunning 25 room mansion built in the Spanish Colonial Revival Style whose beauty supposedly brought Gillette to tears. Gillette died in 1932, and his widow sold the property to prominent film director Clarence Brown in 1935. Brown regularly hosted large parties for well-known Hollywood personalities here, and made several changes to the property including the addition of a projection room and a small airport. He sold the property to the Claretian Order of the Catholic Church in 1952, which used it as a seminary and noviate. The Claretians subsequently sold to Elizabeth Clair Prophet's Church Universal and Triumphant in 1977, which in turn sold to the Soka University of American in 1986. In 2007, Soka sold the property to the National Park Service, which intends to restore and preserve it.

row.title: Lake at Fountain City
row.abstract: The Knoxville suburb of Fountain City began as a center of religious camp meetings in the 1830s. After the Fountain Head Improvement Company built a three-story hotel in 1886 and the Fountain Head Railroad Company began carrying tourists to the area in 1890, however, it lost its original farming character and became a resort area.

row.title: Circle Park Neighborhood
row.abstract: The Circle Park neighborhood was home to many of Knoxville's richest and most prominent citizens during the early part of the 20th century. The area began to decline in the 1940s, and the University of Tennessee bought most of the neighborhood in the 1950s. Between 1960 and 1968, the University razed the original structures to make way for such buildings as the Andy Holt Tower and the McClung Museum, many of which are still in use.

row.title: Masonic Temple
row.abstract: Knoxville's Masonic Temple was originally Charles McClung McGhee's private home. The structure was designed by architect Joseph F. Baumann in 1872 and altered to serve as the Masonic Temple after McGhee's death in 1907. The interior of the home was restored in the early 1990s.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Goetz Sanitarium
row.abstract: Henry Edward Goetz, founder of the Goetz Sanitarium, was born to Edward and Sarah Jane (Hawn) Goetz on February 16, 1874 in Louisville, Tennessee. He attended the Bell House School and the University of Tennessee before graduating from the Tennessee Medical College in 1905. He married Beatrice Hollister on January 24, 1898, and the couple had at least three children%3A Royal Frank, Beatrice, and Helena. Goetz did postgraduate work in 1906 and eventually specialized in otolaryngology. He later became interested in narcotics addicts and attended a special course in mental and nervous diseases in New York in 1913. He founded the Goetz Sanitarium on North Broadway upon his return to Knoxville. He moved his hospital to the Fountain Head Hotel in 1917, and continued to work here until his death following the removal of a brain tumor on December 2, 1927.

row.title: Holston National Bank Building
row.abstract: Knoxville Banking and Trust constructed this building, best known as the Holston National Bank Building, in 1912. At 12 stories, it was Knoxville's tallest edifice until 1928, when it was surpassed by the Andrew Johnson Building. The Holston National Bank became the Holston-Union Bank in 1928 and the Hamilton National Bank (now known as the First Tennessee Bank) in 1931. Although the Holston no longer serves the financial industry, it has been repurposed as a luxury residence building and continues to be a prominent Knoxville landmark.

row.title: View in Melrose Park
row.abstract: Melrose Park was originally an upscale Knoxville residential neighborhood. The University of Tennessee acquired the area in the 1960s and began destroying its Victorian-era homes to allow for University expansion in the late 1970s. Although several homes were adapted to house University programs, few traces of the area's original character remain today.

row.title: Morgan Hall (UT Agricultural Campus)
row.abstract: Morgan Hall was constructed on the University of Tennessee's Agricultural Campus in 1921. Originally called the Agricultural Hall, it was later renamed in honor of Harcourt A. Morgan, who arranged for the State of Tennessee to provide the money needed for its construction. Although space needs have changed many times since the building's construction, care has been taken to maintain the its architectural and historical integrity and it is still in use today.

row.title: Chinese Pavilion
row.abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

row.title: Graf-Cullum House
row.abstract: Richard F. Graf designed and built this house at 325 Woodlawn Pike in about 1923. The Graf family lived in this home for many years before Dr. J.P. Cullum acquired it. Graf and several of his sons operated the architecture firm R.F. Graf & Sons in downtown Knoxville from 1910 until 1942.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Craighead-Jackson House
row.abstract: John Craighead constructed the Craighead-Jackson House in 1818. After Robert Craighead II sold the property in 1855, the structure passed through many hands and fell into serious disrepair. In the late 1950s, the Blount Mansion Association arranged for the home's restoration. The edifice opened as a museum on 3 April 1966 and was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1973. This museum also houses William Perry "Buck" Toms' collection of 18th century silver, said to be the finest in the Southeast.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Yoholo Micco, A Creek Chief
row.abstract: Yoholo Micco was the principal chief of the Eufalo town on the Tallapoosa River. He was one of the Creek delagates who travelled to Washington, DC in 1826 in order to argue against the Treaty of Indian Springs, which ceded all Creek land in Georgia to the Federal Government. His later support of the US Government cost him his office, and he later removed to Arkansas, where he died. This print was taken from a portrait painted by Charles Bird King in 1826. The original has since been destroyed by fire.

row.title: 3rd Platoon, Company A of the 109th Engineers Combat Battalion After African Campaign
row.abstract: The 109th Engineer Regiment was organized as a South Dakota National Guard unit in 1924. It was called up for federal service on February 10, 1941 and trained in Louisiana before being sent to Camp Killadeas, Ireland in preparation for the invasion of North Africa. The 109th was among the first units to land in Algiers in November of 1942 and eventually fought in the Italian theater as well. The unit was deactivated after V-E Day but called up again in 1950 for further service in Germany. Most of the unit had returned home by 1952, where it resumed its duties with the National Guard. The 109th also served in Iraq before the unit was formally deactivated in Sturgis, South Dakota on August 18, 2007.

row.title: Appalachian Exposition Administration Building
row.abstract: The 1910 Appalachian Exposition was held from September 12 to October 12 in Knoxville's Chilhowee Park. The first of its kind in Appalachia, the Fair was intended to demonstrate Southern progress in industry and commerce and to advocate the preservation of the area's natural resources. The fair did not, however, achieve its broader goal%3A to turn Knoxville into a model New South city.

row.title: 1205 W. Clinch Avenue
row.abstract: View of single-family home located at 1205 W. Clinch Avenue in Knoxville, Tennessee. According to Victor A. Hyde, this residence is located in a B-type district, which he defines as one "occupied by white occupants, in which the residences range in value from $2,500 to $10,000." These communities generally separate wealthy A-type communities from poorer C-type communities.

row.title: Masonic Temple
row.abstract: Knoxville's Masonic Temple was originally Charles McClung McGhee's private home. The structure was designed by architect Joseph F. Baumann in 1872 and altered to serve as the Masonic Temple after McGhee's death in 1907. The interior of the home was restored in the early 1990s.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: William Gannaway "Parson" Brownlow Residence
row.abstract: Controversial Methodist preacher and newspaperman William Gannaway "Parson" Brownlow was born in 1805 in Wythe County, Virginia. His zest for confrontation and staunch Union loyalties convinced the Confederacy to expel him from Tennessee during the Civil War, but he returned to Tennessee in March of 1865 when he was elected governor. During his term, Brownlow convinced the legislature to ratify the 14th Amendment (thus sparing Tennessee from Reconstruction) and made great progress toward restoring the State's economic health. He served one term in the US Senate before dying in 1877.

row.title: Chilhowee Park
row.abstract: Swimmers in Chilhowee Park's lake. Among the visible structures are the Southern States Building and the lake's distinctive walkway. Originally known as Lake Ottossee, Chilhowee Park began to develop as a recreational area in 1890 when William G. McAdoo opened a streetcar line making the lake easily accessible from Knoxville. The area was renamed Chilhowee Park in 1900 and was the site of several expositions between 1910 and 1913. Although it has lost some of its former grandeur, the Park is still a popular recreation area today.

row.title: Island Home Farm
row.abstract: Perez Dickinson was born in Amherst, Massachusetts in 1813. He moved to Knoxville in about 1830, where he quickly became an extremely popular and successful merchant. He purchased Williams Island (located in the Tennessee River) in 1869. Here, he constructed a manor house and established Island Home Farm. He raised crops of fruits and vegetables until his death in 1901.

row.title: Gay Street Viaduct
row.abstract: The Gay Street Viaduct was constructed in 1919 when the street's north end was raised by 15 feet. A number of shops moved to locations under the new viaduct, where they prospered for many years. Unfortunately, the structure gradually fell into disrepair and was closed for demolition in November of 2005. It was replaced by a concrete viaduct in late 2006, which remains in use today.

row.title: Knoxville Sentinel Building during the World Series
row.abstract: In the 1920s, the Knoxville Sentinel maintained a board that allowed fans to keep up with the World Series game. It was manned by two boys%3A one (seen near the policeman's perch) relayed news to the crowd via megaphone, and the other (seen at the bottom of the board) updated the posted score. In this 1921 event, the Giants beat the Yankees 5-3.

row.title: John T. Whitaker with Group
row.abstract: John Thompson Whitaker was born on January 25, 1906. He earned his A.B. from the University of the South in 1927 and went on to write for the Chattanooga News and the New York Herald Tribune. He eventually became a foreign correspondent and covered the Ethiopian and Spanish Civil Wars before being stationed in Europe during World War II. He wrote three books%3A And Fear Came (1936), Americas to the South (1939), and We Cannot Escape History (1943). He died on September 11, 1946.

row.title: Knoxville High School
row.abstract: Knoxville High School was built on the site of the old J.Y. Johnston home in 1910 and expanded in 1914 and 1920. It was intended to provide a cultural education and enjoyed a reputation as one of the South's best schools. The school's last class graduated in 1951, after which the structure served as the city schools administration's headquarters. The building was repurposed again in the 1980s, and now houses a number of educational programs including adult education, the adult high school, GED testing, and continuing education.

row.title: Tennessee State Capitol Building
row.abstract: In the early 20th century, popular theory held that this building, located on Cumberland Avenue, was the first state capitol of Tennessee. There is, however, no evidence to support this claim - indeed, several astute commentators have pointed out that this structure was not built until after the capital had moved to Middle Tennessee. In any case, the building was razed in January of 1927.

row.abstract: Although marble is no longer mined in East Tennessee, it was once an important industry in the Knoxville area. This image shows a typical marble quarry in the early 20th century.

row.title: Park Inn
row.abstract: The Park Inn opened in late 1931 in what had been Phi Gamma Delta's Fraternity House at 1541 West Cumberland Avenue. Although it advertised itself as "Knoxville's Outstanding Tourist Home ... Strictly High Class," the enterprise failed in about 1933. Although a private citizen rented out its furnished rooms in 1934, it was once again home to a fraternity (this time Alpha Tau Omega) by 1935.

row.title: Second Presbyterian Church
row.abstract: The Second Presbyterian Church was organized in 1818 due to a split (brought on by disagreements over doctrine and renting pews) in the First Presbyterian Church's congregation. They built their first church on the west side of Prince (now Market) Street in 1820. The congregation grew quickly and moved to a larger building on the corner of Clinch Avenue and Market Street in 1860. The area around the church grew more congested as Knoxville grew, and the congregation sold their Market Street property and moved to a new building on the corner of Clinch and Walnut in 1905. The congregation eventually outgrew this building as well, and moved to a structure on Kingston Pike in 1957.

row.title: Knoxville Traction Company Reservoir and Power House
row.abstract: The Knoxville Traction Company was chartered on March 31, 1898 and eventually operated some 60 electric streetcars on 30 miles of track. It became part of the Knoxville Railway and Light Company when all transit and electric operations were consolidated in 1908. The eventual successor of this organization, the Knoxville Utilities Board (KUB), continues to serve the city today.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Medical Arts Building
row.abstract: The Medical Arts Building, located on Knoxville's Main Street, was completed in 1930. It was constructed under the direct supervision of the medical profession so that it could be tailored to meet the individual needs of each tenant. For many years, it was considered one of the finest Medical Arts Buildings in the United States. The structure has been listed on the National Register of Historic Places since 1984.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: World's Fair Grounds
row.abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

row.title: Typical Houses in the Dale Avenue District
row.abstract: Typical houses on Knoxville's Dale Avenue. Welles places this area in the Northwest District, which she describes as "essentially a mill section, [as] many of its inhabitants depend ... for their living on the large mills." She finds the homes to be "poorly constructed in most instances" but does not find the living conditions as deplorable as they are in some of the other sections.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Wedding Breakfast in "The White Cliffs of Dover"
row.abstract: Clarence Brown giving Irene Dunne last-minute direction on the set of "The White Cliffs of Dover." The movie begins with Susan Dunn (Irene Dunne) and her father, Hiram Porter Dunn (Frank Morgan), vacationing in England during World War I. Here, Susan meets and marries wealthy British aristocrat Sir John Ashwood (Alan Marshal). Sadly, Ashwood is killed on the battlefield, and Susan is left to raise their son, John Ashwood II (Roddy McDowall and Peter Lawford) alone. During World War II, the younger John Ashwood serves with the British army while Susan Ashwood works for the Red Cross. He is wounded in battle, and she is devastated to find her own son among the wounded soldiers that she cares for. She is unable to save his life, but consoles herself with the knowledge that both her husband and her son died for a noble cause.

row.title: Stratford Hotel
row.abstract: This picture was taken shortly after the completion of the Stratford Hotel at 409 Wall Avenue in 1905. Although not as well known as the Andrew Johnson Hotel or the St. James Hotel, the Stratford Hotel operated until 1939. In 1940, it was replaced with the Stratford Hotel Barber Shop.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Clarence Brown Directing "Anna Karenina"
row.abstract: "Anna Karenina" stars Greta Garbo as the sheltered wife of Czarist official Karenin (Basil Rathbone). She is not happy in her marriage, however, and soon falls in love with Count Vronsky (Frederic March). When this affair is discovered, Anna Karenina is cast out of upper-class Russian society and is even prohibited from seeing her son, Sergei (Freddie Bartholomew), whose father tells him that his mother is dead. Anna Karenina follows Vronsky to Venice and later to St. Petersburg, where he deserts her to fight in the Turkish-Serbian War. She is finally driven to suicide, and throws herself under a train.

row.title: Clarence Brown as a Reporter in "The Acquittal"
row.abstract: Clarence Brown playing a reporter in "The Acquittal." The movie tells the story of Andrew Prentice (Charles Wellesley) who has two unrelated adopted sons: Kenneth Winthrop (Richard Travers) and Robert Armstrong (Norman Kerry). Winthrop is married to Madeline Ames (Claire Windsor). When Prentice is found dead, Winthrop is charged with and acquitted of the crime. Thus, it falls to Madeline to find the real killer.

row.title: Clarence Brown Directing Greta Garbo in "Romance"
row.abstract: Presented as a series of flashbacks, "Romance" stars Greta Garbo as famous operatic soprano Madame Rita Cavallini. Thomas Armstrong (Gavin Gordon), and aristocratic clergyman, falls in love with Cavallini at a party and the two begin a relationship in spite of his family's disapproval and rumors of her checkered past. Their plans for marriage dissolve when Armstrong discovers that she was previously involved with his uncle, Cornelius 'Corny' Van Tuyl (Lewis Stone). Armstrong denounces her and the two never see each other again. Unfortunately, his story does not dissuade his grandson Harry (Elliott Nugent) from marrying an actress, and Armstrong later reads of Cavallini's death in the newspaper.
row.name: unknown | Role: Creator | Role URI: http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: View on the Set of "The White Cliffs of Dover"
row.abstract: "The White Cliffs of Dover" begins with Susan Dunn (Irene Dunne) and her father, Hiram Porter Dunn (Frank Morgan), vacationing in England during World War I. Here, Susan meets and marries wealthy British aristocrat Sir John Ashwood (Alan Marshal). Sadly, Ashwood is killed on the battlefield, and Susan is left to raise their son, John Ashwood II (Roddy McDowall and Peter Lawford) alone. During World War II, the younger John Ashwood serves with the British army while Susan Ashwood works for the Red Cross. He is wounded in battle, and she is devastated to find her own son among the wounded soldiers that she cares for. She is unable to save his life, but consoles herself with the knowledge that both her husband and her son died for a noble cause.

row.title: W.M. Fulton House
row.abstract: View of the W.M. Fulton house, built in 1928. According to Victor A. Hyde, this home is located in an A-type community: one "occupied by white inhabitants, having a value of $10,000 or more." Weston Miller Fulton himself (1871-1946) was exceptionally wealthy, having invented a number of useful (and profitable) gadgets.

row.title: Clarence Brown on the Set of "A Woman of Affairs"
row.abstract: "A Woman of Affairs" stars Greta Garbo as Diana Merrick, a worldly socialite who has loved Neville 'Nevs' Holderness (John Gilbert) since both were children. Nevs' father disapproves, and sends Nevs to Egypt to work after convincing him not to marry Diana. Two years later, Diana marries another childhood friend, David Furness (Johnny Mack Brown), who later commits suicide in Paris. As a result of the tragedy, Diana is cast out of upper-class English society and embarks on a string of meaningless affairs with men around the world. She eventually returns to England days before Nevs' wedding to Constance (Dorothy Sebastian).

row.abstract: Larkin and Katherine (Gaw) Brown standing by an automobile on Clarence Brown's ranch in Southern California. This picture taken on the Ranch of our Son 27 1/2 miles from 2021 Holly Hill Towne Hollwood Calif. We both send our love to all three Chappell's. Our Director Son Clarence Brown gave us this auto."

row.abstract: The J.J. Craig Company founded the Candoro Marble Works in South Knoxville in 1914. This business finished marble blocks taken from quarries in Knox, Blount, and Loudon counties in addition to marble imported from around the world. At its peak, it employed about 140 people.

row.title: East Tennessee Female Institute
row.abstract: The East Tennessee Female Institute was founded in 1828. The academy offered such courses as arithmetic, orthography, reading, music, penmanship, astronomy, chemistry, and latin. The institute was merged with the Knoxville public school system in 1882, and this building was demolished in 1889.

row.title: Rudolph Valentino in "The Eagle"
row.abstract: Based on a Pushkin novel, "The Eagle" stars Rudolph Valentino as a Russian cossack named Vladimir Dubrouvsky. He is one of Catherine the Great's particular favorites, but he will not be kept as a lover and spurns her advances. When Kyrilla Troekouroff steals his lands, he creates a secret identity, "The Black Eagle," and becomes a masked avenger. Although bent on revenge, he falls in love with Troekouroff's daughter, Mascha (Vilma Banky). Mascha, in turn, worships the Eagle but disdains his unmasked identity, her foppish French tutor Monsieur Le Blanc. Dubrouvsky's love for Masha eventually counteracts his desire for revenge against her father, and the couple flee Troekouroff's estate. Although captured by the Czarina's men, Catherine rescinds her orders to execute the Eagle and the pair escape to Paris.

row.title: First Methodist Episcopal Church
row.abstract: The first Methodist Episcopal Church was organized shortly after the Civil War by the Reverend J.B. Ford. Their first permanent church, dedicated in 1869, stood on the corner of Clinch and Market Streets. The congregation grew quickly and moved to this church, located on the corner of Clinch Avenue and Locust Street, in 1894. The building was designed in the Romanesque style by architect H.H. Richardson. The Church moved again, this time to the Hugh Sanford property, in 1966 and became the First United Methodist Church when the Methodist Church and the United Evangelical Brethren merged in 1968.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: The Candy Factory
row.abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

row.title: Rutherford B. Hayes Speaking at the Lamar House
row.abstract: When President Rutherford B. Hayes visited Knoxville in 1877, he was honored by a reception at the Lamar House. This establishment was built in 1817, and the Bijou Theatre opened as part of the hotel on March 8, 1909. Over the years, it hosted many famous vaudeville and theater acts. By 2005, however, the Theater was deteriorating and its owners defaulted on their mortgage. Knoxvillians, including Mayor Bill Haslam, banded together to save the Theater and fundraising and renovation efforts are ongoing.

row.title: Port of Knoxville Public Terminal
row.abstract: River traffic has flowed through East Tennessee since the area was settled in the late 18th century. From 1930 to 1933, the TVA made a number of improvements to the river that allowed for a significant increase in the quantity of Knoxville's river trade. The TVA operated Knoxville's Public Terminal (located on Neyland Drive) from 1944 to 1952, when it was leased to private interests. In 1962, the terminal was sold and became a for-hire facility.

row.title: Knox County Court House
row.abstract: The first Knox County Court House was designed by architect Drury P. Armstrong and constructed in 1842. It was replaced by a more modern building, built in the Queen Anne style, in 1885. Now called the old Knoxville Courthouse, this structure stands on approximately the site of the Federal barracks of James White's Fort. New wings were added to either side of the courthouse in 1919.

row.title: Clarence Brown Pumping Water at Gillette Ranch
row.abstract: In 1926, razor baron King Camp Gillette commissioned Wallace Neff to build him a "paradise on earth" in Southern California. The result was a stunning 25 room mansion built in the Spanish Colonial Revival Style whose beauty supposedly brought Gillette to tears. Gillette died in 1932, and his widow sold the property to prominent film director Clarence Brown in 1935. Brown regularly hosted large parties for well-known Hollywood personalities here, and made several changes to the property including the addition of a projection room and a small airport. He sold the property to the Claretian Order of the Catholic Church in 1952, which used it as a seminary and noviate. The Claretians subsequently sold to Elizabeth Clair Prophet's Church Universal and Triumphant in 1977, which in turn sold to the Soka University of American in 1986. In 2007, Soka sold the property to the National Park Service, which intends to restore and preserve it.

row.title: Civic Building and Southern Railway Depot
row.abstract: Front of a souvenir postcard folder showing Knoxville's Civic Building and Southern Railway Station. The Station was built in Knoxville in 1904. It prospered until passenger traffic began to decline in the 1960s due to competition from airplanes and automobiles. The last passenger train to pass through the station was the "Birmingham Special," which departed on August 12, 1970. The station was renovated in the early 1990s for use by Knoxville architectural firm Bullock, Smith, and Partners, Inc.

row.title: Mary Olivia Rawls (Mills) Hoskins and Ostrich
row.abstract: Mary Olivia Rawls was born to William and Susan (Dickason) Rawls on a plantation near Commerce Landing, Mississippi on January 8, 1842. Her parents died shortly after she was born, and she was adopted by Captain John Mills and his wife. The family moved to East Tennessee, where Mary Mills attended Dr. Park's seminary in Rogersville and graduated from the East Tennessee Female Institute. She married William Patton Hoskins (1838-1902) on September 26, 1860, and the couple had seven children: Leila Susan, Nellie Temple, James Dickason, Lynn Wood, Horace Mills, Bessie Olivia, and Mary Margaret. Mary Rawls Mills Hoskins died in 1917 in Knoxville, Tennessee.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Aerial View of Gillette Ranch
row.abstract: In 1926, razor baron King Camp Gillette commissioned Wallace Neff to build him a "paradise on earth" in Southern California. The result was a stunning 25 room mansion built in the Spanish Colonial Revival Style whose beauty supposedly brought Gillette to tears. Gillette died in 1932, and his widow sold the property to prominent film director Clarence Brown in 1935. Brown regularly hosted large parties for well-known Hollywood personalities here, and made several changes to the property including the addition of a projection room and a small airport. He sold the property to the Claretian Order of the Catholic Church in 1952, which used it as a seminary and noviate. The Claretians subsequently sold to Elizabeth Clair Prophet's Church Universal and Triumphant in 1977, which in turn sold to the Soka University of American in 1986. In 2007, Soka sold the property to the National Park Service, which intends to restore and preserve it.

row.title: Lawson McGhee Library
row.abstract: In 1885, Charles McClung McGhee established the Lawson McGhee Library as a memorial to his daughter, May Lawson McGhee Williams. The original building on the corner of Gay and Vine was replaced by this white marble structure on the corner of Market and Commerce in 1917. It remained in use until 1971, when a new building was constructed.

row.title: Opothle Yoholo, a Creek Chief
row.abstract: Opothle Yoholo served as the principal councilor (sometimes called the speaker of the council) in the Creek towns on the Tallapoosa and Coosa rivers in Alabama. He took part in the 1826 Creek delegation to Washington, DC to argue against the Treaty of Indian Springs. Although he remained steadfast in his opposition to the US Government's plans to relocate the Creek, he led a group of Creek warriors against the Seminole during the Creek War of 1836 and later removed to Arkansas voluntarily. This print was taken from a portrait painted by Charles Bird King in 1826. The original has since been destroyed by fire.

row.title: Knoxville Electric Company (622 South Gay Street)
row.abstract: The Knoxville Electric Light and Power Company was organized in 1888. It acquired the Mutual Light & Power Company in 1898, and was itself merged into the Knoxville Railway and Light Company (later known as the Tennessee Public Service Company) in 1905. Knoxville's municipal utility, the Knoxville Electric Power and Water Board, was established in 1939 and is now known as the Knoxville Utilities Board (KUB). This image also provides an excellent view of one of the perches that policemen used to control traffic in the 1920s.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: World's Fair Grounds (including the International Court of Flags and the Sunsphere)
row.abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Entrance to Melrose Place
row.abstract: Melrose Park was originally an upscale Knoxville residential neighborhood. The University of Tennessee acquired the area in the 1960s and began destroying its Victorian-era homes to allow for University expansion in the late 1970s. Although several homes were adapted to house University programs, few traces of the area's original character remain today.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Church Street Methodist Episcopal Church
row.abstract: When the Church Street Methodist Episcopal Church South building (constructed in 1875) was destroyed by fire in 1928, the structure shown replaced it. Although the new building stood at the corner of Henley and Main Streets, the congregation chose to retain "Church Street" in its name. The church's name was changed to Church Street United Methodist Church when the nationwide United Methodist Church was formed in 1968, and this structure continues to operate as a Methodist Church today.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Appalachian Exposition Main Building
row.abstract: The 1910 Appalachian Exposition was held from September 12 to October 12 in Knoxville's Chilhowee Park. The first of its kind in Appalachia, the Fair was intended to demonstrate Southern progress in industry and commerce and to advocate the preservation of the area's natural resources. The fair did not, however, achieve its broader goal%3A to turn Knoxville into a model New South city.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Fort James White
row.abstract: General James White built this house, the first in Knoxville, in 1786. It was originally located at one corner of a rectangular lot with smaller houses in the other three corners, a common frontier design intended to protect against Indians. After the White family established a farm away from this location, the structure was repurposed as the kitchen wing of the Kennedy residence on State Street. In 1906, Isaiah Ford purchased the building and moved it to Woodlawn Pike, where he used it as a private residence. It changed hands again in 1970, when the City Association of Women's Clubs purchased the home and moved it back to central Knoxville. It currently stands near the Knoxville Coliseum and is one of the most visited historical sites in the city.

row.title: John Gilbert, Lew Cody, and Clarence Brown on the Set of "Flesh and the Devil"
row.abstract: "Flesh and the Devil" tells the story of two Austrian military men, Leo von Harden (John Gilbert) and Ulrich von Eltz (Lars Hanson), who have been friends since childhood. At the beginning of the movie, von Harden meets (and begins an affair with) Felicitas (Greta Garbo). When her husband Count Von Rhaden (Marc MacDermott) discovers them, he challenges von Harden to a duel. von Harden kills the Count, but his superiors send him to Africa as punishment. When he returns, it is to find Felicitas married to von Eltz, who he had asked to take care of her during his absence. von Harden eventually loses control of himself, and the movie ends with a climactic duel between the two former friends.

row.title: Gladiolas on C.L. Baum's Bearden Farm
row.abstract: German immigrant Charles L. Baum opened his first florist shop in 1889 at 319 W. Clinch Avenue. The business proved extremely successful, and Baum was able to expand considerably over the years. This image shows gladiolas on Baum's 65-acre farm in Bearden, Tennessee.

row.title: Entrance to Lida (McClung) Ross' Garden
row.abstract: Eliza "Lida" Mills McClung (1882-1968) was born to Calvin Morgan and Annie (McGhee) McClung in Tennessee. She married William Cary Ross (1879-1956) on December 2, 1902 and the couple lived at 4155 Lyons View Pike, where Lida maintained the garden shown above.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Gillette Ranch Dining Room
row.abstract: In 1926, Razor baron King Camp Gillette commissioned Wallace Neff to build him a "paradise on earth" in Southern California. The result was a stunning 25 room mansion built in the Spanish Colonial Revival Style whose beauty supposedly brought Gillette to tears. Gillette died in 1932, and his widow sold the property to prominent film director Clarence Brown in 1935. Brown regularly hosted large parties for well-known Hollywood personalities here, and made several changes to the property, including the addition of a projection room and a small airport. He sold the property to the Claretian Order of the Catholic Church in 1952, which used it as a seminary and noviate. The Claretians subsequently sold to Elizabeth Clair Prophet's Church Universal and Triumphant in 1977, which in turn sold to the Soka University of American in 1986. In 2007, Soka sold the property to the National Park Service, which intends to restore and preserve it.

row.title: Clarence Brown with "Intruder in the Dust Cast" and Others
row.abstract: Clarence Brown with "Intruder in the Dust" cast members and unidentified others. The picture may have been taken while shooting on location in Nashville, Tennessee. The movie is set in rural Mississippi during the 1940s and features Juano Hernandez as Lucas Beauchamp, a black man with a reputation for standing up to whites. When Beauchamp is found standing over a white man's dead body, he is immediately jailed. He insists that he is innocent and asks the town's most prominent lawyer, Gavin Stevens (David Brian), to defend him, but Stevens refuses. The situation changes, however, when a local boy named Chick Mallison (Claude Jarman Jr.) who Beauchamp has helped in the past hears talk of an impending lynching and begs Stevens to change his mind.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Market Street
row.abstract: Knoxville's original Market House was built in 1816. During the Civil War, the Union used the Market House to store ammunition and business was conducted outside. A new Market House was built in 1897 and merchants offered a wide variety of items, including baked goods, fresh meats, and homegrown fruits and vegetables from permanent stalls and wagons parked outside. After being partially destroyed by fire, this structure was demolished to make way for the Market Street Mall in 1960. This particular market took place on Market Street, located near the Market House.

row.title: Lobby of the St. James Hotel
row.abstract: Originally known as the Van Deventer building, the St. James Hotel was built shortly after the "Million Dollar Fire" of 1897. During the 1920s, the hotel developed a reputation as a musical center%3A WNOX (earlier WNAV) was located at the St. James by 1923, and the Brunswick/Vocalion label set up temporary quarters in the building in 1929. A number of artists, many of whom went on to achieve national and international recognition, made recordings here during the "St. James Sessions" of 1929-1930. The hotel was demolished in 1973.

row.title: Riverside Drive Water Pumping Station
row.abstract: This water pumping station (located on Riverside Drive) was refurbished in 1894. The station faced further problems between 1900 and 1908, when the City of Knoxville and the Knoxville Water Company were in litigation over the city's rate ordinance. The Supreme Court ruled in the city's favor in 1909.

row.title: Lawson McGhee Library
row.abstract: In 1885, Charles McClung McGhee established the Lawson McGhee Library as a memorial to his daughter, May Lawson McGhee Williams. The original building on the corner of Gay and Vine was replaced by this white marble structure on the corner of Market and Commerce in 1917. It remained in use until 1971, when a new building was constructed.

row.title: Governor William Blount's Office
row.abstract: Both Governor Blount's home and office were built in 1792. Although the home was restored and opened as a museum in the early 1920s, the office was not repaired until 1955. It currently serves as part of the Blount Mansion museum.

row.title: Interior of the Bijou Theater
row.abstract: The Lamar House Hotel was built in 1817. The Bijou Theatre opened as part of that hotel on March 8, 1909. Over the years, it hosted many famous vaudeville and theater acts. By 2005, however, the Theater was deteriorating and its owners defaulted on their mortgage. Knoxvillians, including Mayor Bill Haslam, banded together to save the Theater and fundraising and renovation efforts are ongoing.

row.title: Portrait, Residence, and Office of "Parson" Brownlow
row.abstract: Controversial Methodist preacher and newspaperman William Gannaway "Parson" Brownlow was born in 1805 in Wythe County, Virginia. His zest for confrontation and staunch Union loyalties convinced the Confederacy to expel him from Tennessee during the Civil War, but he returned to Tennessee in March of 1865 when he was elected governor. During his term, Brownlow convinced the legislature to ratify the 14th Amendment (thus sparing Tennessee from Reconstruction) and made great progress toward restoring the State's economic health. He served one term in the US Senate before dying in 1877.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Technology and Lifestyle Center
row.abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Lobby Card for "The Rains Came"
row.abstract: Set in India in 1938, "The Rains Came" stars Myrna Loy as Lady Edwina Esketh, the privileged wife of British aristocrat Lord Albert Esketh (Nigel Bruce). While visiting the picturesque town of Ranchipur, Lady Esketh meets a former lover, Tom Ransome (George Brent), who is now being pursued by sheltered Fern Simon (Brenda Joyce). Soon after this reunion, Lady Esketh becomes fascinated by Major Rama Safti (Tyrone Power) and pursues him even though Ransome, his closest friend, warns her that he is completely devoted to his medical practice. Before anything can be decided, the city is struck by heavy rains, earthquakes, flooding, polluted water, and finally plague. These disasters force all of the characters to consider carefully what is truly important to them.

row.title: Gay Street Bridge
row.abstract: The Union Army built Knoxville's first bridge across the Tennessee River during the Civil War. This structure was washed away in 1867 and subsequently replaced by a toll bridge. A tornado destroyed this span in 1875, and a fourth bridge was constructed in 1880. This structure lasted until 1898, when it was replaced by a modern and much-admired steel bridge. Also visible in this image is Knoxville's courthouse, which was constructed in 1885.

row.title: Edward Sanford Mansion (Maplehurst)
row.abstract: Businessman Edward Jackson Sanford and his wife, Emma Chavannes, bought this home from Knoxville businessman and politician James Hervey Cowan in 1890. Originally known as "River Lawn," the Sanfords renamed the property "Maplehurst" because of the several maple trees growing on the property. Sanford died in 1902, and in 1912 his estate sold the property to Alex McMillan & Co. for development.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Clarence Brown's Plane in Front of Hangar
row.abstract: In 1926, razor baron King Camp Gillette commissioned Wallace Neff to build him a "paradise on earth" in Southern California. The result was a stunning 25 room mansion built in the Spanish Colonial Revival Style whose beauty supposedly brought Gillette to tears. Gillette died in 1932, and his widow sold the property to prominent film director Clarence Brown in 1935. Brown regularly hosted large parties for well-known Hollywood personalities here, and made several changes to the property including the addition of a projection room and a small airport. He sold the property to the Claretian Order of the Catholic Church in 1952, which used it as a seminary and noviate. The Claretians subsequently sold to Elizabeth Clair Prophet's Church Universal and Triumphant in 1977, which in turn sold to the Soka University of American in 1986. In 2007, Soka sold the property to the National Park Service, which intends to restore and preserve it.
