row.title: View on the Set of "A Woman of Affairs"
row.abstract: "A Woman of Affairs" stars Greta Garbo as Diana Merrick, a worldly socialite who has loved Neville 'Nevs' Holderness (John Gilbert) since both were children. Nevs' father disapproves, and sends Nevs to Egypt to work after convincing him not to marry Diana. Two years later, Diana marries another childhood friend, David Furness (Johnny Mack Brown), who later commits suicide in Paris. As a result of the tragedy, Diana is cast out of upper-class English society and embarks on a string of meaningless affairs with men around the world. She eventually returns to England days before Nevs' wedding to Constance (Dorothy Sebastian).

row.title: Larkin Harry and Catherine Ann (Gaw) Brown in front of their Knoxville Home
row.abstract: Clarence Brown was born on May 10, 1890, in Clinton, Massachusetts. He moved with his family to Knoxville, Tennessee as a child and graduated from Knoxville High School in 1905. Brown received a double degree in mechanical and electrical engineering from the University of Tennessee in 1910 and then began a career selling automobiles in Alabama. Fascinated with movies, he moved to New Jersey where he studied with French director Maurice Tourneur at Peerless Studios. There, the pair directed The Last of the Mohicans (1920). Brown directed or produced more than fifty widely-acclaimed full length motion pictures and worked with many of the most famous performers in the film industry, including Joan Crawford and Clark Gable in Chained (1934), Spencer Tracy in Edison the Man (1940), Elizabeth Taylor in National Velvet (1945), and Gregory Peck in The Yearling (1947). At the time of his retirement in 1952, Brown had received six Academy Award nominations for Best Director and won eight Oscars for his films. When he died in 1987, Brown left $12 million to the University of Tennessee. When added to the $1 million donated during his lifetime, the sum made him the largest donor in the university's history.

row.title: St. John's Episcopal Church
row.abstract: St. John's Episcopal Church was organized in Knoxville in 1826. Its original house of worship (on the corner of Walnut and Cumberland streets) was razed in 1891 in order to make way for a larger structure. This building, designed by J.W. Yost, was completed in 1892. When the Diocese of East Tennessee was created in 1986, the Church became St. John's Cathedral. Currently, the Cathedral is one of the only surviving churches in downtown Knoxville.

row.title: Lobby Card for "The White Cliffs of Dover"
row.abstract: "The White Cliffs of Dover" begins with Susan Dunn (Irene Dunne) and her father, Hiram Porter Dunn (Frank Morgan), vacationing in England during World War I. Here, Susan meets and marries wealthy British aristocrat Sir John Ashwood (Alan Marshal). Sadly, Ashwood is killed on the battlefield, and Susan is left to raise their son, John Ashwood II (Roddy McDowall and Peter Lawford) alone. During World War II, the younger John Ashwood serves with the British army while Susan Ashwood works for the Red Cross. He is wounded in battle, and she is devastated to find her own son among the wounded soldiers that she cares for. She is unable to save his life, but consoles herself with the knowledge that both her husband and her son died for a noble cause.

row.title: Fort Loudon Dam
row.abstract: The TVA built Fort Loudon Dam, the uppermost of the dams on the Tennessee River, between 1940 and 1944 in order to control floods, aid navigation, create electric power, and ensure adequate water supply. The finished dam is 125 feet high and 4,190 feet long. The lake it creates serves as a popular recreation area.

row.title: Clarence Brown and Frederic March on the Set of "Anna Karenina"
row.abstract: "Anna Karenina" stars Greta Garbo as the sheltered wife of Czarist official Karenin (Basil Rathbone). She is not happy in her marriage, however, and soon falls in love with Count Vronsky (Frederic March). When this affair is discovered, Anna Karenina is cast out of upper-class Russian society and is even prohibited from seeing her son, Sergei (Freddie Bartholomew), whose father tells him that his mother is dead. Anna Karenina follows Vronsky to Venice and later to St. Petersburg, where he deserts her to fight in the Turkish-Serbian War. She is finally driven to suicide, and throws herself under a train.

row.title: Individual Market House Stall
row.abstract: Knoxville's original Market House was built in 1816. During the Civil War, the Union used the Market House to store ammunition and business was conducted outside. A new Market House was built in 1897 and merchants offered a wide variety of items, including baked goods, fresh meats, and homegrown fruits and vegetables from permanent stalls and wagons parked outside. After being partially destroyed by fire, this structure was demolished to make way for the Market Street Mall in 1960. This image shows a stall in the market's meat section, which advertises the "finest meat ever offered for sale in Tenn."

row.title: Kuhlman's Drug Store No. 2
row.abstract: William D. Kuhlman opened the first of his chain of drugstores at 301 Gay Street in 1894. The store pictured, Kuhlman's Drug Store No. 2, opened at 600 S. Gay Street in 1905. It closed in 1909, but later re-opened at 607 S. Gay Street. Kuhlman eventually established three additional stores: one at 310 W. Clinch Avenue, one at 322 N. Gay Street, and one on S. Gay Street near the Tennessee River Bridge.

row.title: Clarence Brown Directing "Wife vs. Secretary"
row.abstract: "Wife vs. Secretary" tells the story of Van Stanhope (Clark Gable), an industrious magazine publisher who is happily married to Linda (Myrna Loy). Although his secretary, Helen "Whitey" Wilson (Jean Harlow), is in love with him, she respects his marriage and takes pains to ensure that their relationship remains strictly professional. Linda is suspicious, however, especially since her mother (May Robson) frequently suggests that Van is being unfaithful. These suspicions are apparently confirmed when Van takes Whitey on an important business trip to Cuba. Linda is infuriated, but Whitey manages to convince her that her husband has never betrayed her, thus saving their marriage.

row.abstract: "Edison, The Man" constitutes the sequel to "Young Tom Edison" and the second half of MGM's 1940 biography of Thomas Alva Edison. In this film, elderly Thomas Edison (Spencer Tracy) looks back on his early life. These memories include his early setbacks, the invention of the incandescent light bulb, and his happy family life with his wife, Mary Stillwell (Rita Johnson).

row.title: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences Nomination of Clarence Brown for an Academy Award for "The Yearling"
row.abstract: Director Clarence Brown won an Academy Award for "The Yearling," which tells the story of an American family living in Florida shortly after the Civil War. Ezra "Penny" Baxter (Gregory Peck) is a hardworking farmer struggling to support his wife, Orry (Jane Wyman), and single surviving son, Jody (Claude Jarman, Jr.). When Penny is bitten by a rattlesnake, he is forced to kill a doe to obtain the necessary antivenin. Jody begs to keep her orphaned faun, and his father agrees. When the faun becomes a yearling, however, it begins breaking into the garden that the family depends on for both food and money. As a result, Jody is forced to make a heartbreaking choice.

row.title: Sunsphere Under Construction
row.abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

row.title: View on the Set of "A Woman of Affairs"
row.abstract: "A Woman of Affairs" stars Greta Garbo as Diana Merrick, a worldly socialite who has loved Neville 'Nevs' Holderness (John Gilbert) since both were children. Nevs' father disapproves, and sends Nevs to Egypt to work after convincing him not to marry Diana. Two years later, Diana marries another childhood friend, David Furness (Johnny Mack Brown), who later commits suicide in Paris. As a result of the tragedy, Diana is cast out of upper-class English society and embarks on a string of meaningless affairs with men around the world. She eventually returns to England days before Nevs' wedding to Constance (Dorothy Sebastian).

row.title: First Through Train to Knoxville
row.abstract: This train, which came from Louisville, Kentucky on the East Tennessee, Virginia & Georgia Railroad, was the first through train to arrive in Knoxville. The ETV&G was formed when the East Tennessee & Georgia Railroad merged with the East Tennessee & Virginia Railroad in 1869. The new railroad expanded significantly before merging with the Richmond and Danville Railroad to form the Southern Railway in 1895.

row.title: Gay Street Bridge
row.abstract: The Union Army built Knoxville's first bridge across the Tennessee River during the Civil War. This structure was washed away in 1867 and subsequently replaced by a toll bridge. A tornado destroyed this span in 1875, and a fourth bridge was constructed in 1880. This structure lasted until 1898, when it was replaced by a modern and much-admired steel bridge.

row.title: Mess Hall
row.abstract: View of the Mess Hall at Fort Sill, Oklahoma. The 158th Infantry Regiment began as the First Arizona Volunteer Infantry on September 2, 1865. It was drafted into Federal service during World War I as part of the 40th Division and reassigned to the 45th Division during postwar reorganizations. When a National Emergency was declared on September 16, 1940, the 158th joined the 45th for training at Fort Sill, Oklahoma and Fort Barkley, Texas. They were detached from the 45th in December of 1941 and sent to the Canal Zone for training in jungle warfare before being assigned to the Pacific Theater in early 1943. The unit was scheduled to spearhead the final invasion of Japan, which was subsequently rendered unnecessary by the atomic bomb. The 158th was deactivated and sent home in January of 1946.

row.title: Lake at Fountain City
row.abstract: The Knoxville suburb of Fountain City began as a center of religious camp meetings in the 1830s. After the Fountain Head Improvement Company built a three-story hotel in 1886 and the Fountain Head Railroad Company began carrying tourists to the area in 1890, however, it lost its original farming character and became a resort area.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Chilhowee Park
row.abstract: Boaters on Chilhowee Park's lake prior to the 1910 Appalachian Exposition. Originally known as Lake Ottossee, Chilhowee Park began to develop as a recreational area in 1890 when William G. McAdoo opened a streetcar line making the lake easily accessible from Knoxville. The area was renamed Chilhowee Park in 1900 and was the site of several expositions between 1910 and 1913. Although it has lost some of its former grandeur, the Park is still a popular recreation area today.

row.title: Fulton Sylphon
row.abstract: Weston Fulton, inventor of the Sylphon Bellows, founded Fulton Sylphon in Knoxville in 1904. It manufactured primarily valves and gages, including a thermostat vital to depth charges during World War I and a part crucial to bomb sights during World War II. The company was later sold to Reynolds Metals and then to Robertshaw and Siebe. It also gradually lost its prominence in the field. In 1994, what remained of the business was purchased by Texas leveraged buyout specialist J. Randal Greaves, and its name was changed to Fulton Bellows and Components to reflect its origins. Now known simply as Fulton Bellows LLC and owned by Morris Capital Management Group (which purchased it in August of 2004), the company continues to operate in Knoxville today.

row.title: The Pickle Mansion
row.abstract: George Wesley Pickle built the Pickle Mansion (sometimes called Confederate Hall and Fort Sanders Hall) at 1633 Clinch Avenue in 1889. The structure was severely damaged by fire in 2003, but plans have been made to restore it. Pickle himself was a veteran of the Confederate Second Tennessee Infantry and served as Tennessee's Attorney General and Reporter of the State from 1886 to 1902.

row.title: Post Office and Custom House Building
row.abstract: Completed in 1874, Knoxville's Post Office and Custom House may have been the city's first building to be designed by a professional architect, in this case Alfred B. Mullett. The structure was enlarged in 1910 and operated until a new Post Office was constructed in 1934. The TVA occupied the building until 1976, when it was restored and repurposed as the East Tennessee Historical Center.

row.title: Gillette Ranch Sitting Room
row.abstract: In 1926, Razor baron King Camp Gillette commissioned Wallace Neff to build him a "paradise on earth" in Southern California. The result was a stunning 25 room mansion built in the Spanish Colonial Revival Style whose beauty supposedly brought Gillette to tears. Gillette died in 1932, and his widow sold the property to prominent film director Clarence Brown in 1935. Brown regularly hosted large parties for well-known Hollywood personalities here, and made several changes to the property, including the addition of a projection room and a small airport. He sold the property to the Claretian Order of the Catholic Church in 1952, which used it as a seminary and noviate. The Claretians subsequently sold to Elizabeth Clair Prophet's Church Universal and Triumphant in 1977, which in turn sold to the Soka University of American in 1986. In 2007, Soka sold the property to the National Park Service, which intends to restore and preserve it.

row.title: Don Whitehead in Captain's Uniform
row.abstract: Donald Ford Whitehead was born to Harry Ford and Elizabeth (Bond) Whitehead on April 8, 1908 in Inman, Virginia. He was raised in Kentucky and earned his degree in journalism from the University of Kentucky in 1928. After graduating, he worked for several newspapers in Kentucky and Tennessee before joining the Associated Press in 1935. He worked as a feature writer in New York for several years and eventually became a foreign correspondent. In this role, he reported on World War II (including the North Africa campaign), postwar atomic testing, and the Korean War. He went on to win two Pulitzer Prizes (1951 and 1953) and write several books, including the bestseller The FBI Story (1956). He also worked for both the New York Herald Tribune and the Knoxville News-Sentinel before retiring in 1978. He married Marie Patterson (1906-1979) on 20 December 1928 and the couple had one daughter, Ruth. Whitehead died in Knoxville, Tennessee on January 12, 1981 of lung cancer at age 72.

row.title: View on the Set of "They Met in Bombay"
row.abstract: "They Met in Bombay" is the story of Gerald Meldrick (Clark Gable) and Anya Von Duren (Rosalind Russell), two jewel thieves intent on stealing a gem from India. After failing independently, they decide to team up. Meldrick intends to let von Duren commit the initial theft and then steal the jewel from her, but she discovers his plans and soon both are fugitives in China. They manage to outwit Inspector Cressney (Matthew Boulton) and mercenary freighter captain Chang (Peter Lorre), but are finally drawn into a pitched battle with invading Japanese forces.

row.title: International Court of Flags
row.abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

row.title: Jane Kennedy's Home
row.abstract: View of Mrs. Jane Kennedy's home. General James White built part of the house itself (the first in Knoxville) in 1786. It was originally located at one corner of a rectangular lot with smaller houses in the other three corners, a common frontier design intended to protect against Indians. After the White family established a farm away from this location, the structure was repurposed as the kitchen wing of the Kennedy residence on State Street. In 1906, Isaiah Ford purchased the building and moved it to Woodlawn Pike, where he used it as a private residence. It changed hands again in 1970, when the City Association of Women's Clubs purchased the home and moved it back to central Knoxville. It currently stands near the Knoxville Coliseum and is one of the most visited historical sites in the city.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Clarence Brown Directing "Chained"
row.abstract: "Chained" is the story of Diane "Dinah" Lovering (Joan Crawford), who is having an affair with boss, Manhattan shipping magnate Richard Field (Otto Kruger). Field asks his wife Louise (Marjorie Gateson) for a divorce, but she refuses to abandon her privileged lifestyle and is not upset by her husband's infidelity. Disappointed, Lovering takes a cruise in order to escape her tumultuous personal life. Here, she meets Mike Bradley (Clark Gable), a wealthy Argentinean horse and cattle rancher. The two fall in love despite Lovering's efforts to remain faithful to Field. Lovering eventually decides to return to New York and tell Field that she intends to marry Bradley, but once there discovers that Field has divorced his wife on the condition that he never see his sons again in order to marry her. Lovering cannot disappoint him, but realizes that she has made a mistake a year later when she unexpectedly meets Bradley in Manhattan. Field meets Bradley as well, and realizes that Lovering would prefer to marry him. Thus, he allows her to leave him for her true love.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Ruskin Colony at Yellow Creek, Tennessee
row.abstract: Indiana newspaperman Julius Augustus Wayland inaugurated the idea for the Ruskin Cooperative Association in 1881. His dream was realized in 1894 when the Ruskin Cooperative Association (named after English social critic John Ruskin) was established in Tennessee City. The colony soon moved to a site near a large cave on Yellow Creek that still bears the name Ruskin. Wayland led the colony for only a year, and tensions soon developed between those colonists who wanted to apply radical socialist ideals in order to bring about the "coming nation" and those who considered Ruskin a haven for such American concepts as political and economic independence. By 1899, this factionalism had caused the colony to disintegrate. The colony was put into receivership, sparking two years of lawsuits between the opposing groups over ownership and control of the Association. Although a few of the colony's members attempted to reestablish it in Georgia as the Ruskin Commonwealth, these efforts proved unsuccessful.

row.title: Photograph of Blanche Lavore Inscribed to Ona Maris
row.abstract: Clarence Brown's second wife, Ona (often spelled "Mona") Maris, was born in Buenos Aires, Argentina in 1903. After emigrating to the United States, she acted in such films as "Under a Texas Moon," "Arizona Kid," "On the Make," and "A Devil with Women." She died in 1991 in Buenos Aires.

row.title: Lawson McGhee Library
row.abstract: In 1885, Charles McClung McGhee established the Lawson McGhee Library as a memorial to his daughter, May Lawson McGhee Williams. The original building on the corner of Gay and Vine was replaced by this white marble structure on the corner of Market and Commerce in 1917. It remained in use until 1971, when a new building was constructed.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: World's Fair Grounds (including the Sunsphere, the U.S. Pavilion, and the Amphitheater)
row.abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

row.title: East Tennessee Deaf and Dumb School
row.abstract: The Tennessee Deaf and Dumb School (whose name changed to the Tennessee School for the Deaf in 1925) was established in Knoxville in 1844. The original campus was the Churchwell House, but the school soon moved to land donated by C.M. McClung near the center of town. After closing during the Civil War, the school expanded quickly during the Reconstruction Era. By 1922, the institution had outgrown its quarters and moved to what had been the Dickinson Estate in South Knoxville. As in previous years, both the campus and its programs expanded quickly. The school continues to serve an important role in Tennessee's educational system today.

row.title: Map of Harder & Co.'s Addition to Knoxville
row.abstract: Map of Harder & Co.'s addition to Knoxville, apparently drawn by John H. Shields in 1856. This addition stretches from Ohio Street in the North to the railroad tracks in the South and Spring Street in the East to Elm Street in the West. It borders on Temple's Addition and King's Addition.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Knoxville City Hall
row.abstract: View of the front entrance to Knoxville's old City Hall. The building was constructed in 1844 and originally housed the Tennessee School for the Deaf. It served as a makeshift hospital for both Union and Confederate troops during the Civil War but returned to its original purpose when the war ended. It became Knoxville's City Hall in 1924, and continued in this function until 1980. The structure is now listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

row.title: Tennessee State Capitol Building
row.abstract: In the early 20th century, popular theory held that this building, located on Cumberland Avenue, was the first state capitol of Tennessee. There is, however, no evidence to support this claim - indeed, several astute commentators have pointed out that this structure was not built until after the capital had moved to Middle Tennessee. In any case, the building was razed in January of 1927.

row.title: Appalachian Exposition Main Building
row.abstract: The 1910 Appalachian Exposition was held from September 12 to October 12 in Knoxville's Chilhowee Park. The first of its kind in Appalachia, the Fair was intended to demonstrate Southern progress in industry and commerce and to advocate the preservation of the area's natural resources. The fair did not, however, achieve its broader goal%3A to turn Knoxville into a model New South city.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Greta Garbo in "A Woman of Affairs"
row.abstract: "A Woman of Affairs" stars Greta Garbo as Diana Merrick, a worldly socialite who has loved Neville 'Nevs' Holderness (John Gilbert) since both were children. Nevs' father disapproves, and sends Nevs to Egypt to work after convincing him not to marry Diana. Two years later, Diana marries another childhood friend, David Furness (Johnny Mack Brown), who later commits suicide in Paris. As a result of the tragedy, Diana is cast out of upper-class English society and embarks on a string of meaningless affairs with men around the world. She eventually returns to England days before Nevs' wedding to Constance (Dorothy Sebastian).

row.title: Military Parade on Gay Street
row.abstract: Spanish-American War soldiers, likely from Tennessee, parading on Gay Street in approximately 1898. Tennessee raised four regiments for the war, but only two ever saw action%3A the 1st Tennessee fought in the Philippines (July 1898-January 1901), and the 4th Tennessee served with the occupation force in Cuba (December 1898-May 1899).

row.title: Port of Knoxville Public Terminal
row.abstract: River traffic has flowed through East Tennessee since the area was settled in the late 18th century. From 1930 to 1933, the TVA made a number of improvements to the river that allowed for a significant increase in the quantity of Knoxville's river trade. The TVA operated Knoxville's Public Terminal (located on Neyland Drive) from 1944 to 1952, when it was leased to private interests. In 1962, the terminal was sold and became a for-hire facility.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: First Methodist Episcopal Church
row.abstract: The first Methodist Episcopal Church was organized shortly after the Civil War by the Reverend J.B. Ford. Their first permanent church, dedicated in 1869, stood on the corner of Clinch and Market Streets. The congregation grew quickly and moved to this church, located on the corner of Clinch Avenue and Locust Street, in 1894. The building was designed in the Romanesque style by architect H.H. Richardson. The Church moved again, this time to the Hugh Sanford property, in 1966 and became the First United Methodist Church when the Methodist Church and the United Evangelical Brethren merged in 1968.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: First Baptist Church
row.abstract: Brothers James and John Moses organized the congregation that would become Knoxville's First Baptist Church in 1843. The church's first permanent house of worship stood on Gay Street and was completed in 1850. The congregation split in 1869, and the dissidents formed Knoxville's Second Baptist Church. The First Baptist Church moved to their second home (made possible in large part by merchant and philanthropist W.W. Woodruff) in 1888. Their current house of worship, located at the corner of Walnut and Main Streets, was completed in 1924 and is still in use today. It was placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1997.

row.title: Lincoln Memorial Hospital
row.abstract: Constructed in 1905, Lincoln Memorial Hospital was closely associated with Lincoln Memorial University's medical program. LMU bought the facility outright in May of 1909, and its medical program merged with four others to form the University of Tennessee College of Medicine in Memphis in 1911.

row.subject_topical: Motion picture producers and directors--United States | http://id.loc.gov/authorities/subjects/sh87006130
row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: John Gilbert and Greta Garbo in "A Woman of Affairs"
row.abstract: "A Woman of Affairs" stars Greta Garbo as Diana Merrick, a worldly socialite who has loved Neville 'Nevs' Holderness (John Gilbert) since both were children. Nevs' father disapproves, and sends Nevs to Egypt to work after convincing him not to marry Diana. Two years later, Diana marries another childhood friend, David Furness (Johnny Mack Brown), who later commits suicide in Paris. As a result of the tragedy, Diana is cast out of upper-class English society and embarks on a string of meaningless affairs with men around the world. She eventually returns to England days before Nevs' wedding to Constance (Dorothy Sebastian).

row.title: Gillette Ranch Billiard Room
row.abstract: In 1926, Razor baron King Camp Gillette commissioned Wallace Neff to build him a "paradise on earth" in Southern California. The result was a stunning 25 room mansion built in the Spanish Colonial Revival Style whose beauty supposedly brought Gillette to tears. Gillette died in 1932, and his widow sold the property to prominent film director Clarence Brown in 1935. Brown regularly hosted large parties for well-known Hollywood personalities here, and made several changes to the property, including the addition of a projection room and a small airport. He sold the property to the Claretian Order of the Catholic Church in 1952, which used it as a seminary and noviate. The Claretians subsequently sold to Elizabeth Clair Prophet's Church Universal and Triumphant in 1977, which in turn sold to the Soka University of American in 1986. In 2007, Soka sold the property to the National Park Service, which intends to restore and preserve it.

row.title: Lake at Fountain City
row.abstract: The Knoxville suburb of Fountain City began as a center of religious camp meetings in the 1830s. After the Fountain Head Improvement Company built a three-story hotel in 1886 and the Fountain Head Railroad Company began carrying tourists to the area in 1890, however, it lost its original farming character and became a resort area.

row.title: Group at Marion Brown's 50th Birthday Party
row.abstract: Marion Ruth Spies was born in Ohio on January 22, 1905. She worked as a schoolteacher before moving to Hollywood in search of a more exciting life. She married director Clarence L. Brown on November 10, 1947. He had previously been married to Paul (called Polly) Pratt, Ona Maris, and Alice Joyce. Later in life, Marion Brown became one of the major forces behind the Browns' many contributions to the University of Tennessee. Clarence Brown died on August 17, 1987 and Marion Brown followed on May 10, 1993.

row.title: Post Office and Custom House Building
row.abstract: Completed in 1874, Knoxville's Post Office and Custom House may have been the city's first building to be designed by a professional architect, in this case Alfred B. Mullett. The structure was enlarged in 1910 and operated until a new Post Office was constructed in 1934. The TVA occupied the building until 1976, when it was restored and repurposed as the East Tennessee Historical Center.

row.title: Audience in the Bijou Theater
row.abstract: The Lamar House Hotel was built in 1817. The Bijou Theatre opened as part of that hotel on March 8, 1909. Over the years, it hosted many famous vaudeville and theater acts. By 2005, however, the Theater was deteriorating and its owners defaulted on their mortgage. Knoxvillians, including Mayor Bill Haslam, banded together to save the Theater and fundraising and renovation efforts are ongoing. This photograph was taken between Acts II and III of _Little Johnny Jones_ on the Bijou's opening night.

row.title: Second Presbyterian Church
row.abstract: The Second Presbyterian Church was organized in 1818 due to a split (brought on by disagreements over doctrine and renting pews) in the First Presbyterian Church's congregation. They built their first church on the west side of Prince (now Market) Street in 1820. The congregation grew quickly and moved to a larger building on the corner of Clinch Avenue and Market Street in 1860. The area around the church grew more congested as Knoxville grew, and the congregation sold their Market Street property and moved to a new building on the corner of Clinch and Walnut in 1905. The congregation eventually outgrew this building as well, and moved to a structure on Kingston Pike in 1957.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Chilhowee Park
row.abstract: Boaters on Chilhowee Park's lake prior to the 1910 Appalachian Exposition. Originally known as Lake Ottossee, Chilhowee Park began to develop as a recreational area in 1890 when William G. McAdoo opened a streetcar line making the lake easily accessible from Knoxville. The area was renamed Chilhowee Park in 1900 and was the site of several expositions between 1910 and 1913. Although it has lost some of its former grandeur, the Park is still a popular recreation area today.

row.title: Interior of the Whittle Springs Hotel
row.abstract: The original Whittle Springs Hotel was built in about 1902 about three miles to the north of Knoxville. It advertised such conveniences as electric lights, baths, unexcelled cuisine, and both telephone and telegraph connections. This structure burned in 1919, and the second Whittle Springs Hotel was constructed on the same site. This building was razed in 1964.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Clarence Brown and Rudolph Valentino on the set of "The Eagle"
row.abstract: Based on a Pushkin novel, "The Eagle" stars Rudolph Valentino as a Russian cossack named Vladimir Dubrouvsky. He is one of Catherine the Great's particular favorites, but he will not be kept as a lover and spurns her advances. When Kyrilla Troekouroff steals his lands, he creates a secret identity, "The Black Eagle," and becomes a masked avenger. Although bent on revenge, he falls in love with Troekouroff's daughter, Mascha (Vilma Banky). Mascha, in turn, worships the Eagle but disdains his unmasked identity, her foppish French tutor Monsieur Le Blanc. Dubrouvsky's love for Masha eventually counteracts his desire for revenge against her father, and the couple flee Troekouroff's estate. Although captured by the Czarina's men, Catherine rescinds her orders to execute the Eagle and the pair escape to Paris.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Wonderland Hotel
row.abstract: The Wonderland Park resort community (including the Wonderland Hotel) was created in Elkmont in 1912 to rival the Appalachian Club's nearby resort area. The Wonderland Park Hotel and its associated buildings became the Wonderland Club in 1914 when they were sold to a group of private investors from Knoxville. Most of these private owners managed to obtain lifetime leases when the Great Smoky Mountains National Park was created. The majority of these leases were eventually converted to 20-year leases that were later extended to expire in 1992. The Wonderland Hotel ceased operations when its lease expired and collapsed in 2005 while debate over what to do with the historic structures standing in Elkmont raged. Although salvage efforts were discussed, the hotel was demolished in late 2006.

row.title: First Electric Streetcar to Lake Ottosee
row.abstract: Although Knoxville's streetcar system was established in 1876, electric streetcars did not arrive until 1890 when W.C. McAdoo Jr. consolidated the existing streetcar lines into the Knoxville Electric Streetcar Company. McAdoo electrified four lines in all: the Lake Ottosee Line, the Park Avenue Line, the Washington Avenue Line, and the Broadway Line. The streetcar in this image was the first to run on the electrified lines.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Myrna Loy in "Wife vs. Secretary"
row.abstract: "Wife vs. Secretary" tells the story of Van Stanhope (Clark Gable), an industrious magazine publisher who is happily married to Linda (Myrna Loy). Although his secretary, Helen "Whitey" Wilson (Jean Harlow), is in love with him, she respects his marriage and takes pains to ensure that their relationship remains strictly professional. Linda is suspicious, however, especially since her mother (May Robson) frequently suggests that Van is being unfaithful. These suspicions are apparently confirmed when Van takes Whitey on an important business trip to Cuba. Linda is infuriated, but Whitey manages to convince her that her husband has never betrayed her, thus saving their marriage.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Clarence Brown in Childhood
row.abstract: Clarence Brown was born on May 10, 1890, in Clinton, Massachusetts. He moved with his family to Knoxville, Tennessee as a child and graduated from Knoxville High School in 1905. Brown received a double degree in mechanical and electrical engineering from the University of Tennessee in 1910 and then began a career selling automobiles in Alabama. Fascinated with movies, he moved to New Jersey where he studied with French director Maurice Tourneur at Peerless Studios. There, the pair directed "The Last of the Mohicans" (1920). Brown directed or produced more than fifty widely-acclaimed full length motion pictures and worked with many of the most famous performers in the film industry, including Joan Crawford and Clark Gable in "Chained" (1934), Spencer Tracy in "Edison the Man" (1940), Elizabeth Taylor in "National Velvet" (1945), and Gregory Peck in "The Yearling" (1947). At the time of his retirement in 1952, Brown had received six Academy Award nominations for Best Director and won eight Oscars for his films. When he died in 1987, Brown left $12 million to the University of Tennessee. When added to the $1 million donated during his lifetime, the sum made him the largest donor in the university's history.

row.title: Gay Street Viaduct
row.abstract: The Gay Street Viaduct was constructed in 1919 when the street's north end was raised by 15 feet. A number of shops moved to locations under the new viaduct, where they prospered for many years. Unfortunately, the structure gradually fell into disrepair and was closed for demolition in November of 2005. It was replaced by a concrete viaduct in late 2006, which remains in use today.

row.title: View of the Tennesse River from the UT Agricultural Experiment Station
row.abstract: The University of Tennessee's Agricultural Experiment Station was established in 1882 with the intention of furthering agricultural research in the state. It grew quickly, and by 1900 branch stations were being built so that research could be conducted under specific local conditions. Today, these stations continue to research numerous topics and provide important contributions to agricultural science in Tennessee and around the world.

row.title: Clarence Brown Plowing with Horses
row.abstract: In 1926, razor baron King Camp Gillette commissioned Wallace Neff to build him a "paradise on earth" in Southern California. The result was a stunning 25 room mansion built in the Spanish Colonial Revival Style whose beauty supposedly brought Gillette to tears. Gillette died in 1932, and his widow sold the property to prominent film director Clarence Brown in 1935. Brown regularly hosted large parties for well-known Hollywood personalities here, and made several changes to the property including the addition of a projection room and a small airport. He sold the property to the Claretian Order of the Catholic Church in 1952, which used it as a seminary and noviate. The Claretians subsequently sold to Elizabeth Clair Prophet's Church Universal and Triumphant in 1977, which in turn sold to the Soka University of American in 1986. In 2007, Soka sold the property to the National Park Service, which intends to restore and preserve it.

row.title: Clark Gable and Rosalind Russell in "They Met in Bombay"
row.abstract: "They Met in Bombay" is the story of Gerald Meldrick (Clark Gable) and Anya Von Duren (Rosalind Russell), two jewel thieves intent on stealing a gem from India. After failing independently, they decide to team up. Meldrick intends to let von Duren commit the initial theft and then steal the jewel from her, but she discovers his plans and soon both are fugitives in China. They manage to outwit Inspector Cressney (Matthew Boulton) and mercenary freighter captain Chang (Peter Lorre), but are finally drawn into a pitched battle with invading Japanese forces.

row.title: East Tennessee Hospital for the Insane
row.abstract: The East Tennessee Hospital for the Insane opened in 1886 with 99 patients transferred from the older Tennessee Lunatic Asylum in Nashville. In 1920, the facility's name was changed to Eastern State Hospital as part of a program to rename all of the asylums in the state. The facility was updated in 1971 after a number of deficiencies were exposed. The hospital's name was changed again, this time incorporating the phrase "Mental Health Institute," in 1977. It continues to operate as a mental health care center today.

row.title: Directors of the Appalachian Exposition
row.abstract: The 1910 Appalachian Exposition was held from September 12 to October 12 in Knoxville's Chilhowee Park. The first of its kind in Appalachia, the Fair was intended to demonstrate Southern progress in industry and commerce and to advocate the preservation of the area's natural resources. The fair did not, however, achieve its broader goal%3A to turn Knoxville into a model New South city.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Aftermath of the "Million Dollar Fire"
row.abstract: View of Gay Street after Knoxville's "Million Dollar Fire." This fire, which occurred on April 7, 1897, started in the Hotel Knox and consumed most of the 400 block of Gay Street before being stopped at the Sanford, Chamberlain & Albers Company Building with a firewall. The fire killed three people and a rare white mule (visiting Knoxville with an itinerant circus). The mule's ghost is said to have started a number of small fires in the area since.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Rudolph Valentino in "The Eagle"
row.abstract: Based on a Pushkin novel, "The Eagle" stars Rudolph Valentino as a Russian cossack named Vladimir Dubrouvsky. He is one of Catherine the Great's particular favorites, but he will not be kept as a lover and spurns her advances. When Kyrilla Troekouroff steals his lands, he creates a secret identity, "The Black Eagle," and becomes a masked avenger. Although bent on revenge, he falls in love with Troekouroff's daughter, Mascha (Vilma Banky). Mascha, in turn, worships the Eagle but disdains his unmasked identity, her foppish French tutor Monsieur Le Blanc. Dubrouvsky's love for Masha eventually counteracts his desire for revenge against her father, and the couple flee Troekouroff's estate. Although captured by the Czarina's men, Catherine rescinds her orders to execute the Eagle and the pair escape to Paris.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Gillette Ranch Sitting Room
row.abstract: In 1926, Razor baron King Camp Gillette commissioned Wallace Neff to build him a "paradise on earth" in Southern California. The result was a stunning 25 room mansion built in the Spanish Colonial Revival Style whose beauty supposedly brought Gillette to tears. Gillette died in 1932, and his widow sold the property to prominent film director Clarence Brown in 1935. Brown regularly hosted large parties for well-known Hollywood personalities here, and made several changes to the property, including the addition of a projection room and a small airport. He sold the property to the Claretian Order of the Catholic Church in 1952, which used it as a seminary and noviate. The Claretians subsequently sold to Elizabeth Clair Prophet's Church Universal and Triumphant in 1977, which in turn sold to the Soka University of American in 1986. In 2007, Soka sold the property to the National Park Service, which intends to restore and preserve it.

row.title: Baker-Himel School
row.abstract: Lewis M.G. Baker and Charles M. Himel established this private school, located on the corner of Highland and 12th Streets, in 1889. It was dedicated to preparing boys for college, and for many years the University of Tennessee and several other schools admitted its graduates without further examination. The school's building was destroyed by fire in 1893 but was replaced by a larger structure later that year. It finally closed in 1913.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Clarence Brown Directing "Flesh and the Devil"
row.abstract: "Flesh and the Devil" tells the story of two Austrian military men, Leo von Harden (John Gilbert) and Ulrich von Eltz (Lars Hanson), who have been friends since childhood. At the beginning of the movie, von Harden meets (and begins an affair with) Felicitas (Greta Garbo). When her husband Count Von Rhaden (Marc MacDermott) discovers them, he challenges von Harden to a duel. von Harden kills the Count, but his superiors send him to Africa as punishment. When he returns, it is to find Felicitas married to von Eltz, who he had asked to take care of her during his absence. von Harden eventually loses control of himself, and the movie ends with a climactic duel between the two former friends.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Mrs. Jane Kennedy's Home
row.abstract: Four children playing on the front lawn of Mrs. Jane Kennedy's home. General James White built part of the house itself (the first in Knoxville) in 1786. It was originally located at one corner of a rectangular lot with smaller houses in the other three corners, a common frontier design intended to proctect against Indians. After the White family established a farm away from this location, the structure was repurposed as the kitchen wing of the Kennedy residence on State Street. In 1906, Isaiah Ford purchased the building and moved it to Woodlawn Pike, where he used it as a private residence. It changed hands again in 1970, when the City Association of Women's Clubs purchased the home and moved it back to central Knoxville. It currently stands near the Knoxville Coliseum and is one of the most visited historical sites in the city.

row.title: Donald Crisp and Elizabeth Taylor in "National Velvet"
row.abstract: "National Velvet" stars Elizabeth Taylor as Velvet Brown, an English girl with a passion for horses who wins the spirited but untrained steed Pie in a town auction. Velvet is determined to win the prestigious Grand National, and jaded jockey Mi Taylor (Mickey Rooney) is hired to train her. Although Velvet's father (Donald Crisp) disapproves, her mother (Anne Revere), recalling her own girlhood ambitions, repeatedly overrules his decisions in favor of their headstrong daughter. Against all odds, Velvet and Pie go on to win the Steeplechase at the Grand National.

row.title: Training at Camp Barkley
row.abstract: The original caption for this image reads "Camp Barkley. Dec 9 1941. Co. K. 158th Inf. 45th Div." The 158th Infantry Regiment began as the First Arizona Volunteer Infantry on September 2, 1865. It was drafted into Federal service during World War I as part of the 40th Division and reassigned to the 45th Division during postwar reorganizations. When a National Emergency was declared on September 16, 1940, the 158th joined the 45th for training at Fort Sill, Oklahoma and Fort Barkley, Texas. They were detached from the 45th in December of 1941 and sent to the Canal Zone for training in jungle warfare before being assigned to the Pacific Theater in early 1943. The unit was scheduled to spearhead the final invasion of Japan, which was subsequently rendered unnecessary by the atomic bomb. The 158th was deactivated and sent home in January of 1946.

The 158th Infantry Regiment began as the First Arizona Volunteer Infantry on September 2, 1865. It was drafted into Federal service during World War I as part of the 40th Division and reassigned to the 45th Division during postwar reorganizations. When a National Emergency was declared on September 16, 1940, the 158th joined the 45th for training at Fort Sill, Oklahoma and Fort Barkley, Texas. They were detached from the 45th in December of 1941 and sent to the Canal Zone for training in jungle warfare before being assigned to the Pacific Theater in early 1943. row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Joan Crawford in "Possessed"
row.abstract: "Possessed" is the story of Marian Martin (Joan Crawford), a factory girl who moves to Manhattan looking for excitement and hoping to trade her life on the assembly line for one more posh. When she meets lawyer Mark Whitney (Clark Gable), she thinks her dreams have come true%3A he is rich and handsome and can buy her the life she dreams of. Unfortunately, he is already married and his political ambitions would be destroyed by a divorce scandal. Thus, Martin becomes his mistress and poses as his ex-wife. When her small town ex-boyfriend Al Manning (Wallace Ford) asks her to marry him, she turns him down and he exposes Whitney's sordid private life. Martin is forced to defend her relationship with Whitney at an election rally, and her story moves the crowd to tears. Relieved, Whitney proposes to Martin, thus fulfilling her ambitions.

row.title: The Sunsphere
row.abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

row.title: Gay Street Bridge
row.abstract: The Union Army built Knoxville's first bridge across the Tennessee River during the Civil War. This structure was washed away in 1867 and subsequently replaced by a toll bridge. A tornado destroyed this span in 1875, and a fourth bridge was constructed in 1880. This structure lasted until 1898, when it was replaced by a modern and much-admired steel bridge.

row.title: Knoxville Court House
row.abstract: The first Knox County Court House was designed by architect Drury P. Armstrong and constructed in 1842. It was replaced by a more modern building, built in the Queen Anne style, in 1885. Now called the old Knoxville Courthouse, this structure stands on approximately the site of the Federal barracks of James White's Fort. New wings were added to either side of the courthouse in 1919. Tennessee's first governor, John Sevier, and his wives, Sarah Hawkins and Catherine "Bonny Kate" Sherrill, are buried on the lawn.

row.title: Sand and Gravel Company
row.abstract: Like all of the sand and gravel manufacturing plants operating in Knoxville in 1939, this establishment was located on the banks of the Tennessee River. According to Victor Hyde, such mills were of of considerable local economic importance even though they produced much less than the plants in Western Tennessee and little of their product was shipped outside of East Tennessee.

row.title: C.J. McClung Residence
row.abstract: Charles J. McClung, Franklin H. McClung, and James Cowan operated an extremely successful dry goods wholesale business called Cowan, McClung, and Co. in central Knoxville during the early part of the 20th century. Built in 1875, this home was designed by Nashville architect P.J. Williamson and stood on Main Avenue until it was destroyed in about 1964.

row.title: Clarence Brown and Greta Garbo on the Set of "Flesh and the Devil"
row.abstract: "Flesh and the Devil" tells the story of two Austrian military men, Leo von Harden (John Gilbert) and Ulrich von Eltz (Lars Hanson), who have been friends since childhood. At the beginning of the movie, von Harden meets (and begins an affair with) Felicitas (Greta Garbo). When her husband Count Von Rhaden (Marc MacDermott) discovers them, he challenges von Harden to a duel. von Harden kills the Count, but his superiors send him to Africa as punishment. When he returns, it is to find Felicitas married to von Eltz, who he had asked to take care of her during his absence. von Harden eventually loses control of himself, and the movie ends with a climactic duel between the two former friends.

row.title: Aftermath of the "Million Dollar Fire"
row.abstract: View of Gay Street after Knoxville's "Million Dollar Fire." This fire, which occurred on April 7, 1897, started in the Hotel Knox and consumed most of the 400 block of Gay Street before being stopped at the Sanford, Chamberlain & Albers Company Building with a firewall. The fire killed three people and a rare white mule (visiting Knoxville with an itinerant circus). The mule's ghost is said to have started a number of small fires in the area since.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Scene from "The Eagle"
row.abstract: Based on a Pushkin novel, "The Eagle" stars Rudolph Valentino as a Russian cossack named Vladimir Dubrouvsky. He is one of Catherine the Great's particular favorites, but he will not be kept as a lover and spurns her advances. When Kyrilla Troekouroff steals his lands, he creates a secret identity, "The Black Eagle," and becomes a masked avenger. Although bent on revenge, he falls in love with Troekouroff's daughter, Mascha (Vilma Banky). Mascha, in turn, worships the Eagle but disdains his unmasked identity, her foppish French tutor Monsieur Le Blanc. Dubrouvsky's love for Masha eventually counteracts his desire for revenge against her father, and the couple flee Troekouroff's estate. Although captured by the Czarina's men, Catherine rescinds her orders to execute the Eagle and the pair escape to Paris.

row.title: Water Merchant Richard "Uncle Dick" Payne
row.abstract: Richard "Uncle Dick" Payne (1813-1885) sold water to Knoxvillians from his two-wheeled cart from 1845 until his death in 1885. He was an extremely popular merchant and is generally recognized as Knoxville's first "water works." Payne Street (in the Reservoir Hill area) is named in his honor.

row.title: Ellis and Earnest Drugstore
row.abstract: College friends Wilbur Ellis and Harold Ernest opened Ellis and Ernest Drugstore near the University of Tennessee campus in 1926. For many years, E&E served as a popular gathering place for UT students as well as Knoxville residents and tourists. The drugstore was razed in the late 1960s in order to accommodate the Carolyn P. Brown University Center, but the establishment was commemorated with the Ellis and Ernest Friendship Walk.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Greta Garbo in "Romance"
row.abstract: Presented as a series of flashbacks, "Romance" stars Greta Garbo as famous operatic soprano Madame Rita Cavallini. Thomas Armstrong (Gavin Gordon), and aristocratic clergyman, falls in love with Cavallini at a party and the two begin a relationship in spite of his family's disapproval and rumors of her checkered past. Their plans for marriage dissolve when Armstrong discovers that she was previously involved with his uncle, Cornelius 'Corny' Van Tuyl (Lewis Stone). Armstrong denounces her and the two never see each other again. Unfortunately, his story does not dissuade his grandson Harry (Elliott Nugent) from marrying an actress, and Armstrong later reads of Cavallini's death in the newspaper.

row.title: Gay Street Bridge
row.abstract: The Union Army built Knoxville's first bridge across the Tennessee River during the Civil War. This structure was washed away in 1867 and subsequently replaced by a toll bridge. A tornado destroyed this span in 1875, and a fourth bridge was constructed in 1880. This structure lasted until 1898, when it was replaced by a modern and much-admired steel bridge.

row.title: The Candy Factory
row.abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

row.title: Ayres Hall
row.abstract: Ayres Hall, named for UT president Brown Ayres, was constructed in 1919 to replace decaying Old College, East College, and West College. Although money was raised to preserve Old College (dear to many alumni) it was discovered that its brick, which had been cheaply made, had decayed to the point that it was unsafe to move and the building was razed. Ayres Hall was dedicated in 1921 and has served as the campus's "landmark building" ever since. Chi Omega donated Ayres' first set of chimes in 1950, which rang every quarter hour until they were stolen by vandals in the early 1970s. The Class of 1991 replaced the chimes as their senior gift, thus reviving the tradition of "telling time by Ayres' chimes."

row.title: Will Geer and Juano Hernandez in "Intruder in the Dust"
row.abstract: Will Geer (who played Sheriff Hampton) and Juano Hernandez in "Intruder in the Dust." The movie is set in rural Mississippi during the 1940s and features Juano Hernandez as Lucas Beauchamp, a black man with a reputation for standing up to whites. When Beauchamp is found standing over a white man's dead body, he is immediately jailed. He insists that he is innocent and asks the town's most prominent lawyer, Gavin Stevens (David Brian), to defend him, but Stevens refuses. The situation changes, however, when a local boy named Chick Mallison (Claude Jarman Jr.) who Beauchamp has helped in the past hears talk of an impending lynching and begs Stevens to change his mind.

row.title: Hotel Farragut
row.abstract: Named after Admiral David Glasgow Farragut, the Hotel Farragut opened on the corner of Gay and Clinch (the site of the old Imperial Hotel) on February 1, 1919. It flourished until 1929 when the Andrew Johnson Hotel opened nearby, after which time the two hotels provided each other with stiff competition. The Farragut closed in 1977 and was converted into office space in 1978.

row.title: Whittle Springs Hotel
row.abstract: The original Whittle Springs Hotel (shown) was built in about 1902 about three miles to the north of Knoxville. It advertised such conveniences as electric lights, baths, unexcelled cuisine, and both telephone and telegraph connections. This structure burned in 1919, and the second Whittle Springs Hotel was constructed on the same site. This building was razed in 1964.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Knoxville's First Market House
row.abstract: Knoxville's original Market House was built in 1816. During the Civil War, the Union used the Market House to store ammunition and business was conducted outside. A new Market House was built in 1897 and merchants offered a wide variety of items, including baked goods, fresh meats, and homegrown fruits and vegetables from permanent stalls and wagons parked outside. After being partially destroyed by fire, this structure was demolished to make way for the Market Street Mall in 1960.

row.abstract: Row of "Shot Gun" houses on Knoxville's King Street. According to Hyde, these homes are located in a D-Class neighborhood%3A one "occupied by negroes, irrespective of property value." Structures in these sections tend to be "of the poorest type, being constructed of unfinished lumber loosely thrown together and stripped" although some were previously part of slightly more prosperous C-Class neighborhoods.

row.title: John T. Whitaker and Mary Maverick (Lloyd) Whitaker
row.abstract: John Thompson Whitaker was born on January 25, 1906. He earned his A.B. from the University of the South in 1927 and went on to write for the Chattanooga News and the New York Herald Tribune. He eventually became a foreign correspondent and covered the Ethiopian and Spanish Civil Wars before being stationed in Europe during World War II. He wrote three books%3A And Fear Came (1936), Americas to the South (1939), and We Cannot Escape History (1943). He died on September 11, 1946. The woman shown with Whitaker is most likely his first wife, Mary Maverick Lloyd (1905-1976), who devoted her life to the cause of world government and citizenship.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Chilhowee Park
row.abstract: Swimmers in Chilhowee Park#x0027;s lake. Visible are the extreme left side of the Liberal Arts Building (constructed for the National Conservation Exposition of 1913) and the lake#x0027;s distinctive walkway. Originally known as Lake Ottossee, Chilhowee Park began to develop as a recreational area in 1890 when William G. McAdoo opened a streetcar line making the lake easily accessible from Knoxville. The area was renamed Chilhowee Park in 1900 and was the site of several expositions between 1910 and 1913. Although it has lost some of its former grandeur, the Park is still a popular recreation area today.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Lobby Card for "The Yearling"
row.abstract: "The Yearling" tells the story of an American family living in Florida shortly after the Civil War. Ezra "Penny" Baxter (Gregory Peck) is a hardworking farmer struggling to support his wife, Orry (Jane Wyman), and single surviving son, Jody (Claude Jarman, Jr.). When Penny is bitten by a rattlesnake, he is forced to kill a doe to obtain the necessary antivenin. Jody begs to keep her orphaned faun, and his father agrees. When the faun becomes a yearling, however, it begins breaking into the garden that the family depends on for both food and money. As a result, Jody is forced to make a heartbreaking choice.

row.title: Fort James White
row.abstract: General James White built this house, the first in Knoxville, in 1786. It was originally located at one corner of a rectangular lot with smaller houses in the other three corners, a common frontier design intended to protect against Indians. After the White family established a farm away from this location, the structure was repurposed as the kitchen wing of the Kennedy residence on State Street. In 1906, Isaiah Ford purchased the building and moved it to Woodlawn Pike, where he used it as a private residence. It changed hands again in 1970, when the City Association of Women's Clubs purchased the home and moved it back to central Knoxville. It currently stands near the Knoxville Coliseum and is one of the most visited historical sites in the city.

row.abstract: Clay Brown Atkin (1864-1931) built the Hotel Atkin in the late 1870s on Knoxville's Gay Street. Atkin also ran a business manufacturing furniture and mantels, developed a number of other Knoxville and Fountain City properties, and served as director of a number of local organizations.

row.title: American Limestone Company Mine
row.abstract: The American Limestone Company was established in 1913 to process some of the rock generated by the zinc mines near Knoxville. In 1971, the American Smelting and Refining Company (ASARCO) bought the American Limestone Company, including all four of its Knoxville mines. It continues to process limestone in East Tennessee today.

row.title: Hubert R. Knickerbocker
row.abstract: This image most likely shows Hubert Renfro Knickerbocker (1898-1949), who was a prominent foreign correspondent for such newspapers as the New York Evening Post and the Philadelphia Public Ledger. He covered such conflicts as the Italo-Abyssinian War (1935-1936), the Spanish Civil War (1936-1937), and the Sino-Japanese War (1937) before working in Europe during World War II. He also taught journalism at Southern Methodist University (1922-1923) and wrote a number of books.

row.title: Kingdom of Saudi Arabia's Pavilion and Ayres Hall
row.abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

row.title: Kingston Pike at Scenic Drive
row.abstract: Intersection of Kingston Pike and Scenic Drive during the late 19th century. The Pike began as a 15-mile toll road stretching from Knoxville to Campbell's Station. It had been completely paved by the 1920s and began to develop as a commercial area in the 1930s. It still serves as a major Knoxville thoroughfare today.

row.title: View of Strong Hall (White Avenue Entrance)
row.abstract: Sophronia Strong Hall (known colloquially as "Sophie's") was built in 1925 when the University found itself in need of a larger women's dormitory. Benjamin Rush Strong (1848-1915) had left the University $30,000 in his will for the purpose on the condition that the resulting building be named after his mother, Sophronia (Marrs) Strong, and that a wildflower garden be planted every spring in her memory. Several wings were added in the 1950s, each named after one of the first co-eds to attend the University. Sophronia Strong's ghost was said to watch over the Hall's residents, appearing as a lady dressed in white on her birthday (February 17) and perpetrating various harmless pranks. The last residents of the hall moved out after the 2008 Spring Semester and the building was put to other uses.

row.title: Clarence Brown Directing "Anna Karenina"
row.abstract: "Anna Karenina" stars Greta Garbo as the sheltered wife of Czarist official Karenin (Basil Rathbone). She is not happy in her marriage, however, and soon falls in love with Count Vronsky (Frederic March). When this affair is discovered, Anna Karenina is cast out of upper-class Russian society and is even prohibited from seeing her son, Sergei (Freddie Bartholomew), whose father tells him that his mother is dead. Anna Karenina follows Vronsky to Venice and later to St. Petersburg, where he deserts her to fight in the Turkish-Serbian War. She is finally driven to suicide, and throws herself under a train.

row.title: Gillette Ranch Sitting Room
row.abstract: In 1926, Razor baron King Camp Gillette commissioned Wallace Neff to build him a "paradise on earth" in Southern California. The result was a stunning 25 room mansion built in the Spanish Colonial Revival Style whose beauty supposedly brought Gillette to tears. Gillette died in 1932, and his widow sold the property to prominent film director Clarence Brown in 1935. Brown regularly hosted large parties for well-known Hollywood personalities here, and made several changes to the property, including the addition of a projection room and a small airport. He sold the property to the Claretian Order of the Catholic Church in 1952, which used it as a seminary and noviate. The Claretians subsequently sold to Elizabeth Clair Prophet's Church Universal and Triumphant in 1977, which in turn sold to the Soka University of American in 1986. In 2007, Soka sold the property to the National Park Service, which intends to restore and preserve it.

row.title: Clarence Brown and Spud Manning by Plane
row.abstract: Clarence Brown (left) and Herbert Emerson "Spud" Manning (right) by Brown's plane. At the National Air Races (held on July 1-4), Brown piloted the plane to 11,000 feet and Manning jumped to "thrill spectators in the grandstand." Manning, whose specialty was opening his parachute at the last moment, died in a boating accident later in the year.

row.title: Central Methodist Episcopal Church, South
row.abstract: Central Methodist Episcopal Church South, designed by Chattanooga architect R.H. Hunt, was dedicated in March of 1927. It represented a combination of two older Knoxville Methodist congregations: Broad Street and Centenary. The church was renamed Central United Methodist Church when the United Methodist Church was formed in 1968. Although membership has dwindled, the church continues to operate today.

row.title: Park City High School
row.abstract: Park City High School was built in 1907. For a brief time, it was the largest high school in Knoxville. It later became Park Lowry Grammar School and was closed in 1982. The building was sold to private contractors in the mid 1980s, but was completely razed after being badly damaged by fire in September of 1987.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Gay Street Bridge and Tennessee River
row.abstract: The Union Army built Knoxville's first bridge across the Tennessee River during the Civil War. This structure was washed away in 1867 and subsequently replaced by a toll bridge. A tornado destroyed this span in 1875, and a fourth bridge was constructed in 1880. This structure lasted until 1898, when it was replaced by a modern and much-admired steel bridge.

row.title: Central Methodist Episcopal Church, South
row.abstract: Central Methodist Episcopal Church South, designed by Chattanooga architect R.H. Hunt, was dedicated in March of 1927. It represented a combination of two older Knoxville Methodist churches%3A Broad Street and Centenary. The church was renamed Central United Methodist Church when the United Methodist Church was formed in 1968. Although membership has dwindled, the church continues to operate today.

row.title: John Whitaker and Unidentified Woman
row.abstract: John Thompson Whitaker was born on January 25, 1906. He earned his A.B. from the University of the South in 1927 and went on to write for the Chattanooga News and the New York Herald Tribune. He eventually became a foreign correspondent and covered the Ethiopian and Spanish Civil Wars before being stationed in Europe during World War II. He wrote three books%3A And Fear Came (1936), Americas to the South (1939), and We Cannot Escape History (1943). He died on September 11, 1946.

row.title: Donald Crisp in "National Velvet"
row.abstract: "National Velvet" stars Elizabeth Taylor as Velvet Brown, an English girl with a passion for horses who wins the spirited but untrained steed Pie in a town auction. Velvet is determined to win the prestigious Grand National, and jaded jockey Mi Taylor (Mickey Rooney) is hired to train her. Although Velvet's father (Donald Crisp) disapproves, her mother (Anne Revere), recalling her own girlhood ambitions, repeatedly overrules his decisions in favor of their headstrong daughter. Against all odds, Velvet and Pie go on to win the Steeplechase at the Grand National.

row.title: Knoxville General Hospital
row.abstract: Knoxville General Hospital opened on Cleveland Place in 1902. It served as Knoxville's primary hospital until August of 1956, when it was replaced by the University of Tennessee Memorial Hospital (now the University of Tennessee Medical Center).

row.title: Clark Gable and Myrna Loy in "Wife vs. Secretary"
row.abstract: "Wife vs. Secretary" tells the story of Van Stanhope (Clark Gable), an industrious magazine publisher who is happily married to Linda (Myrna Loy). Although his secretary, Helen "Whitey" Wilson (Jean Harlow), is in love with him, she respects his marriage and takes pains to ensure that their relationship remains strictly professional. Linda is suspicious, however, especially since her mother (May Robson) frequently suggests that Van is being unfaithful. These suspicions are apparently confirmed when Van takes Whitey on an important business trip to Cuba. Linda is infuriated, but Whitey manages to convince her that her husband has never betrayed her, thus saving their marriage.

row.title: Perez Dickinson Home
row.abstract: Perez Dickinson was born in Amherst, Massachusetts in 1813. He moved to Knoxville in about 1830, where he quickly became an extremely popular and successful merchant. He had this elegant home at the corner of Main and Locust Streets built in 1831. After his death in 1901, C.B. Atkin bought the house and made several additions, including a front portico in the classic colonial style. The structure was demolished in about 1950.

row.title: Company Fatigue Detail
row.abstract: The original caption for this image reads "Company fatigue detail - unloading gravel in company street. March-1941. Camp Barkley, Texas. Co. K 158th Inf. 45th Div." The 158th Infantry Regiment began as the First Arizona Volunteer Infantry on September 2, 1865. It was drafted into Federal service during World War I as part of the 40th Division and reassigned to the 45th Division during postwar reorganizations. When a National Emergency was declared on September 16, 1940, the 158th joined the 45th for training at Fort Sill, Oklahoma and Fort Barkley, Texas. They were detached from the 45th in December of 1941 and sent to the Canal Zone for training in jungle warfare before being assigned to the Pacific Theater in early 1943. The unit was scheduled to spearhead the final invasion of Japan, which was subsequently rendered unnecessary by the atomic bomb. The 158th was deactivated and sent home in January of 1946.

row.title: Woman's Building
row.abstract: The Woman's Building was originally constructed in 1897 as the Knoxville Building at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition in Nashville. The following year, a number of Knox County's women's organizations had the building moved from Nashville to Knoxville's Main Street. Unfortunately, the structure burned in 1906.

row.title: Kingston Pike Entrance to Melrose Park
row.abstract: Melrose Park was originally an upscale Knoxville residential neighborhood. The University of Tennessee acquired the area in the 1960s and began destroying its Victorian-era homes to allow for University expansion in the late 1970s. Although several homes were adapted to house University programs, few traces of the area's original character remain today.

row.abstract: Richard Travers and Claire Windsor in a still from "The Aquittal." The movie tells the story of Andrew Prentice (Charles Wellesley) who has two unrelated adopted sons: Kenneth Winthrop (Richard Travers) and Robert Armstrong (Norman Kerry). Winthrop is married to Madeline Ames (Claire Windsor). When Prentice is found dead, Winthrop is charged with and aquitted of the crime. Thus, it falls to Madeline to find the real killer.

row.title: Entrance to the World's Fair (Red Gate)
row.abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

row.title: Whittle Springs Hotel
row.abstract: The original Whittle Springs Hotel was built in about 1902 about three miles to the north of Knoxville. It advertised such conveniences as electric lights, baths, unexcelled cusine, and both telephone and telegraph connections. This structure burned in 1919, and the second Whittle Springs Hotel (shown) was constructed on the same site. This building was razed in 1964.

row.title: Gay Street Viaduct
row.abstract: This bridge was built in 1876 in order to allow traffic on Gay Street to travel over the railroad tracks. It was replaced in 1919 when Gay Street's northern end was raised by 15 feet and a viaduct was constructed. A number of shops moved to locations under the new viaduct, where they prospered for many years. Unfortunately, the structure gradually fell into disrepair and was closed for demolition in November of 2005. It was replaced by a concrete viaduct in late 2006, which remains in use today.

row.title: Fort Sill, Oklahoma
row.abstract: The original caption for this image reads "This is looking down the street in front of our company. Looking north. Bldgs on right are mess halls. Fort Sill Okla. Nov 14- 1940." The 158th Infantry Regiment began as the First Arizona Volunteer Infantry on September 2, 1865. It was drafted into Federal service during World War I as part of the 40th Division and reassigned to the 45th Division during postwar reorganizations. When a National Emergency was declared on September 16, 1940, the 158th joined the 45th for training at Fort Sill, Oklahoma and Fort Barkley, Texas. They were detached from the 45th in December of 1941 and sent to the Canal Zone for training in jungle warfare before being assigned to the Pacific Theater in early 1943. The unit was scheduled to spearhead the final invasion of Japan, which was subsequently rendered unnecessary by the atomic bomb. The 158th was deactivated and sent home in January of 1946.
