row.title: Mary Olivia Rawls (Mills) Hoskins
row.abstract: Mary Olivia Rawls was born to William and Susan (Dickason) Rawls on a plantation near Commerce Landing, Mississippi on January 8, 1842. Her parents died shortly after she was born, and she was adopted by Captain John Mills and his wife. The family moved to East Tennessee, where Mary Mills attended Dr. Park's seminary in Rogersville and graduated from the East Tennessee Female Institute. She married William Patton Hoskins (1838-1902) on September 26, 1860, and the couple had seven children: Leila Susan, Nellie Temple, James Dickason, Lynn Wood, Horace Mills, Bessie Olivia, and Mary Margaret. Mary Rawls Mills Hoskins died in 1917 in Knoxville, Tennessee.

row.title: Clarence Brown on the Set of "Deep Waters"
row.abstract: The film "Deep Waters," directed by Clarence Brown's mentor Maurice Tourneur, was adapted from the book "Caleb West: Master Diver" by Francis H. Smith and released in 1920. In the movie, Henry Sanford (Henry Woodward) is building a lighthouse at Keyport when he falls in love with Kate Leroy (Florence Deshon). Unfortunately, she is already married to wealthy Morgan Leroy (Jack McDonald). Simultaneously, Betty (Barbara Bedford), wife of master diver Caleb West (Broerkin Christians), attracts the attention of Bill Lacey (John Gilbert), who works with her husband. When Lacey is injured, Betty takes care of him and eventually agrees to run away with him. She soon repents of her rash action, but her husband will not take her back. Later, Lacey's ship is wrecked near the new lighthouse and West makes a dive to recover his body. Upon returning to the surface, he discovers that Betty has been operating his air pump, and the two reconcile.

row.title: Elizabeth Taylor in "National Velvet"
row.abstract: "National Velvet" stars Elizabeth Taylor as Velvet Brown, an English girl with a passion for horses who wins the spirited but untrained steed Pie in a town auction. Velvet is determined to win the prestigious Grand National, and jaded jockey Mi Taylor (Mickey Rooney) is hired to train her. Although Velvet's father (Donald Crisp) disapproves, her mother (Anne Revere), recalling her own girlhood ambitions, repeatedly overrules his decisions in favor of their headstrong daughter. Against all odds, Velvet and Pie go on to win the Steeplechase at the Grand National.

row.title: Gay Street Bridge
row.abstract: The Union Army built Knoxville's first bridge across the Tennessee River during the Civil War. This structure was washed away in 1867 and subsequently replaced by a toll bridge. A tornado destroyed this span in 1875, and a fourth bridge was constructed in 1880. This structure lasted until 1898, when it was replaced by a modern and much-admired steel bridge.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Lawson McGhee Library
row.abstract: In 1885, Charles McClung McGhee established the Lawson McGhee Library as a memorial to his daughter, May Lawson McGhee Williams. The original building on the corner of Gay and Vine was replaced by this white marble structure on the corner of Market and Commerce in 1917. It remained in use until 1971, when a new building was constructed.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Corporal Thomas J. Hawley Jr.
row.abstract: The original caption for this image reads "Corp. Hawley. Co. K 158th Inf. 45th Div. Fort Sill Okla. Sept 1940-March 1941." The 158th Infantry Regiment began as the First Arizona Volunteer Infantry on September 2, 1865. It was drafted into Federal service during World War I as part of the 40th Division and reassigned to the 45th Division during postwar reorganizations. When a National Emergency was declared on September 16, 1940, the 158th joined the 45th for training at Fort Sill, Oklahoma and Fort Barkley, Texas. They were detached from the 45th in December of 1941 and sent to the Canal Zone for training in jungle warfare before being assigned to the Pacific Theater in early 1943. The unit was scheduled to spearhead the final invasion of Japan, which was subsequently rendered unnecessary by the atomic bomb. The 158th was deactivated and sent home in January of 1946.

row.title: Ewell Farm (Spring Hill, Tennessee)
row.abstract: George Campbell Brown was born to Lizinka Campbell and James Percy Brown on November 27, 1840. He served in the Confederate Army during the Civil War and later operated his family's farm, called Ewell Farm, in Spring Hill (Maury County) Tennessee. Under his management, the farm expanded into one of the region's most prosperous plantations. After his death on July 30, 1893, his son Lucius Polk Brown took over the thriving family business.

row.title: Houses on Park Avenue
row.abstract: View of houses on Knoxville's Park Avenue. These houses were part of Welles' Central District, which she reports is characterized by "poverty, filth and squalor ... in many sections" although conditions had improved in recent years. Most of the people who live in the area are "poor whites of unassorted varieties of occupations."

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Berry Funeral Home
row.abstract: Ralph Lawson Berry founded the Ralph L. Berry Funeral Home on September 20, 1928. His son, Fred O. Berry Sr., joined him in the business in 1934, but problems among the stockholders forced both to resign in 1936. In 1937, Ralph Berry, Fred Berry, and Edward Weigel founded the Berry Funeral Home on South Gay Street. In 1948, the business expanded when the Berry Funeral Home purchased and remodeled a structure (shown here) on Chapman Highway. A number of other major expansions were made in later years (including a merger with SCI Funeral Services of Tennessee) and Berry Funeral Home continues to operate as one of the most prestigious mortuary services in Tennessee.

row.title: Knoxville High School
row.abstract: Knoxville High School was built on the site of the old J.Y. Johnston home in 1910 and expanded in 1914 and 1920. It was intended to provide a cultural education and enjoyed a reputation as one of the South's best schools. The school's last class graduated in 1951, after which the structure served as the city schools administration's headquarters. The building was repurposed again in the 1980s, and now houses a number of educational programs including adult education, the adult high school, GED testing, and continuing education.

row.title: Clarence Brown on Umbrella Rock in Point Park
row.abstract: Unidentified man, Larkin Brown, and Clarence Brown sitting on "Umbrella Rock" in Point Park (located on Lookout Mountain near Chattanooga, Tennessee). A plaque near them commemorates the Battle of Wauhatchie. This battle, fought in southern Tennessee and northern Georgia on October 28-29, 1863, was one of the most significant night engagements of the Civil War.

row.title: Post Office and Custom House Building
row.abstract: Completed in 1874, Knoxville's Post Office and Custom House may have been the city's first building to be designed by a professional architect, in this case Alfred B. Mullett. The structure was enlarged in 1910 and operated until a new Post Office was constructed in 1934. The TVA occupied the building until 1976, when it was restored and repurposed as the East Tennessee Historical Center.

row.title: Clarence Brown and Helen Hayes on the Set of "Night Flight"
row.abstract: Lionel Barrymore stars in "Night Flight" as Riviere, a dedicated pilot contracted to deliver mail. He is determined to keep to his schedule, even if it endangers his pilots. Among these airmen is Jules (Clark Gable) who does not respect Riviere but does his best to fulfill his expectations. After he is killed, Riviere has to tell his widow (Helen Hayes) that he is dead. Riviere does not, however, reduce his demands, even after he loses another pilot. Instead, he insists that more men be called up to ensure that the mail is delivered on time.

row.title: Portrait of John T. Whitaker
row.abstract: John Thompson Whitaker was born on January 25, 1906. He earned his A.B. from the University of the South in 1927 and went on to write for the Chattanooga News and the New York Herald Tribune. He eventually became a foreign correspondent and covered the Ethiopian and Spanish Civil Wars before being stationed in Europe during World War II. He wrote three books%3A And Fear Came (1936), Americas to the South (1939), and We Cannot Escape History (1943). He died on September 11, 1946.

row.title: Lincoln Memorial Hospital
row.abstract: Constructed in 1905, Lincoln Memorial Hospital was closely associated with Lincoln Memorial University's medical program. LMU bought the facility outright in May of 1909, and its medical program merged with four others to form the University of Tennessee College of Medicine in Memphis in 1911.

row.title: Fort James White
row.abstract: General James White built this house, the first in Knoxville, in 1786. It was originally located at one corner of a rectangular lot with smaller houses in the other three corners, a common frontier design intended to protect against Indians. After the White family established a farm away from this location, the structure was repurposed as the kitchen wing of the Kennedy residence on State Street. In 1906, Isaiah Ford purchased the building and moved it to Woodlawn Pike, where he used it as a private residence. It changed hands again in 1970, when the City Association of Women's Clubs purchased the home and moved it back to central Knoxville. It currently stands near the Knoxville Coliseum and is one of the most visited historical sites in the city.

row.title: Hotel Atkin
row.abstract: Clay Brown Atkin (1864-1931) built the Hotel Atkin in the late 1870s on Knoxville's Gay Street. Atkin also ran a business manufacturing furniture and mantels, developed a number of other Knoxville and Fountain City properties, and served as director of a number of local organizations.

row.title: Residences on Kingston Pike
row.abstract: Charles McClung built Kingston Pike in 1792. He also commissioned the first home to be built along the Pike, which he named "Statesview." Over the years, other wealthy Knoxvillians built more homes along the road, including Drury P. Armstrong's "Crescent Bend" (1832), Robert H. Armstrong's "Bleak House" (1856), and J.E. Lutz's "Westwood" (1890). Although the Pike has been heavily developed during the 20th century, some portions retain their original residential character.

row.title: World's Fair Entrance (Red Gate) and Neyland Stadium
row.abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

row.title: 1st Lieutenant King and Staff Sergeant Lyle Haug in Africa
row.abstract: Snapshot of 1st Lieutenant Welby Matthew King and Staff Sergeant Lyle Howard Haug of the 109th Engineer Battalion taken during the unit's service in Africa. King (1919-1991) went on to serve in Korea and later settled in southern California. Haug (1918-2002) was a graduate of Madison Normal and taught elementary school in South Dakota before the war.

row.title: Brown using his own camera on the set of "Idiot's Delight"
row.abstract: Clarence Brown using his own camera on the set of "Idiot's Delight." The movie (based on the play of the same name by Robert Sherwood) stars Clark Gable as entertainer Harry Van. Van and his partner Madame Zuleika (Laura Hope Crews) have developed a "psychic" act in which Van gives the blindfolded Zuleika cues that allow her to accurately describe a member of the audience. Zuleika becomes so drunk, however, that she confuses her prompts (even when reminded loudly from offstage by Irene Fellara) and the couple are booed off stage. Years later, Van and Fellara (Norma Shearer) meet in a hotel in Geneva and a series of antics ensue. The pair's shallow lives provide a vivid counterpoint to a world on the brink of war.

row.title: Mary Olivia Rawls (Mills) Hoskins and Betsey Olivia Beeler
row.abstract: Mary Olivia Rawls was born to William and Susan (Dickason) Rawls on a plantation near Commerce Landing, Mississippi on January 8, 1842. Her parents died shortly after she was born, and she was adopted by Captain John Mills and his wife. The family moved to East Tennessee, where Mary Mills attended Dr. Park's seminary in Rogersville and graduated from the East Tennessee Female Institute. She married William Patton Hoskins (1838-1902) on September 26, 1860, and the couple had seven children: Leila Susan, Nellie Temple, James Dickason, Lynn Wood, Horace Mills, Bessie Olivia, and Mary Margaret. Bessie Hoskins married Ulysses Beeler in 1897, and the couple had one child, Betsey, in 1915. Mary Rawls Mills Hoskins died in 1917 in Knoxville, Tennessee.

row.title: William Blount Mansion
row.abstract: William Blount (who signed the US Constitution and served as the Governor of the Territory of the United States South of the Ohio River) and his wife Mary commissioned this home in 1792. In addition to its impressive size, the home boasted a number of features not commonly seen on the frontier, including hardwood floors and glass windows. A group of women led by Mary Boyce Temple led a campaign to preserve Blount Mansion in the early 1920s, and the house became a museum in 1925. It was declared a National Historic Landmark in 1965.

row.title: Market House and Market Street
row.abstract: Knoxville's original Market House was built in 1816. During the Civil War, the Union used the Market House to store ammunition and business was conducted outside. A new Market House was built in 1897 and merchants offered a wide variety of items, including baked goods, fresh meats, and homegrown fruits and vegetables from permanent stalls and wagons parked outside. After being partially destroyed by fire, this structure was demolished to make way for the Market Street Mall in 1960.

row.title: Me-Na-Wa, a Creek Warrior
row.abstract: Menawa (meaning The Great Warrior) was chief of the Oakfuskee Creek towns lying on the Tallapoosa River in Alabama. He was widely known as a talented and brutal warrior. A determined opponent of both Creek Chief William MacIntosh and MacIntosh's 1825 Treaty of Indian Springs (which ceded all Creek land in Georgia to the Federal Government), Menawa took part in the 1826 delegation to Washington, DC designed to repudiate the treaty. Although the group failed to have the treaty revoked, Menawa was instrumental in having a provision inserted allowing the Creek to obtain legal patents for their land. He, along with Opothle Yoholo, later fought alongside American troops against the Seminole in Alabama. This print was taken from a portrait painted by Charles Bird King in 1826, when Menawa was said to be about sixty years old. The original has since been destroyed by fire.

row.title: William Gannaway "Parson" Brownlow Residence
row.abstract: Controversial Methodist preacher and newspaperman William Gannaway "Parson" Brownlow was born in 1805 in Wythe County, Virginia. His zest for confrontation and staunch Union loyalties convinced the Confederacy to expel him from Tennessee during the Civil War, but he returned to Tennessee in March of 1865 when he was elected governor. During his term, Brownlow convinced the legislature to ratify the 14th Amendment (thus sparing Tennessee from Reconstruction) and made great progress toward restoring the State's economic health. He served one term in the US Senate before dying in 1877.

row.title: David Brian, Juano Hernandez, and Claude Jarman Jr. in "Intruder in the Dust"
row.abstract: David Brian, Juano Hernandez, and Claude Jarman Jr. in "Intruder in the Dust." The movie is set in rural Mississippi during the 1940s and features Juano Hernandez as Lucas Beauchamp, a black man with a reputation for standing up to whites. When Beauchamp is found standing over a white man's dead body, he is immediately jailed. He insists that he is innocent and asks the town's most prominent lawyer, Gavin Stevens (David Brian), to defend him, but Stevens refuses. The situation changes, however, when a local boy named Chick Mallison (Claude Jarman Jr.) who Beauchamp has helped in the past hears talk of an impending lynching and begs Stevens to change his mind.

row.title: John T. Whitaker with Unidentified Group
row.abstract: John Thompson Whitaker was born on January 25, 1906. He earned his A.B. from the University of the South in 1927 and went on to write for the Chattanooga News and the New York Herald Tribune. He eventually became a foreign correspondent and covered the Ethiopian and Spanish Civil Wars before being stationed in Europe during World War II. He wrote three books%3A And Fear Came (1936), Americas to the South (1939), and We Cannot Escape History (1943). He died on September 11, 1946. This photograph may have been taken during one of Whitaker's lecture tours.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Clarence Brown Directing "The Eagle"
row.abstract: Based on a Pushkin novel, "The Eagle" stars Rudolph Valentino as a Russian cossack named Vladimir Dubrouvsky. He is one of Catherine the Great's particular favorites, but he will not be kept as a lover and spurns her advances. When Kyrilla Troekouroff steals his lands, he creates a secret identity, "The Black Eagle," and becomes a masked avenger. Although bent on revenge, he falls in love with Troekouroff's daughter, Mascha (Vilma Banky). Mascha, in turn, worships the Eagle but disdains his unmasked identity, her foppish French tutor Monsieur Le Blanc. Dubrouvsky's love for Masha eventually counteracts his desire for revenge against her father, and the couple flee Troekouroff's estate. Although captured by the Czarina's men, Catherine rescinds her orders to execute the Eagle and the pair escape to Paris.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: St. James Hotel
row.abstract: Originally known as the Van Deventer building, the St. James Hotel was built shortly after the "Million Dollar Fire" of 1897. During the 1920s, the hotel developed a reputation as a musical center: WNOX (earlier WNAV) was located at the St. James by 1923, and the Brunswick/Vocalion label set up temporary quarters in the building in 1929. A number of artists, many of whom went on to achieve national and international recognition, made recordings here during the "St. James Sessions" of 1929-1930. The hotel was demolished in 1973.

row.title: Kingston Apartments
row.abstract: The University of Tennessee built the 21-story Kingston Apartments in 1968 in order to accommodate its rapidly expanding student population. The building served as married and graduate student housing until 2006, when New York developer Stanley Mohr bought the property with plans to turn it into a private apartment building.

row.title: Chisholm's Tavern
row.abstract: John Chisholm built this structure, which he operated as Chisholm's Tavern, on land he bought from James White in 1792. He sold the property sometime before 1800. In this photograph, the building is shown in use as a multi-family residence. The edifice was razed in December of 1966.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Camp Barkley Field Kitchen
row.abstract: The original caption for this image reads "Our Kitchen in which we ate from just before our Battle with the 157th Inf. March-31-1941. Camp Barkley Texas. Co. K. 158th Inf. 45th Div." The 158th Infantry Regiment began as the First Arizona Volunteer Infantry on September 2, 1865. It was drafted into Federal service during World War I as part of the 40th Division and reassigned to the 45th Division during postwar reorganizations. When a National Emergency was declared on September 16, 1940, the 158th joined the 45th for training at Fort Sill, Oklahoma and Fort Barkley, Texas. They were detached from the 45th in December of 1941 and sent to the Canal Zone for training in jungle warfare before being assigned to the Pacific Theater in early 1943. The unit was scheduled to spearhead the final invasion of Japan, which was subsequently rendered unnecessary by the atomic bomb. The 158th was deactivated and sent home in January of 1946.

row.title: "Intruder in the Dust" Cast Members and Unidentified Others
row.abstract: "Intruder in the Dust" cast members and unidentified others (possibly local dignitaries who visited while "Intruder" was shooting on location in Nashville, Tennessee). The movie is set in rural Mississippi during the 1940s and features Juano Hernandez as Lucas Beauchamp, a black man with a reputation for standing up to whites. When Beauchamp is found standing over a white man's dead body, he is immediately jailed. He insists that he is innocent and asks the town's most prominent lawyer, Gavin Stevens (David Brian), to defend him, but Stevens refuses. The situation changes, however, when a local boy named Chick Mallison (Claude Jarman Jr.) who Beauchamp has helped in the past hears talk of an impending lynching and begs Stevens to change his mind.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Se-Loc-Ta, a Creek Chief
row.abstract: Selocta was the son of principal Creek chief Chinnaby, who supported the United States during the Creek War of 1813-1814. Selocta served as a guide and warrior during the conflict, and was eventually instrumental in negotiating the peace settlement. It was in part due to his influence that the Creek later ceded their land on the Alabama River. This print was taken from a portrait painted by Charles Bird King in 1826. The original has since been destroyed by fire.

row.title: Entrance to the World's Fair (Showing Neyland Stadium)
row.abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

row.title: John Gilbert and Greta Garbo in "A Woman of Affairs"
row.abstract: "A Woman of Affairs" stars Greta Garbo as Diana Merrick, a worldly socialite who has loved Neville 'Nevs' Holderness (John Gilbert) since both were children. Nevs' father disapproves, and sends Nevs to Egypt to work after convincing him not to marry Diana. Two years later, Diana marries another childhood friend, David Furness (Johnny Mack Brown), who later commits suicide in Paris. As a result of the tragedy, Diana is cast out of upper-class English society and embarks on a string of meaningless affairs with men around the world. She eventually returns to England days before Nevs' wedding to Constance (Dorothy Sebastian).

row.title: Clarence and Marion Brown
row.abstract: Marion Ruth Spies was born in Ohio on January 22, 1905. She worked as a schoolteacher before moving to Hollywood in search of a more exciting life. She married director Clarence L. Brown on November 10, 1947. He had previously been married to Paul (called Polly) Pratt, Ona Maris, and Alice Joyce. Later in life, Marion Brown became one of the major forces behind the Browns' many contributions to the University of Tennessee. Clarence Brown died on August 17, 1987 and Marion Brown followed on May 10, 1993.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: The Pickle Mansion
row.abstract: George Wesley Pickle built the Pickle Mansion (sometimes called Confederate Hall and Fort Sanders Hall) at 1633 Clinch Avenue in 1889. The structure was severely damaged by fire in 2003, but plans have been made to restore it. Pickle himself was a veteran of the Confederate Second Tennessee Infantry and served as Tennessee's Attorney General and Reporter of the State from 1886 to 1902.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Knox County Court House
row.abstract: The first Knox County Court House was designed by architect Drury P. Armstrong and constructed in 1842. It was replaced by a more modern building, built in the Queen Anne style, in 1885. Now called the old Knoxville Courthouse, this structure stands on approximately the site of the Federal barracks of James White's Fort. New wings were added to either side of the courthouse in 1919. Visible in the background is the Hotel Andrew Johnson.

row.title: Brown on the Set of "Sadie McKee"
row.abstract: Sadie McKee (Joan Crawford) is a cook's daughter and works a maid for the wealthy Alderson family. Although she flirts with her employer, Mike Alderson (Franchot Tone), she loves her humble boyfriend Tommy Wallace (Gene Raymond). The couple runs away to New York to get married, but before the ceremony Wallace meets a showgirl and deserts McKee. She decides to stay in the city, and gets a job in a nightclub owned by alcoholic millionaire Jack Brennan (Edward Arnold). Brennan is smitten with McKee, who eventually gives up on finding true love and marries Brennan for his money. She is unhappy, however, and leaves him when she finds out that Wallace is in trouble. With Alderson's help, she eventually discovers that he is extremely ill in a hospital. She goes to visit him, and he pair confess their love for each other shortly before Wallace dies.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Joan Crawford and Clark Gable in "Possessed"
row.abstract: "Possessed" is the story of Marian Martin (Joan Crawford), a factory girl who moves to Manhattan looking for excitement and hoping to trade her life on the assembly line for one more posh. When she meets lawyer Mark Whitney (Clark Gable), she thinks her dreams have come true%3A he is rich and handsome and can buy her the life she dreams of. Unfortunately, he is already married and his political ambitions would be destroyed by a divorce scandal. Thus, Martin becomes his mistress and poses as his ex-wife. When her small town ex-boyfriend Al Manning (Wallace Ford) asks her to marry him, she turns him down and he exposes Whitney's sordid private life. Martin is forced to defend her relationship with Whitney at an election rally, and her story moves the crowd to tears. Relieved, Whitney proposes to Martin, thus fulfilling her ambitions.

row.title: Crowds at the World's Fair
row.abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: St. James Hotel
row.abstract: Originally known as the Van Deventer building, the St. James Hotel was built shortly after the "Million Dollar Fire" of 1897. During the 1920s, the hotel developed a reputation as a musical center: WNOX (earlier WNAV) was located at the St. James by 1923, and the Brunswick/Vocalion label set up temporary quarters in the building in 1929. A number of artists, many of whom went on to achieve national and international recognition, made recordings here during the "St. James Sessions" of 1929-1930. The hotel was demolished in 1973.

row.title: Hotel Farragut
row.abstract: Named after Admiral David Glasgow Farragut, the Hotel Farragut opened on the corner of Gay and Clinch (the site of the old Imperial Hotel) on February 1, 1919. It flourished until 1929 when the Andrew Johnson Hotel opened nearby, after which time the two hotels provided each other with stiff competition. The Farragut closed in 1977 and was converted into office space in 1978.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Students in Strong Hall
row.abstract: Sophronia Strong Hall (known colloquially as "Sophie's") was built in 1925 when the University found itself in need of a larger women's dormitory. Benjamin Rush Strong (1848-1915) had left the University $30,000 in his will for the purpose on the condition that the resulting building be named after his mother, Sophronia (Marrs) Strong, and that a wildflower garden be planted every spring in her memory. Several wings were added in the 1950s, each named after one of the first co-eds to attend the University. Sophronia Strong's ghost was said to watch over the Hall's residents, appearing as a lady dressed in white on her birthday (February 17) and perpetrating various harmless pranks. The last residents of the hall moved out after the 2008 Spring Semester and the building was put to other uses.

row.title: First Presbyterian Church
row.abstract: Although the congregation was established in the 1790s, the original First Presbyterian Church building (called the "Brick Meeting House" was not finished until 1816. This structure was replaced by the one shown here in 1855. This building was razed in 1901 in order to allow for the construction of a larger facility.

row.title: Mary Cora de Garmo Bryan
row.abstract: Portrait of Mary Cora de Garmo (1891-1986) taken at her wedding to Charles W. Bryan (1890-1966) on May 9, 1920. Born on August 28, 1891, Mary was the first child of Frank and Mary Eloise (Donnell) de Garmo. She earned her A.B. (1912) and M.A. (1913) degrees at Washington College and eventually obtained a Ph.D from Cornell University (1931). During her career as a nutritionist, she taught at several educational institutions, edited the "Journal of Home Economics," wrote four books, helped to develop the national school lunch program, and served in a variety of professional organizations. She died in Illinois on May 12, 1986.

row.title: Knoxville High School
row.abstract: Knoxville High School was built on the site of the old J.Y. Johnston home in 1910 and expanded in 1914 and 1920. It was intended to provide a cultural education and enjoyed a reputation as one of the South's best schools. The school's last class graduated in 1951, after which the structure served as the city schools administration's headquarters. The building was repurposed again in the 1980s, and now houses a number of educational programs including adult education, the adult high school, GED testing, and continuing education.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Oakwood Mansion
row.abstract: Charles J. McClung built Oakwood Mansion for his son, Matthew McClung, in 1870. The house changed hands in 1873, when it became home to Matthew's sister Lucy and her husband, Jacob Lytton Thomas. The home was then located at the outskirts of town, allowing Thomas to farm and raise livestock. Railroad contractor Henry H. Thrasher purchased the house in about 1905 and remodeled it completely, adding porches, columns, and the brick exterior. He sold it in the late 1920s to a group of physicians, who renamed it the Howard-Henderson Hospital. It was briefly known as the Acuff Clinic before becoming the Kingston Pike Motel in the late 1950s. When that enterprise failed, the structure was remodeled and reopened as the Kingston Pike Nursing Home. It continued in this capacity until the early 1990s. It was home to a number of businesses, including a beauty parlor and a restaurant, before Sam Furrow purchased it in 1999. The structure currently serves as office space for a number of enterprises.

row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Machinery and Liberal Arts Building
row.abstract: The Machinery and Liberal Arts Building was constructed in Chilhowee Park as part of the 1913 National Conservation Exposition. Although this event dealt only with local issues, it was an ambitious attempt to educate citizens and businessmen about the importance of conserving natural resources. The Exposition was sponsored by President Theodore Roosevelt and continued previous efforts in the field.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Appalachian Avenue on the Appalachian Exposition Grounds
row.abstract: The 1910 Appalachian Exposition was held from September 12 to October 12 in Knoxville's Chilhowee Park. The first of its kind in Appalachia, the Fair was intended to demonstrate Southern progress in industry and commerce and to advocate the preservation of the area's natural resources. The fair did not, however, achieve its broader goal%3A to turn Knoxville into a model New South city.

row.title: Drawing Room in the Blount Mansion
row.abstract: William Blount (who signed the US Constitution and served as the Governor of the Territory of the United States South of the Ohio River) and his wife Mary commissioned this home in 1792. In addition to its size, the home boasted a number of features not commonly seen on the frontier, including hardwood floors and glass windows. A group of women led by Mary Boyce Temple led a campaign to preserve Blount Mansion in the early 1920s, and the house became a museum in 1925. The portraits on the far wall show William Blount (left) and his half-brother Willie Blount.

row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.title: Aerial View of Gillette Ranch
row.abstract: In 1926, razor baron King Camp Gillette commissioned Wallace Neff to build him a "paradise on earth" in Southern California. The result was a stunning 25 room mansion built in the Spanish Colonial Revival Style whose beauty supposedly brought Gillette to tears. Gillette died in 1932, and his widow sold the property to prominent film director Clarence Brown in 1935. Brown regularly hosted large parties for well-known Hollywood personalities here, and made several changes to the property including the addition of a projection room and a small airport. He sold the property to the Claretian Order of the Catholic Church in 1952, which used it as a seminary and noviate. The Claretians subsequently sold to Elizabeth Clair Prophet's Church Universal and Triumphant in 1977, which in turn sold to the Soka University of American in 1986. In 2007, Soka sold the property to the National Park Service, which intends to restore and preserve it.

row.title: Kingston Apartments
row.abstract: The University of Tennessee built the 21-story Kingston Apartments in 1968 in order to accommodate its rapidly expanding student population. The building served as married and graduate student housing until 2006, when New York developer Stanley Mohr bought the property with plans to turn it into a private apartment building.

row.title: John Gilbert and Greta Garbo in "A Woman of Affairs"
row.abstract: "A Woman of Affairs" stars Greta Garbo as Diana Merrick, a worldly socialite who has loved Neville 'Nevs' Holderness (John Gilbert) since both were children. Nevs' father disapproves, and sends Nevs to Egypt to work after convincing him not to marry Diana. Two years later, Diana marries another childhood friend, David Furness (Johnny Mack Brown), who later commits suicide in Paris. As a result of the tragedy, Diana is cast out of upper-class English society and embarks on a string of meaningless affairs with men around the world. She eventually returns to England days before Nevs' wedding to Constance (Dorothy Sebastian).

row.title: Church Street Methodist Episcopal Church, South
row.abstract: When the Church Street Methodist Episcopal Church South building (constructed in 1875) was destroyed by fire in 1928, the structure shown replaced it. Although the new building stood at the corner of Henley and Main Streets, the congregation chose to retain "Church Street" in its name. The church's name was changed to Church Street United Methodist Church when the nationwide United Methodist Church was formed in 1968, and this structure continues to operate as a Methodist Church today.

row.title: Greta Garbo in "Romance"
row.abstract: Presented as a series of flashbacks, "Romance" stars Greta Garbo as famous operatic soprano Madame Rita Cavallini. Thomas Armstrong (Gavin Gordon), and aristocratic clergyman, falls in love with Cavallini at a party and the two begin a relationship in spite of his family's disapproval and rumors of her checkered past. Their plans for marriage dissolve when Armstrong discovers that she was previously involved with his uncle, Cornelius 'Corny' Van Tuyl (Lewis Stone). Armstrong denounces her and the two never see each other again. Unfortunately, his story does not dissuade his grandson Harry (Elliott Nugent) from marrying an actress, and Armstrong later reads of Cavallini's death in the newspaper.

row.title: Southern Railway Depot
row.abstract: This Southern Railway Station was built in Knoxville in 1904. It prospered until passenger traffic began to decline in the 1960s due to competition from airplanes and automobiles. The last passenger train to pass through the station was the "Birmingham Special," which departed on August 12, 1970. The station was renovated in the early 1990s for use by Knoxville architectural firm Bullock, Smith, and Partners, Inc.

row.title: Knox County Court House
row.abstract: The first Knox County Court House was designed by architect Drury P. Armstrong and constructed in 1842. It was replaced by a more modern building, built in the Queen Anne style, in 1885. Now called the old Knoxville Courthouse, this structure stands on approximately the site of the Federal barracks of James White's Fort. New wings were added to either side of the courthouse in 1919. Tennessee's first governor, John Sevier, and his wives, Sarah Hawkins and Catherine "Bonny Kate" Sherrill, are buried on the lawn.

row.title: Distinguished group of intercollegiate agriculturalists
row.abstract: Distinguished group of agriculturalists who sailed on United Fruit lines SS San Jose from New Orleans, July 31, on an agricultural inspection trip to Honduras and Guatemala. They are guests of the United Fruit Company. It is expected that their reactions will prove beneficial to relationships between the Americas and the improvement of agricultural conditions.
